webTitle: Count me out of the England job

fields.headline: Count me out of the England job
fields.trailText: Some advice for the FA - when you ring up Darren Tackle to offer him the vacant hot seat, don't greet him with the word, "Wasssaaap?".
fields.body:
Tuesday
No. Definitely not. No, no. You will find no talk about the England job. Darren Tackle is not going to give his inside tip. He is not even going to reveal who he drew in Wattsy's sweepstake. Far as DT is concerned that is the subject furthest from the lips of your ordinary decent pro. See, there's one thing you can be certain of with managers: there'll always be another one along in a minute. Fact of the matter is, does it matter what muppet they puts out in front of the England mob? It's the same result every time, innit?

That is, bloke picks whoever the papers tells him to pick, they play like a bunch of girls, crowd boos them, papers say them lot should never have been picked in the first place, papers start campaign to see muppet removed, muppet goes, papers call him all sorts of names for deserting his post. And never once does any single one of said muppets save their job by doing the bleedin' obvious: ie pick yours truly.

So if Bobby/Bryan/Peter/ Big Ron/Arsène/Lord Fergie of the Stop Watch - or whoever they gets to put their finger in the gaping hole what is English football - is not interested in Darren Tackle then you can rest assured Darren Tackle is not interested in any of them.

Wednesday
What Darren Tackle is interested in, however, is starting a campaign to stop the use of the phrase "wasssap". Pronto.

Let's get one thing straight. And I'm talking here to all you wannabe heavy dudes thinking that yelling said phrase 25 times a minute is all that it takes to place yourself on the very edge of what's happening. When yelled at high volume by the likes of yours truly into the face of a handy-looking divorcee, after the consumption of several bottles of Uzbekistani lager down at Dell's in the context of an opening line in a chat-up routine, then the above- mentioned phrase is wholly appropriate. When used by anyone else at any other time, it is about as street as Anne Widdecombe.

I was only pondering this very subject on the way home from training and thinking that, just to set an example, the next person what says "wasssaap" in my ear-shot will get a shoeing, when the mobe goes.

"Wasssaaap?" It's Wattsy.

"I'm just on me way home," I says, through gritted teeth.

"No, no, bro," says Wattsy. "That's not the game at all. You should say: 'Just chillin' out, watching the game, having a Bud.' Then I say 'Wasssaaap' again."

"Yeah, right, mate. I'll tell you what's up. I've got someone on the other line so piss off." I flicks lines.

"Wasssaaap?" It's Rodney.

"Jus chillin', watching the game, havin' a Bud," I says, wearily.

"You what?" he screams. "No time for that, boy. You should be at Wembley, remember. You're playing in the last ever game in the stadium. You're in Barry Fry's World XI against the cast of Emmerdale. It's for charity, boy. I organised a fee. Cash. Three long 'uns, pick it up off of the ref at half-time."

"Barry Fry's World XI?"

"Yeah, it's you, one of the Bosnians, eight Peterborough trainees and a bloke with one cap for the Turks and Caicos Islands."

"Still, good to work with Bazza."

"Er, he can't be there, he's doing some radio show promoting his book. Always been your ambition to play at Wembley though boy, eh?"

Thursday
And it still is. I'll spare you the gruesome details of yours truly's attempt to get past the security at Wembley and allow the hallowed turf to be properly graced for the final time. Let's just say in the cold light of day it may not have been the best way to oil the mechanism of my entry to chin the doorman. But then he shouldn't have greeted the arrival of yours truly with "waaassaap" should he? Examples have to be set.

Still, there's always next time. Way candidates is dropping out the race, the sensible punter wouldn't rule out the probability of the first England team at the new Wembley being led out by a certain D Tackle.

webTitle: Officehours: Secretaries prefer men

fields.headline: Why can't a woman (boss) be more like a man?
fields.standfirst: Forget feminine charms. Secretaries prefer to work for men.  Bill Saunders  reports
fields.trailText: Forget feminine charms. Secretaries prefer to work for men.
fields.body:
The office is increasingly becoming a more feminine place. This is not a hunch - or a flash of feminine intuition - but a fact widely supported by informed research, such as that from the Department for Education and Employment's Labour Market Information Database. So today, Bosses' Day, it is surprising to discover that many secretaries would rather work for a man than for a woman.

If you have never heard of Bosses' Day, you are not alone. Even the greetings card industry, its chief advocate, concedes that the event has yet to seize the public imagination. In the US, it runs in tandem with Secretaries' Day which falls in April. This has been rather more of a commercial success, with about 1m cards sold there every year.

In this country, the greetings card industry is more tight-lipped about sales. But suffice it to say that Secretaries' Day does not turn over a lot of business here, and Bosses' Day does even worse. But as Britain's bosses face the annual disappointment of the postman passing them by yet again, they can take heart from a survey from DeskDemon, an internet portal for secretaries, which reveals that they are heartily approved of by their PAs.

Or at any rate male bosses can: the women do not come out nearly as well. While the vast majority of those working as secretaries are women, when asked which gender they would prefer to work for, 64% said that they would rather work for a man; 30% had no preference, and a depressingly small 6% would rather work for a woman.

Such sentiments swim against the tide. Even DeskDemon's CEO Mek Rahmani admits to being "surprised". Surprised, that is, and a little relieved: "Being a male boss myself, it's good to see men receiving acknowledgement for being understanding and approachable bosses."

It's a truism that in the modern, team-playing office, the ability to listen, to be accessible and to encourage are vital skills for any manager wishing to make his or her mark. It is also often assumed that these abilities come more naturally to women than to men. So what are the qualities that make male bosses so much more appealing? It turns out, according to the survey, that most secretaries believe it is men who are far better at listening, encouraging and being accessible: 42% of secretaries described male bosses as "pleasant and easygoing"; 26% described them as more "approachable and understanding".

As so often happens when drawing out gender differences with a broad brush (or a survey), the sticking point in the all-female relationships is assumed to be jealousy. Nearly one-third of PAs who had worked for a woman claimed that their boss felt undermined by their abilities. Bitchiness ranks a close second, with 28% of PAs claiming to have been undermined in public by a woman boss.

These negative reports are not neccessarily supported by outside observers. It has often been noted that in some fields, particularly media and especially public relations, ambitious secretaries are encouraged precisely because so many managers themselves began their careers in administration. But this window of opportunity may be closing, as media increasingly considers itself a more professionalised business, encourages graduate trainees, and draws a firmer line between management and support staff (although these days, of course, many secretaries tend to be graduates, too).

All the same, when only 6% of secretaries in the survey claim that a male boss felt threatened by their talents, this may reflect over-confidence on the part of men rather than a selfless impulse to nurture talent. Yet it is disappointing to discover that 42% of secretaries felt they had been underestimated by a woman boss, whereas only 23% (still, admittedly, a sizeable proportion) of secretaries felt unappreciated by their male bosses.

And given that women still lag behind in attaining senior management positions - about the only level of management that gets the privilege of a PA these days - it is not a good sign that women do extraordinarily well in "the worst boss I ever worked for" stakes: half of all secretaries elect a woman to that role, while 44% choose a man. It's a small gap, admittedly - but disproportionate, considering that women still make up only 22% of managers.

Nevertheless, DeskDemon's survey is not an unrelenting condemnation of women's ability to form working relationships with their own sex. The average length of working relationship between female managers and their PAs is in excess of six years. This is almost double the average time that any PA stays in a job, so some women managers must be getting something right.

It should also be noted that a couple of years ago Office Angels discovered that what few male secretaries there are tend to work for women managers. Perhaps, given the choice, more men would prefer to work for women.

webTitle: Footsie gains a technology index

fields.headline: Footsie gains a technology index
fields.trailText: If recent turmoil still hasn't ruined your appetite for technology stocks, you'll welcome a 'new economy' index which goes live today, tracking UK technology, media and telecommunications companies.
fields.body:
If recent turmoil still hasn't ruined your appetite for technology stocks, you'll welcome a 'new economy' index which goes live today, tracking UK technology, media and telecommunications companies.

The FTSE TMT was developed to meet the ever increasing demand for information in the rapidly growing technology, media and telecommunications sector and will help both individual and institutional investors to keep an eye on how well the sector is doing.

The index will track the share price of the top 50 TMT companies from the FTSE 350. This should prove a valuable reference tool as well as confirm the technology sector's coming-of-age as a force to be reckoned with and not just a passing fad.

Products launched to coincide with the index comprise iShare's exchange traded fund (ETF) and iFTSE TMT.

ETFs are hybrid products - part listed companies in which shares can be bought and part collective investments which pool the resources of investors and buy shares in a number of companies and thereby gain exposure to a variety of risks.

In iFTSE TMT's case, it will buy shares in the companies listed on the FTSE TMT. As the value of the index goes up and down, as will the value of an investment. At present, it is the only fund focusing exclusively on the new index, but the FTSE expects more to hit the market shortly.

The iFTSE TMT is listed on the London Stock Exchange's extraMark, and shares in the fund are bought like any other. The fund hopes that by spreading its exposure throughout the volatile TMT sector, it will get some of the growth without all of the fall. It also hopes to attract investors who have neither the time nor the money to build up individual portfolios and who want to invest in the new economy whilst not exposing themselves to individual companies.

webTitle: On hiding and nothing

fields.headline: On hiding and nothing
fields.standfirst: They seek him here, they seek him there. Do you have an invisible boss? asks Judi James
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: They seek him here, they seek him there. Do you have an invisible boss? asks Judi James.
fields.body:
Ask yourself a few questions about your boss. Does he or she spend the day enmeshed in meetings and only communicate via email and phone? Is your workplace populated with minions whose sole job seems to be to act as corporate bodyguards, blocking all contact between you and the person you work for?

If so, you are working for an invisible boss. Supposedly busy, but in reality scared witless by their own lack of the management skills business gurus preach many bosses are currently becoming more remote than a Tibetan hermit. High-profile bullying and harassment court cases being brought against bosses by their staff make them feel less gregarious.

Give it a go yourself. Pick your victim and get going on the phone. You will - I promise - get one of three responses:

1. Someone you have never heard of before will tell you they are working from home, off sick or at a conference.

2. Their PA will say they are in meetings all day, week or decade.

3. You will be answered by voice mail.

Assuming your boss has a function, though, you may well find yourself with a genuine need to communicate. Empowerment is all very well but sometimes we all need a little steer from above. So how can you cope when your boss has a habit of doing a Pimpernel?

 Track, but do not attack. Stalk your prey out but without being seen. Check for any routines or rotas. Discover busy times and quieter times and plan to approach him/her during the latter.

 Never plan the accidental meeting in anywhere like the lift or toilet, and then start talking business. This makes them nervous or stressed if they cannot even go for a pee alone. Try to make it feel as though they got talking to you, if possible.

 Never get messages passed on unless this is the boss of bosses, someone so remote and omnipotent that face-to-face communication is unheard of in the company. Having said that, though, do not be too fazed by status. If you need to talk to someone you have every right, whatever their job title.

If your boss is still unobtainable, book an appointment to speak with him or her. Make it in person, rather than over the phone. If you cannot get an early appointment, book one anyway for whatever date is available. One colleague of mine was offered the second week in January for an appointment to speak to his chief executive on the phone. His problem would not wait that long but he took the date anyway, just so he could tell the CEO that the system was not working.

People avoid moaners and whingers, though. If you get the chance to speak, throw in some positives. So be concise and plan your communication in advance - or the heady excitement of having finally cornered your prey might be too much for you and you will start to babble in tongues. Write notes.

Finally, make no more than three major points. Most invisible bosses suffer from ADS ( attention deficiency syndrome) and may become more withdrawn if you drown them with your monologue. And once you have made your points always agree on steps for future action. Summarise by re-stating those steps. If no actions are agreed then your hard work will all have been pointless.

webTitle: Jazz review: ED/GE

fields.headline: ED/GE
fields.standfirst:
Spitz, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Spitz, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Computers are a fundamental part of contemporary sound culture, yet their strengths tend not to apply to real-time music. In the studio, they have economic clout and operational flexibility; live, they're inflexible and boring to watch. That's why pop programmes are full of dancing and costumes. ED/GE is a newish way of dealing with this issue - there are nine horns, a synthesizer (the versatile Jim Watson) and a computer on stage.

ED/GE stands for Ed Jones and Geoff Wilkinson. The latter was part of the studio team US3, who struck gold (and platinum) a few years ago when they looped the catchiest bits of some old Blue Note records and added noises to make ersatz fusion epitomised by Canteloop, a clever recycling of Herbie Hancock's Canteloupe Island that swiftly became a ubiquitous lifestyle soundtrack. Jones is an impressive jazz reed player/arranger whose CV includes many US3 sessions.

The debut gig of this new partnership of boffin and blower was part of the Serious Sampler series, which enables experimental ventures such as this to go ahead with a good sound system in front of a small, clued-up audience. If you experiment, you expect to win, fail and make some discoveries, and all that happened on Friday.

Though it was Wilkinson's stage debut, he resisted the temptation to don glitter and feather boa and instead sat impassively at a computer monitor, chewing gum, keying commands to trigger a whole set's worth of rhythm tracks. Jones's arrangements ranged from simple riffs to the complicated busyness beloved of American college jazz bands.

A couple of numbers had Jones's opening cadenza weaving in and out of a spoken word "story of jazz" sample before the beats crashed in. A brave attempt to cover Gil Evans's sublime Las Vegas Tango was thrilling, if over-respectful. A Cuban-influenced number allowed Watson to pay homage to Ruben Gonzalez before the trumpeters shot into overdrive. But these are early days for a band that, given a fair wind (and some smarter software?), may get looser, wilder and tighten up.

webTitle: Pop review: Cinerama

fields.headline: Cinerama
fields.standfirst:
Manchester University
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Manchester University
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Wedding Present, David Gedge's previous band, used to do a cover version of It's Not Unusual. Unlike Tom Jones, however, Gedge isn't regularly showered with lingerie. Tonight, in fact, all he gets is one pair of unsexy white pants, possibly M&S, thrown at him. Those pants are Cinerama in 100% cotton microcosm.

Breasts, beguiling girls and snatched sexual encounters litter Disco Volante, Cinerama's second album, as they've littered Gedge's songs for the past 15 years. Matey hecklers call him "rude", but he's nowhere near that glamorous. Songs like Apres Ski (The Graduate, but English and unsatisfying) resonate precisely because they're couched in the mundane details of guilty liaisons, petty jealousy and those moments when "the wine goes in and the truth comes out". When people shag in Cinerama songs, they're invariably pressed against the kitchen sink.

The fans here have grown up with Gedge. They don't want to revel in nostalgia - there are no Weddoes' songs and, Wow aside, scant reminders of that band's growling guitars; they're here because Gedge still candidly picks at the awkward areas of relationships while turning a fine tune. These are two things that you'll always need, even if you spend more time than you should looking for tile adhesive/babysitters these days. Cinerama are unmistakably indie, but lean, colourful indie.

Simple chords are arranged cleverly, and old tricks - quiet/loud guitars in 146 Degrees - are given a new zip, treated deftly. Maniac - keyboards whirling like a carousel - and Dance, Girl, Dance, for instance, are indie tunes that swing their hips insouciantly. People dance like it's Leeds Poly disco, 1987, all over again.

Gedge describes Lollobrigida as "difficult to sing", but he finds every song hard. In a good way. His half-spoken intonation is full of subtle cadences, while his "crooning" voice is deep, wounded. Maybe he's just struggling for the notes, but he sounds passionate, exasperated, fit-to-burst. More complex songs, such as the clunky Superman, build to anthemic singalong choruses that might sound a little pat, were it not for his brute, overwrought vulnerability.

Charming and unstarry (that's him, by the T-shirt stall), an unapologetically indie Everyman, if Gedge is a man out of time, it's partly because the world has turned bland. Cinerama's compact, imperfect songs sound visceral and energetic. There is life in the old dog yet.

webTitle: Theatre review: Hamlet

fields.headline: Hamlet
fields.standfirst:
Lowry, Salford
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Lowry, Salford
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Another day, another Hamlet - except director Bill Alexander and the Birmingham Repertory Theatre company bring to the classic real ebullience and charm. For a start, the production is beautifully lit by Tim Mitchell. Clouds of dry ice billow across the stage throughout; the whirring of the machine adds eerie accompaniment. Footlights erect shimmering pillars of light and smoke through which the ghost of Hamlet's father passes, and dark chambers are stunningly patterned by a single source. A warm light bursts through a doorway, splintering shadows all around, and in a moment of horrible realisation, Gertrude's shock-white face is caught in a fading cross light.

As well as obscuring the relations between truth and falsehood, good and evil, action and inertia, these etiolated chambers represent the recesses of disturbed minds; with an insidious, menacing music to underthread the suspense, there is a real feeling of claustrophobia and fret.

Richard McCabe as Hamlet worries his way from distemper to despair with a boyish petulance, dancing his diseased wit around the others' incredulity. It's a strong performance, full of wicked smiles and tremulous gestures, and one that rejuvenates the linguistic felicity of all the familiar lines. Hamlet's defiant delirium is nicely judged, too, and his fey sparring with Pal Aron's impassioned Laertes reveals by contrast one man of thought, another of action.

If the rationale for Ophelia's frenzied decline was largely unexplored by the Bard, then Rakie Ayola's maidenly naivety goes some way to explain the deleterious effects of the prince's love. Her delivery is gushing and girlish, and Hamlet's quick scorn entraps her. David Hargreaves offers a well-measured Polonius, Ophelia's father, but Gerard Murphy's Claudius does not quite suggest the regal arrogance that it perhaps should. Nor does his frantic scheming - more comic than condemned - fully relate his increasing desperation.

A striking production, then, and one that approaches the play and its formidable heritage with a laudable, fresh-faced simplicity.

webTitle: DTI rules to curb easy credit

fields.headline: DTI rules to curb easy credit
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is to crack down on lending practices that result in people being saddled with unaffordable debts.
fields.body:
The government is to crack down on lending practices that result in people being saddled with unaffordable debts.

It will outline a new voluntary code this month at a summit with the big banks and other lending institutions to encourage a more responsible attitude to lending.

A broad range of financial firms is to be invited to the meeting with Kim Howells, the consumer affairs minister, who has been motivated to take action after the Citizens Advice Bureaux reported a sharp rise in the numbes of people asking for advice on large debts.

It is the latest move by the government to try to take the financial services industry to task and introduce more consumer-friendly practices and follows the Treasury-backed Don Cruickshank investigation into competition in the banking sector.

It also comes after calls by the government for the industry to offer CAT (charges, access and terms) standards on products ranging from mortgages to credit cards. The leading banks are also braced for an unprecedented level of public scrutiny next month from the competition commission which is investigating their approach to business banking following the Cruickshank report.

Mr Howells is expected to ask lenders, ranging from the big banks to credit card companies and providers of HP schemes, to sign up to voluntary guidelines at the summit.

The minister is expected to set out guidelines, demanding closer checks on applicants' other debt commitments. The DTI is also understood to want the industry to review the notorious small print in loan and other credit agreements.

The decision to call in the lenders follows a report by the CAB which found that debts on store cards, mail order and HP repayments, loans, overdrafts and credit cards had increased by 16% year-on-year.

The CAB, which published the report last month, raised concerns that people were being encouraged to borrow more than they could afford after a 37% rise in visits about debt worries to CABs around the country.

CABs handled nearly 1m general debt inquiries in the year, of which over 500,000 were new problems in the 1999-2000 period.

At the time the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux called on lenders to take a responsible approach to lending by using advertising and marketing which did not encourage people to take on more debt than they could afford.

The CAB produced cases which included a 37-year-old man who had credit card debt of £600 and agreed to £5 monthly repayments but interest was being charged at almost £6 per day and the debt had risen to £4,500 in three years.

The government's concerns appear to focus particularly on people with low incomes and come as it is trying to work with the financial services industry to tackle the wider issue of social and financial exclusion. The banks are already working on setting up basic, no overdraft, accounts in their branches aimed at about 3m people who do not have one. The government is also trying to win their support for a loss-making universal bank in the 18,000 post offices up and down the country.

webTitle: Officehours: Where the money is

fields.headline: Where the money is
fields.standfirst:
City secretaries have had pay rises of 18 per cent in the past year. So brush up your skills and head for town. Dolly Dhingra reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: City secretaries have had pay rises of 18 per cent in the past year. So brush up your skills and head for town. Dolly Dhingra reports...
fields.body:
'Show me the money," demanded the sportsman of his agent, played by Tom Cruise, in the film Jerry Maguire. Routinely quoted to employers by employees - in our dreams, at least - the line is destined for immortality. But for some, money is a dirty word, too vulgar a subject to talk about. Yet it is one of the main reasons we work at all. And if you're a secretary in search of more of the stuff, the City and West End of London is where you need to be, according to a review carried out by recruitment company Crone Corkill.

Surveying the wages of candidates working in Crone Corkill's City, West End and Richmond branches over the first six months of this year, compared with the same period last year, the review shows that junior secretaries are averaging £17,000 with top PAs earning £30,000 to £37,000. They also admit to having placed a director's PA on a salary of £47,000 and a business assistant at £50,000, but those were the exceptions, not the norm, so don't get too excited.

So what do we mean when we say City secretaries? "Traditionally, the City was the finance industry and within one square mile of the Bank of England," says director of Crone Corkill Melanie Melrose. "Now it really has extended, and includes Canary Wharf, and the industries include law, insurance, dot.coms, telecom and property companies. But really, when we talk of the City, we are talking of banking."

The junior secretary sector has seen the sharpest increase in growth. West End salaries have risen, year on year, by 21%, ranging from £14,000 to £19,000; in the City they have increased by a similarly impressive 18.6%. Increasingly, it is graduates who are entering the market as juniors. But what do they look for?

"We have a higher number of graduates than before and a lot of them take a year out and temp. Not all of them want to go on the milkrounds and become accountants," says Melrose. "Graduates realise that secretarial and administrative positions are a good career option. With keyboard skills, they could be earning a salary of £18,000, which compares favourably with entry positions in other professions."

Carolyn Asome, a languages graduate from Manchester University, has been temping with Crone Corkill for over a year. "I've worked for Credit Suisse, First Boston and others, and you have to be very efficient, on the ball, and enthusiastic. Notoriously, banking pays the most. I'm probably earning twice as much in the City as I would working as a waitress," she says.

And yet still there remains a scarcity of secretaries. "Our survey reflects a shortage of really good candidates, with good skills and initiative, which is forcing employers to pay more to attract the best," says Melrose. So what skills do you need to earn all this cash? Are secretaries in the Smoke really any different from others? "Technically, no, but you have to make sure your skills are up to scratch. You need to know packages such as Excel, PowerPoint and Outlook.

"You also have to be commercially aware. You are entering a very particular culture, so you have to have a 'can do' attitude, be prepared to work very long hours - often you have to work late at a moment's notice. Secretaries who are flexible are the ones who get the most offers," says Melrose.

So you might not get the time to spend all the money, but it's not just cash that's on offer. Perks for City secretaries can be excellent, too. Packages can include in-house gyms or reduced rates for membership; performance-related bonuses, lavish social events and financial help with purchasing property. Not bad, not bad at all.

webTitle: Opera review: Don Giovanni

fields.headline: A muddy Don Giovanni
fields.standfirst:
Don Giovanni
Glyndebourne
Rating: *
fields.trailText:
Don Giovanni
Glyndebourne
Rating: *
fields.body:
Graham Vick's production of Don Giovanni was not well received when it rounded off his Mozart/Da Ponte trilogy in Glyndebourne's main festival this summer. In fact, it was panned. But it had already been chosen as one of the works on the Touring Opera's programme, so tour it must. His revival is worth hearing for the singers, but the staging is unlikely to add to anyone's understanding of the opera - let alone their enjoyment.

If Vick intended to imbue the opera with a feeling of uncleanliness, then he succeeded. The set was dominated by a huge pile of earth spilling in from a door on one side; one felt that all the characters should be brushing dirt from their clothing much of the time. The mound was more effective as a setting for the graveyard scene, with bare hands pushing up through the earth, groping for a hold on the world above - until the effect was spoilt by the arrival of a foot, which just made the audience giggle. Another laugh came in the final scene as the Don proved he really could eat a horse, disembowelling the beast with his bare hands. Such gags might have a place in a horror movie, but here they undermined any serious atmosphere of decadence.

The biggest cop-out was saved for Don Giovanni's unrepentant demise. Would he be dragged to hell by the hands in the graveyard? No, he was merely crowded by doppelgangers who then ran with him off stage - possibly to hell, yes, but more likely to the bar.

In the face of all this, the performers were admirable. The orchestra, under Martyn Brabbins, were spirited though a little lacking in delicacy. The Italian Michele Bianchini was a convincing, smouldering Don, although his weighty voice was acumbersome instrument for the role. Mary Plazas's Donna Elvira was very much worth hearing, and Zerlina was prettily sung in Sarah Fox's gauzy soprano. But this cast is wasted on a cynical production whose intentions are as muddy as the set.

 In repertory until October 28. Box office: 01273 813813. Then touring to Woking, Norwich, Milton Keynes, Plymouth, Oxford and Stoke-on-Trent.

webTitle: Comedy review: Rhona Cameron

fields.headline: Rhona Cameron, ruined by television
fields.standfirst:
Rhona Cameron
Komedia, Brighton
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Rhona Cameron
Komedia, Brighton
Rating: **
fields.body:
TV is a dangerous thing, as Roald Dahl reminded us in his dark and nutty morality tale Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. In the Oompa-Loompas' words: "It rots the sense in the head. It kills imagination dead." When the brattish Mike Teavee thrusts himself in front of Willy Wonka's camera, it turns him into a tiny-voiced homunculus nonetheless desperate to repeat the experience.

Stand-up comedians face similar risks. Give a star of the club circuit their own TV series and artistic ambition too often vanishes faster than a body-builder's testicles. You're more likely to find Ann Widdecombe smoking crack in a Brixton stairwell than be surprised or stretched by the likes of Alan Davies or Frank Skinner.

So the omens weren't good for Rhona Cameron's first tour after her BBC2 sitcom, Rhona. Even so, the self-styled "defensive, hard-drinking lesbian" managed to disappoint. This was a night of exhumation rather than entertainment. Out came all the subjects comedy fans believed long dead: shopping; the difficulty of assembling flat-pack furniture; Big Issue sellers; Who Wants to Be a Millionaire; even - God help us - the Six Million Dollar Man. All that was missing was partners who hog the duvet. Cameron's single attempt at topicality only underlined how out of touch she is: sorry, Rhona, but Big Brother jokes now stink like last month's fish. Delivery that was presumably meant to be casual turned out rambling, and Cameron only connected with her audience on the most superficial level: "Brighton means a lot to me - it's full of very attractive lesbians." She dropped most subjects as soon as they got a laugh or two, rather than running with them and risking losing her audience. "You have to generalise, otherwise there'd be no comedy," she told us, which takes some beating for sheer boneheadedness.

The changeovers, meanwhile, had all the grace of an arthritic hippopotamus ("So - cabs, eh?") and only her extended routines about 17th-century stalkers and the stupid rules imposed on airline passengers suggested we were following a train of thought rather than a series of back-of-an-envelope moments. The BBC is apparently mulling over whether to give Cameron another series. For her sake, let's hope the answer is no.

 At Maddermarket Theatre, Norwich (01603 620917), tomorrow; Memorial Hall, Sheffield (0114-278 9789), on Wednesday; then touring.

webTitle: Theatre review: Plague

fields.headline: Plague
fields.body:
"Plague - Dundee": as diary entries go, it's not the most promising prospect. But John Retallack's adaptation of Camus' novel, La Peste, is a darkly gorgeous thing. Like a Hopper painting brought to choreographed life, pestilence never looked so lovely.

In the novel, plague has gripped a city, which becomes a major character. The challenge for Retallack was to give a sense of this while making his drama an engaging story of individuals. This he has achieved through the use of music (Bach, Brel, Messiaen) and dance as a symbolic backdrop. The company, representing the city, moves in line, using jerky movements to suggest the monotony of life before the plague, the horror when it has a hold over them. They swoop to the city's gates as they close, shutting them in; they swarm through the streets, like the rats spreading disease underground.

Against this, a battle wages between the plague (played with vampy spirit by Irene Macdougall) and a doctor (Richard Conlon), struggling to come to terms with the horror he encounters without religion to sustain him. Partly a metaphor for war (La Peste was written in 1947), the novel and this intelligent adaptation ask difficult questions about collective responsibility. Plague still has resonance: it made tough viewing as the Middle East conflict escalated.

With these issues hovering, this poetic, symbolic production is an intense, bleak drama. But it is about life as much as death, how it goes on, and there are lighter edges to the drama. An aspiring writer, author of just one cliched line, grandly burns his complete works, mistakenly thinking he is dying. A journalist visiting the city gets trapped and is frantic to leave; during the year in which the city is closed he decides he has to stay.

As well as handling the big ideas well, this production also attends to the tiny details. The boy, forbidden by his father from talking at the dinner table, screams in death; the table becomes an operating table, and finally the mortuary slab. Plague looks on, her lips twisted, the colour of blood.

 Until October 28. Box office: 01382 223530.
fields.bodyText: "Plague - Dundee": as diary entries go, it's not the most promising prospect. But John Retallack's adaptation of Camus' novel, La Peste, is a darkly gorgeous thing. Like a Hopper painting brought to choreographed life, pestilence never looked so lovely. In the novel, plague has gripped a city, which becomes a major character. The challenge for Retallack was to give a sense of this while making his drama an engaging story of individuals. This he has achieved through the use of music (Bach, Brel, Messiaen) and dance as a symbolic backdrop. The company, representing the city, moves in line, using jerky movements to suggest the monotony of life before the plague, the horror when it has a hold over them. They swoop to the city's gates as they close, shutting them in; they swarm through the streets, like the rats spreading disease underground. Against this, a battle wages between the plague (played with vampy spirit by Irene Macdougall) and a doctor (Richard Conlon), struggling to come to terms with the horror he encounters without religion to sustain him. Partly a metaphor for war (La Peste was written in 1947), the novel and this intelligent adaptation ask difficult questions about collective responsibility. Plague still has resonance: it made tough viewing as the Middle East conflict escalated. With these issues hovering, this poetic, symbolic production is an intense, bleak drama. But it is about life as much as death, how it goes on, and there are lighter edges to the drama. An aspiring writer, author of just one cliched line, grandly burns his complete works, mistakenly thinking he is dying. A journalist visiting the city gets trapped and is frantic to leave; during the year in which the city is closed he decides he has to stay. As well as handling the big ideas well, this production also attends to the tiny details. The boy, forbidden by his father from talking at the dinner table, screams in death; the table becomes an operating table, and finally the mortuary slab. webTitle: Officehours: Danger - temps at work

fields.headline: Danger - temps at work
fields.standfirst: Who's to blame if you injure yourself in the workplace? If you don't know, you're not alone. Most recruitment agencies don't know either. But who's looking after the temps? Kate Hilpern  reports
fields.trailText: Who's to blame if you injure yourself in the workplace? If you don't know, you're not alone. Most recruitment agencies don't know either. Kate Hilpern reports...
fields.body:
At least one person a day dies at work in the UK. And no, it's not only in nuclear power stations, or down the few remaining coal mines. It's in regular working environments, mostly as a result of falls. What's more, 2.2m people have to take time off because of work-related health problems, resulting in 13bn working days being lost annually.

There's worse news still for recruitment agency workers, who make up a significant proportion of the army of support staff, according to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE). "We have found that recruitment agencies in this country are unclear as to what their health and safety responsibilities are towards workers registered with them," explains Frances Gilbert of Bostock Marketing Group, the company that carried out the research for the HSE. "This means that recruitment agency workers may not receive the same level of health and safety protection as other employees."

In other words, temps get a raw deal when it comes to staying safe at work. Nobody, after all, seems quite sure if it's the agency or the host employer who is responsible for looking after them. Mel Draper, head of HSE's policy division, argues that "although most recruitment agencies and host employers claim to exchange information on capabilities, training and health and safety features of the job, the fact remains that a poor level of awareness of health and safety legislation exists."

As a result, temps may not be issued with safe and comfortable work stations, which are essential in decreasing the risk of ailments including severe back and neck pain and repetitive strain injury (RSI). In addition, they may not be using computers with glare-free screens and adjustable brightness and contrast controls that avoid damaging eye-sight. They may not be warned about fire exits and danger spots around the building, and they may be expected to work in an area surrounded by lethally stacked boxes and cabinets. And, crucially, they may not know at whom to direct their frustration when they find themselves confronted with these situations in an unfamiliar office.

Suing a company for damages, now a widely accepted action for any one injured at work if the employer is to blame, is a further grey area for the temp. If they don't know if it's the agency or the hiring employer which is supposed to take reasonable care for their safety - and provide them with safe equipment, plant and premises, adequate supervision and proper training - then they don't know from whom to seek compensation.

The HSE's report reveals that around half of all recruitment agencies do not have measures in place to ensure they are fulfilling their health and safety obligations, and that joining a smaller temping agency is particularly risky. In fact, research shows that, whether or not you're a temp, you are twice as likely to be hurt in an industrial accident if you work for a small firm than a large one. According to the Health and Safety Commission (HSC), many smaller businesses "have greater difficulty understanding their legal duties and are unclear about the action they should take."

So what's the solution? How can support staff - especially temps - make sure they're safeguarded in the future? According to Belinda Brooke, legal adviser for the Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC), a good start would be for agencies, host employers and temps themselves to learn the facts about the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974. "In fact," she argues, "we believe most agencies already know them."

It works like this. There are two types of agencies: those, such as Manpower, where the temp is fully employed by the agency; and the majority, including Adecco, where the temp is engaged by the agency under a "contract for services". "You'll only know which kind you belong to by asking," advises Brooke. "In the first case, it's the agency that is the employer and health and safety is therefore its responsibility.

"In the second case, the responsibility is split. Before you go to any assignment, the agency has a duty to advise you of any accident or health-risk that could occur as a result of the type of work. Say you're doing a copytyping job, you could expect the agency to warn you that there'll be a lot of typing - so if you suffer from RSI, you would have the chance to refuse the job. Additionally, it must tell you who to approach within the host company to inform you about health and safety issues related to the premises."

In both cases, adds Brooke, the employer has a general duty of care for anybody - even if they are self-employed - who is on their premises, but that is legally "weaker" than the Health and Safety at Work Act. "It's complicated," she acknowledges, "but worth getting your head round so that you can make sure you have minimised all risks before you begin any assignment."

So complicated has the legislation become, admits the government, that over the past 18 months, it has, through the HSC, been looking at ways to simplify it. Revamping the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 could, for instance, be something of a solution itself. The problem is that the original act presumed that companies would continue directly to employ most of their workforce. It did not envisage large numbers of people being self-employed, part-timers or sub-contractors. And it certainly didn't envisage the fact that the majority of the secretarial sector would be temping. This means that the supply chain among businesses has become complex, once again leaving ambiguity about who is responsible for health and safety.

A further way forward for secretarial staff may be to introduce tougher legislation that protects workers from violence at work. According to the HSE, there has been a significant increase in the number of violent attacks by colleagues and clients. And while the British Crime Survey does not have a specific category for workplace violence - making figures hard to come by - it does note "acquaintance violence" which accounts for about half of all attacks on men and a third of all attacks on women. An incredible 23% of these incidents involve a customer or client, and around 20% occur at work.

"Receptionists and other secretarial staff who deal with the public may be particularly at risk because they're often the first point of contact for aggressive customers or clients," stresses Sarah Simpson, training director for the Suzy Lamplugh Trust. "There are, in fact, five pieces of legislation relevant to violence at work including, above all, the good old Health and Safety at Work Act 1974. But many employers think health and safety has nothing to do with personal safety. In consequence, a lot don't react until something terrible happens."

Andrew Pemberton, director of Human Focus, a company helping employers to reduce accidents and health risks, is, however, resolutely positive about the future. "We have opened the first UK centre aimed solely at helping employees with neck and spinal pain back to normal work duties, and it has been enormously popular. I'm the first to admit that I don't believe that's because companies are increasingly caring towards their staff. I believe it's because they are finally becoming more financially aware of health and safety.

"Health and safety failures cost Great Britain up to £18bn per year. More and more companies are learning this by the day and if that's not a good enough reason to start protecting staff, I don't know what is."

webTitle: Pop review: Allison Moorer

fields.headline: Allison Moorer
fields.standfirst:
Dingwalls, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Dingwalls, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
She may be traditional down to her oft-repeated felicitations to "y'all", but Alabama's Allison Moorer is hardly a typical country woman, and not solely because she is her own lyricist. In a genre marked by mawkish addiction to despair, she and older sister Shelby Lynne understand genuine tragedy. Fourteen years ago, when Moorer was herself 14, her father shot and killed her mother and then himself. Her current album, The Hardest Part, charts a relationship not dissimilar to that of her parents. However, Moorer sings directly of the murderous evening only once, in the harrowing Cold Cold Earth, which she performs alone. Extraordinarily raw and almost too close to home for public airing, when she whispers the "two daughters he treated so terribly" line, watching her feels like intruding upon the private grief of those 14 years.

Moorer's rich voice has an authentic twang, more Billie Jo Spears than Faith Hill, but with the help of a sympathetic five-piece band she keeps it both country and universally accessible. As with the best of her peers and predecessors, Moorer - black vest, jeans, effective pout - presents her heartbreak in flirtatious fashion. "Have you got your swollen organ?" she teases keyboardist Michael Webb. He blushes underneath his beard.

When Moorer transports herself into the centre of a song such as No Next Time though, the frisky mood alters. This nasty tale of a betrayed wife taunting her philandering husband with his own excuses is standard country fare, but in these assured hands its naked emotion transcends genre. Similarly the Oscar-nominated A Soft Place to Fall, taken from Robert Redford's flaccid film The Horse Whisperer: again, its lyrical sophistication ("ask me anything but where I've been") isn't sacrificed on the altar of porch homily. Is It Worth It, "a song which makes me feel like my insides are on the outside", is another divorce saga. Moorer plays the sultry, wounded siren in a manner that would scare the lights out of husband and producer Butch Primm, were he here and not back in Nashville.

She can rock out, too. Long Black Train and the anthemic Send Down an Angel roar along like a less stodgy Pretenders, while her glorious wailing on guitarist Will Kimbrough III's broody showcase Don't Have a Gun suggests that if it went belly up today, she would conquer the backing vocalist circuit tomorrow. Surely that will not be necessary.

webTitle: Abbey doubles size of agency scheme

fields.headline: Abbey doubles size of agency scheme
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Abbey National is preparing to double the number of branches operating under the innovative franchising arrangement it started testing in August.
fields.body:
Abbey National is preparing to double the number of branches operating under the innovative franchising arrangement it started testing in August.

The bank will today tell about 40 of its 720 branches that they can participate in the scheme, which is beating its internal targets on sales.

Nine weeks into the trial, the 45 branches at present operating as franchises in south Wales, Ealing and Hammersmith in London, and Newcastle have produced sales 20% further ahead of target than non-franchised branches.

The bank believes it could boost its revenue streams by £250m a year by moving towards franchising, which gives local managers more autonomy over their branches. The franchised branches retain the Abbey brand.

The local area managers are given additional rewards for meeting sales targets and could increase their salaries 2.5 times if they meet certain criteria. Abbey has set these tests beyond pure sales to include retention of mortgage and savings accounts, customer satisfaction surveys and controlling variable costs.

The 400 staff already working in franchise arrangements have remained as employees of Abbey National, which has helped the bank avoid regulatory problems.

At a time when banks are aiming to cut costs by closing branches, Abbey's rivals are yet to follow suit and begin franchising. Some admit to being sceptical about its long-term potential.

But Abbey believes the early figures speak for themselves. The average weekly performance in the franchised branches is three times higher than the company's targets.

At the moment, Abbey is only allowing established branch managers to take on franchises but it has advertised nationally the opportunity to run franchises in the future and found 50% of the applicants were from other retail and industry backgrounds.

The next group of franchise branches will be given their new status from the end of this month for a six-month period.

While the franchise branches have risen sharply in their internal rankings, they are not yet the top performers within the group. Of the 143 internal groupings, the four franchises are ranked third, sixth, 24th and 30th in terms of product sales in relation to targets. One of them, however, is selling more bank accounts than any other branch.

webTitle: Opera review: Tristan und Isolde

fields.headline: Tristan and Isolde as caged hamsters
fields.standfirst:
Tristan und Isolde
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Tristan und Isolde
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
There's something about Herbert Wernicke's staging of Tristan und Isolde, the first of the Royal Opera's new productions this season, that reminds me irresistibly of hamsters. Breeding the rodents is a tricky business; they don't get on very well, and getting a pair to mate has to be approached carefully, bringing them together just for a few minutes to do the business and then separating them before they can kill each other. Wernicke treats these most famous of operatic lovers like that too: his set (he's done everything, including the lighting) consists of two colour-coded boxes - blue for the boy, blood red for the girl - and Tristan and Isolde are never allowed to leave these domains, as if close contact would cause them to tear each other limb from limb. Even in the second act the hamsters - sorry, the lovers - never approach within 10 yards of each other, never exchange glances; their boxes move suggestively together and the lighting becomes more elaborate as they get worked up, but that's about it.

The director may be making the valid point that Tristan and Isolde's love is not only artificial (triggered by the love potion that Brangaene administers at the end of the first act), but also a self-centered emotion; that they are in love with the idea of being in love rather than with each other. But that is a very cerebral reading, and when it is combined with wooden acting from the two principals - their risible gestures should have gone out with Victorian melodrama - the result is desperately vapid.

There are pitifully few other dramatic ideas: sailors in blazers and puttees greet King Marke's first appearance through megaphones and Tristan pulls himself on to Melot's sword at the end of Act 1; Brangaene's warnings in the second act are signalled by a wandering torch beam, for all the world like Tinkerbell in Peter Pan, and she takes poison just before Isolde launches into her Liebestod. It's not enough.

The protagonists sound as if they are singing through megaphones. The Isolde, Gabriele Schnaut, seems incapable of anything less than fortissimo, and if the Tristan, Jon Frederic West, cannot quite match her volume he certainly equals the unpleasant acidity of her tone; they make an uningratiating couple. Even the Kurwenal, Alan Titus, barks rather than sings his lines; there was no chance of respite, so that at the end of the first act my ears were ringing as if I'd just sat through a Metallica concert. The only distinguished contributions come from Petra Lang's Brangaene, a real presence on stage, vocally and dramatically, and from Peter Rose's eloquent, touching Marke; but no one goes to a performance of Tristan und Isolde to hear those roles.

Bernard Haitink has craved to conduct this work at Covent Garden for the past 10 years; he obtains superb playing from the ROH Orchestra and brings his usual transparency in Wagner to the score. But the performance never catches fire as it should; when no passion is being generated on stage it must be hard to supply it all from the pit. Haitink made no secret of his dislike of the Richard Jones Ring at Covent Garden, which he conducted so loyally and so well; now, with a production of Tristan that summons up less dramatic energy in four hours than that Ring managed in any four minutes, he will have his work cut out to make it convincing.

 In repertory until November 9. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Officehours: Sec's tips: Leaving

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 7. Leaving
fields.trailText: 7. Leaving
fields.body:
If bosses had any sense, they would never let us go on holiday. It seems that around half of us use the time to take a serious look at our jobs - and we don't always like what we see. According to the Recruitment and Employment Confederation, hardly have we returned the bucket and spade to the cupboard, than we start job-hunting. But the REC believes that even once you've resigned, you should resist the urge to burn your bridges with your employer, and recommends the following exit etiquette.

 Remember your first day in the job? Wouldn't it have been easier if your predecessor had left at least one piece of paper explaining what the job entailed? Make detailed notes about systems and procedures in the office, and identify the key people and how they can help. Explain any outstanding matters, and warn of any sensitive areas that need delicate handling.

 Get all your work up to date before you go. Less charitable colleagues will know that it's easy to blame a departed workmate for problems, so avoid giving them reason to do so. It will help your boss and your successor, and you'll leave with a clear conscience, knowing you have dealt with everything professionally. Sit down with your boss in your last week and explain where you've got to, pointing out any issues that need urgent attention.

 Even though you may dream about it, resist a heated last-day confrontation where you tell your boss exactly what you think of him or her. Even if you feel the company has treated you unfairly, you may understand the bigger picture in time. webTitle: Shoaib injury boosts England

fields.headline: Shoaib injury boosts England
fields.standfirst: Pakistan fast bowler is ruled out as Hussain's men seek to end touring side's bleak record
fields.trailText: Pakistan fast bowler is ruled out as Hussain's men seek to end touring side's bleak record.
fields.body:
England head for Pakistan a chastened side after Nairobi and their wretched performance against the South Africans in the quarter-final of the ICC Knockout Trophy - but heartened by yesterday's withdrawl of Shoaib Akhtar from the upcoming series.

Akhtar, the 24-year-old paceman, was treated by specialists in Australia after being hampered by injury in recent seasons, and he will need to rest for at least a month before returning to full fitness. He misses all three Tests and the three one-day internationals.

He said: 'I'm feeling pain in my shoulder but my knee and ankle are far better. It will take me another month to play at the highest level. I hope to play in England next year when Pakistan tour there and hope to play county cricket in 2002.'

Akhtar or no Akhtar, England are playing against the big boys now. In the summer of 2000, they were able to overwhelm Zimbabwe and a West Indian team who are still in freefall, but when they came across a quality team they were found to be rusty and woefully inadequate. By the look on Nasser Hussain's face at the conclusion of the match in Nairobi, he would probably regard this as a charitable assessment. It won't be any easier in Pakistan.

The defeat against South Africa was not unexpected but the ease with which England were overcome was mildly alarming. There were one or two tactical errors; it was an indulgence for Hussain to bat himself at three in that game, although I doubt whether this made any difference to the outcome. However, in the long term, Hussain's limitations in one-day cricket could become a problem.

In the short term, Hussain has revealed how consuming the skipper's job has become. At the end of the domestic summer, he admits he was drained - despite the success against the West Indies: 'I was tired at the end of the season,' he says. 'The job is on my mind all the time. I'm constantly thinking about selection. I try to switch off but it's difficult especially in England because I'm surrounded by cricket. I find it easier abroad.'

Pakistan, however, presents a real challenge to Hussain. England land there tomorrow in the knowledge that they have only ever won one Test match on Pakistan soil and that was almost 40 years ago. Ted Dexter's side won by five wickets in Lahore in October 1961 in the first of a three-match series, which was interrupted by a five-Test rubber in India. They have not threatened to win there since. Just before you decide that it might be more rewarding to support the national soccer side, perhaps we should also point out that England have only lost twice in Pakistan. On both occasions in 1984 and 1987 they were undone by the magical wrist spin of Abdul Qadir. The other 15 matches have all been drawn.

There are several reasons for the high proportion of draws. The pitches have often been flat and grassless. Rain, mist and fog can sometimes intervene in Pakistan. Moreover, on the hastily-arranged 1968-69 tour, riots curtailed two of the matches; the only one that was not interrupted was in Dacca where there was no police or army presence and the student leaders controlled the crowds far more successfully.

Colin Milburn, who had been playing in Western Australia, joined that party as a reinforcement. The Surrey off-spinner Pat Pocock was dispatched to the airport and mischievously arranged to take him straight to the grottiest resthouse he could find in Karachi as if this was England's Test base. Milburn was suitably aghast but not too dispirited since he went on to score his final century for England before losing an eye in a car crash in Northampton a few weeks later. In those days, food and accommodation could be a problem. Now the players will stay in international hotels almost indistinguishable from those in Sydney or Cape Town. This makes touring Pakistan more comfortable, but less of an adventure.

There were no victories on the next two tours either, led by Tony Lewis in 1972-73 and Mike Brearley, whose broken arm allowed Geoff Boycott to take charge for the final Test in 1977-78. In that match in Karachi, I can't help noticing that Mike Gatting made his debut; in the first innings England suffered a world record of lbws (six), including Gatting, who was also leg before in the second innings. One of the umpires happened to be named Shakoor Rana, who was also in situ when England lost in Karachi in 1984. All of which seems of minor significance until we recall that memorable altercation in 1987 in Faisalabad as the second day of the Test was limping to a close.

England have not played a Test match in Pakistan since that tour and inevitably, Shakoor Rana, who lives in Lahore, has been tracked down and it seems that the incident still represents the pinnacle of his career. 'How can I regret?' he told the Guardian last week. 'It made me the most famous umpire.'

Given the 1987-88 tour and all the recent betting scandals this latest expedition may require a wee bit of diplomacy as well as cricketing resolve and patience. Despite the records, I would not bank on three draws in Pakistan this time. The nature of the Pakistan bowling attack has changed since England were last there - although Akhtar's absence will make a difference. They have always possessed capable spinners, but over the past decade they have had some of the most potent pace bowlers in the world (not just an Imran Khan in isolation). In fact, England's best chance of success will come if the wickets offer some assistance to the pacemen. Hussain's team would love to see a bit of grass and moisture in Lahore, Faisalabad and Karachi since they have some confidence in their own pace attack, but it is a forlorn hope.

None of the England players has ever played a Test in Pakistan, and they will have to overcome a trial by spin. The bowling of Saqlain Mushtaq and whoever is chosen to accompany him will be an ordeal for all the England batsmen. England counter with an unproven duo. Ashley Giles, provided he recovers fitness, has just one Test to his name and Ian Salisbury has so far faltered whenever he has been promoted to the Test arena. If England leave Karachi in December after another trio of draws, they will have not done too badly.

webTitle: Going up? Fayed being served by Tigana

fields.headline: Going up? Fayed being served by Tigana
fields.standfirst: Alan Smith foresees a great future for Fulham, the 'department store' club
fields.trailText: Alan Smith foresees a great future for Fulham, the 'department store' club.
fields.body:
Just over three years ago, I walked into an office at Harrods for a meeting with Mohamed al-Fayed and Kevin Keegan, who told me: 'People may laugh at us but Fulham will be in the Premiership within five years.'

That was in September 1997, when Fulham had just won promotion from the Third Division. Today, as leaders of the First Division with a 100 per cent League record, I have no doubt that they will be a Premiership club next season.

Today Fulham are playing Blackburn - interesting because Fayed is aiming to emulate the rapid rise Rovers enjoyed from the lower half of the old Second Division to Premiership champions in the space of five years.

Using Jack Walker's millions, Kenny Dalglish - like Keegan, a former Liverpool legend - had assembled a top-class side who became champions and were regulars in Europe when Fulham were floundering in the Third Division.

I was at that meeting in Knightsbridge because I'd been recommended to them as the man to set up and run the youth academy at Fulham, and, coincidentally, I'd once turned down the chance to do a similar thing at Ewood Park.

But what sold me on Fulham, quite apart from the fact that I grew up supporting them and have always had a soft spot for the club, was the absolute clarity of Fayed's vision.

He had a five-year plan, along with Keegan, although it looks like Jean Tigana will carry it through to fruition.

Barring a disastrous downturn in fortune, which I simply cannot envisage, Fulham will go up next May and, I believe, prosper in the Premiership. I do not, however, think they can go all the way and emulate Blackburn in winning the title, nor sustain a long-term challenge to the top-six elite because they will never be able to establish regular crowds of 50,000 or so.

But they should be able to get 25,000 every week in the Premiership and comfortably compete with the likes of Leicester and West Ham. A big issue is whether they can redevelop their stadium to increase its capacity or have to move away from Craven Cottage, which would be a great shame when you consider its history and traditions.

Fulham have always been a special club in many ways, but I would say they are now unique in the way they are organised. For a start, the HQ and power base is in Knightsbridge, SW3 rather than Craven Cottage. The club is run like a department of Harrods rather than a separate business and in this scheme of things, being manager of Fulham is barely different from running the food hall or menswear department.

The staff and players have Harrods discount cards and are paid on Harrods payslips, and if you are considered to be doing a good job you are very well rewarded.

But there is another side - and it can be ruthless. A good number of heads have rolled in the past three or four years. It is not just managers and players who have come and gone - the head of security and finance director were dismissed almost without warning. It is the sort of place where both on and off the field you have to perform ... or you will be out.

When I arrived, Ray Wilkins was manager but he paid the price for failing to win promotion in his first season. Kevin Keegan got Fulham into the First Division but then left for England, and Paul Bracewell did not last a season.

I do think, however, it was an excellent idea to make Tigana's appointment before the end of the season so he had those final seven games - when I was in charge along with Karlheinz Riedle and Roy Evans - to see what he needed to do.

He came along in the summer with his own ideas and staff, and has been fantastic - perhaps the best signing Fulham have made. Certainly I can never remember a stronger or more consistent side than this one, where they have, in each area, the best players by far in the division, in Maik Taylor, Chris Coleman, John Collins and Louis Saha. Tigana has an excellent knowledge of French football from his time as a coach and an agent there, and he has two other excellent young Frenchmen in Fabrice Fernandes and Nicholas Sahoun.

But he has also been as good as his word in blooding youngsters who have come through the academy and is very keen to build for the future with homegrown talent too.

Tigana already has seven or eight players who can thrive in the Premiership, and will have no problem recruiting another four or five when they go up. He has the resources to do that without having to sell - indeed this year's reserves are almost the same as last year's first team.

Tigana also has the cachet to attract very good players to the club, just as Keegan did. Whenever I spent time in Europe for Fulham, people who had never previously heard of the club knew about them because of the manager. Keegan understood the importance of marketing, and that is another reason why Fulham stand out - their marketing philosophy is the same as Harrods', and indeed a lot of club merchandise is on sale there. But I do wonder what would happen if Fayed left for any reason. Walker left a lot of money in trust funds so that Blackburn will remain wealthy for years to come. I don't know if that would be the case at Fulham.

I'm more concerned that my Crystal Palace team are playing them this week. They are a frightening prospect for any club, and I suspect could give a few Premiership teams a run for their money. Fulham haven't been in the top flight for almost 40 years, when chairman Tommy Trinder, the music hall comedian, made most of his jokes at the club's expense.

But there are not too many people laughing at them - or Fayed's vision - now.

webTitle: Dream debut for canny Caniggia

fields.headline: Dream debut for canny Caniggia
fields.trailText: Scottish review
fields.body:
Claudio Caniggia showed his class by marking his first match in Scottish football with a goal.

The signing of the former Argentine World Cup striker, who was brought on as a substitute just before half-time in place of Steven Milne with his team 1-0 ahead, had prompted some 3,000 Dundee fans to make the trip to Aberdeen.

After 10 minutes of the second half, Dundee handed Aberdeen a lifeline when Gavin Rae was sent off for retaliation. However, Aberdeen continued to find it hard to break down the Dundee defence, and in the last minute, shortly after they'd had Philip McGuire sent off for a foul on Caniggia, the Argentine broke clear to make it 2-0.

If anybody can have been said to have inspired Caniggia, then it was surely Dundee's player-manager, Ivano Bonetti.

It was Bonetti who had opened the scoring after 30 minutes, when the ball was played back to him on the edge of the box by Juan Sara and he found the net with a brilliant chip.

How Dundee United could do with finishing like that. Dundee's bottom-of-the-table neighbours, the only Premier League team without a win, slumped to a 4-0 home defeat by Hearts.

Robert Tomaschek opened the scoring after just eight minutes, and two quality goals midway through the half by Andy Kirk put Hearts in the comfort zone. United's agony was completed by defender Kevin James - not to mention the 4-0 Motherwell win over St Johnstone that has left them five points adrift at the bottom.

One St Johnstone player who will have found that defeat particularly hard to take was Darren Dodds, whose own goal presented Motherwell with the lead.

It was Motherwell's first home league win of the season, although their satisfaction was offset by the fact that their Dutch defender Benito Kemble appeared to lose his composure and was sent off for two bookable offences in the space of five minutes.

Dunfermline, another team rooted deep in the bottom half of the table, lost 2-1 at Kilmarnock through a goal by Garry Holt five minutes from the end.

webTitle: Zitelli leads revival

fields.headline: Zitelli leads revival
fields.trailText: Injury-hit Rangers lose to resurgent Hibernian.
fields.body:
The most surprising aspect of Hibs' victory was that they should be on offer at 3-1 against by bookmakers before the start. Of course, the odds compilers would have done their work before the details of Rangers' appaling injury problems emerged. The error of their ways was emphasised by David Zitelli, when he struck the goal which continued the Easter Road side's extraordinary resurgence.

Clearly aroused by the aromatic whiff of the blood of wounded opponents, Hibs had a predatory look about them from the very start of the match while Rangers' shocking casualty list, containing eight players who would have been regarded as first picks, made them uncommonly vulnerable.

From goalkeeper Stefan Klos through full-backs Fernando Ricksen and Arthur Numan to midfielder Giovanni van Bronckhorst and forwards Ronald de Boer, Rod Wallace, Neil McCann and Michael Mols, Dick Advocaat was sorely tried in the business of assembling a team to visit the home of opposition, who have made their best start to the league campaign in decades.

They seemed to sense their own weakness, too, as they appeared apprehensive and uncertain during those periods when the Hibs midfield and attack swarmed in the vicinity of 19-year-old Mark Brown, facing a hectic time in the visitors' goal.

The teenager was tested and found gratifyingly wanting by Zitelli even before the Frenchman gave Hibs the lead, leaping high to his right to touch a terrific shot from the striker over his crossbar. He was, however, given no hope of redemption the next time Zitelli came threatening.

Breaking from defence, Hibs moved the ball sweetly from Paul Fenwick to John O'Neil, the latter stroking the pass from midfield into the path of Zitelli on the right. The manoeuvre left him clear on the right side of the penalty area and his low drive sent the ball into the far corner.

Rangers, having avoided damage during the early onslaught, then promised some of their own as they played composed and menacing football, but Allan Johnston, the recipient of most of the good chances, finished poorly. Johnston's replacement with Kanchelskis at half-time was no surprise, but it would have been difficult to predict the controversies in which the Ukrainian would be the central figure during the second half.

After fewer than 15 minutes, he was clear inside the penalty area and, as he delayed his shot until he could see the whites of Colgan's eyes, Gary Smith appeared to take his legs from behind. The first impression was of an incontestable penalty kick, but referee Kenny Clark not only refused the claims, but booked Kanchelskis for diving.

That action would have its effect nine minutes from the end, when the Rangers winger committed a foul on Ulrik Laursen which drew a second yellow and, consequently, a red card. The drama seemed appropriate to an engrossing match, with Rangers exerting most of the second-half pressure in their search for equality.

But there was a general aimlessness about their endeavours, with their forwards Billy Dodds and Peter Lovenkrands especially ineffective and even the normally reliable Jorg Albertz in midfield unusually quiet.

The better players wore green-and-white shirts, most notably the ever-composed Franck Sauzee in defence, the inventive Russell Latapy and John O'Neil in midfield, and the inexhaustible Mixu Paatelainen in the front line. Given Rangers' shortage of first-choice personnel, there was no shame in losing to a Hibs team presently overflowing with self-belief.

webTitle: Wasteful Ipswich lack killer touch

fields.headline: Wasteful Ipswich lack killer touch
fields.trailText: With barely a quarter of the season gone, it is perhaps tempting fate to suggest that Ipswich will not only survive but prosper in the Premiership. There are plenty of pitfalls ahead for George Burley's effervescent team and he is the first to acknowledge them.
fields.body:
With barely a quarter of the season gone, it is perhaps tempting fate to suggest that Ipswich will not only survive but prosper in the Premiership. There are plenty of pitfalls ahead for George Burley's effervescent team and he is the first to acknowledge them.

A priority must be to make sure that teams like West Ham are not given the opportunity to strike back for a point after being all but buried by fluent, forceful football.

Yet eight points from their last four matches - and seventh place in the table - offer compelling evidence that Ipswich are on the right track. Certainly, their first- half performance yesterday was of the highest order. They have the confidence to express themselves fully, with one second-half cameo capturing that confidence, with Jamie Clapham 'nut-megging' Steve Lomas, then beating the West Ham captain for a second time when he recovered his ground.

'It was disappointing not to have won because we had three or four times as many chances as they did,' insisted Burley.'But I could not have asked any more from my lads. We played some tremendous stuff. If we keep playing like that, we shall have no fears.'

Harry Redknapp raised several eyebrows by suggesting that his team created almost as many openings and were good value for a point. Redknapp met with no argument with his assessment of Ipswich, declaring: 'They are a good side who passed the ball well, have loads of movement and a nice shape. I said at the start of the season that all three who came up would do well. I can see this being the toughest Premiership ever.'

Redknapp's main worry is a lack of central defenders after the loss in the last minute of Igor Stimac with a deep leg gash through to the muscle, which is likely to keep him out of action for some time.

Ipswich were ahead after five minutes, Marcus Stewart meeting a centre from Fabian Wilnis with a precise angled header inside the upright. Had Jim Magilton's shot from a Stewart pass gone in soon afterwards instead of striking the base of the upright and rebounding into the arms of Shaka Hislop, it could have been a landslide.

Instead, West Ham rode their luck and the second-half introduction of John Moncur for Nigel Winterburn helped give them greater impetus.

Even so, it was against the run of play when Paolo Di Canio connected with a chip to the far post from Trevor Sinclair with a sweet volley from the junction of the six- yard area which flew into the far corner.

Ipswich changed their front pair, bringing on James Scowcroft and David Johnson, and should have won it three minutes from the end of normal time. Hislop's save from Hermann Hreidarsson was commendable, but the defender had enough time and space in which to direct his shot from 12 yards well away from the goalkeeper.

Stimac's injury marred a splendidly entertaining afternoon for a crowd who have every right to be relishing the campaign ahead.
