webTitle: Phillips lights up

fields.headline: Phillips lights up
fields.trailText: The wait eventually proved worthwhile for Sunderland supporters. A game that started 45 minutes late because a workman's wayward drill severed the Stadium of Light's electricity supply was settled by Kevin Phillips' penalty.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
The wait eventually proved worthwhile for Sunderland supporters. A game that started 45 minutes late because a workman's wayward drill severed the Stadium of Light's electricity supply was settled by Kevin Phillips' penalty.

Then Phillips - not even on the bench for England against Finland - capped Sunderland's satisfying day by dismissing suggestions that his international prospects would be improved if he played elsewhere.

Phillips said: 'Some people might see it like that, but I don't. I've played for England while at Sunderland and, if you are playing well and scoring goals, you have a chance.

'I'm very happy at Sunderland and would be daft to say I'm not. I've had three great seasons here and this season is starting to go the way I want.

'We've beaten Chelsea and proved we can mix it with the big boys.'

In truth, Sunderland did substantially more than just beat Chelsea. They overwhelmed them with a committed, aggressive performance that added immeasurably to the Premiership education of the new Chelsea manager, Claudio Ranieri.

A career in Italy and games against Liverpool and Manchester United had surely not prepared him for the sort of relentless pressure exerted by Sunderland.

Their approach should have been rewarded long before the decisive moment in the 62nd minute when - elsewhere in the Premiership - players were soaking in the bath. Mario Melchiot's contribution was just as wet. The Chelsea defender tugged on Niall Quinn's shirt in front of goal to present Phillips with his penalty, but still didn't prevent Quinn getting in a header. The foul - ineffectual and misjudged - was only in keeping with yet another disappointing performance by the Londoners at this ground.

Last season they were 4-0 down at the interval and could have succumbed in similar fashion after Dennis Wise, proving yet again his ability to start a fight in an empty room, became unnecessarily involved after Quinn fouled Marcel Desailly in the opening exchanges.

Wise craned his neck to look up at Quinn and accuse him of going over the top, instantly igniting the passion of Sunderland's fans and players. It was a passion that never ebbed and eventually produced a 66th minute foul by Graeme Le Saux and retaliation from Kevin Kilbane that earned both a red card.

It also produced a series of chances for Sunderland.

Chelsea might have been behind after only seven minutes when Julio Arca skillfully created space for a shot that bounced down off the underside of the bar. Referee Jeff Winter and his assistant decided it hadn't crossed the line and, unlike Finland on Wednesday night, replays suggested they were right.

Three minutes later, Sunderland went close again with a move made in Ireland. Kilbane's cross was destined for Niall Quinn at the far post before a desperate interception by Ed de Goey.

The Dutch keeper was even more impressive seconds later when he instinctively turned away Quinn's close-range header following an athletic overhead kick from Phillips. Quinn's value to this Sunderland side was emphasised yet again when his first touch to Michael Gray's cross took him inside Desailly and his second lopped on to the top of the net with de Goey scrambling back. The openings were not as plentiful in the rest of the match, but Sunderland's superiority was unchallenged until after the dismissal of Kilbane and Le Saux.

Sunderland manager Peter Reid said: 'It unbalanced us. Kevin was having a tremendous game and his departure upset us more than them.'

Quinn and Alex Rae were also singled out by Reid, but he said: 'My players were absolutely superb - every one of them. We competed well all over the park and played some lovely stuff. I was proud of my players.'

His pride was matched by his pleasure at Phillips' words. 'We have a really good relationship,' he said. 'He doesn't have a problem here and, if he does, he hasn't told me.'

webTitle: Henry the key again

fields.headline: Henry the key again
fields.trailText: Now where were we? Arsenal were going impressively, after wins over Lazio and Manchester United. Aston Villa had taken 10 points from four games to leap up the Premiership table. We expected a feast from two in-form teams. But with some players jaded by two weeks of intense international activity, some rusty from the break, we saw instead a messy match of half-chances poorly finished.
fields.body:
Now where were we? Arsenal were going impressively, after wins over Lazio and Manchester United. Aston Villa had taken 10 points from four games to leap up the Premiership table. We expected a feast from two in-form teams. But with some players jaded by two weeks of intense international activity, some rusty from the break, we saw instead a messy match of half-chances poorly finished.

It was settled by the one that was taken, Thierry Henry again making it 1-0 to the Arsenal, as he had done against United, if not quite so spectacularly. There was then no way back for Villa, who had played the neater football for much of the match but again lacked cutting edge, especially when one man short after the belated dismissal of Lee Hendrie by a referee who had forgotten to send him off until his oversight was pointed out to him.

Rob Harris was the ref who allowed Tranmere Rovers to play with 11 men in an FA Cup tie last season after sending one wild Rover off. Yesterday he brandished a second yellow card at Hendrie but it took Arsenal's Gilles Grimandi to remind him as Hendrie lined up in a wall to face the free-kick. The first offence, for kicking the ball away, had preceded the second, pulling back Robert Pires, by just seven minutes. Mr Harris appears to have the memory of a goldfish. 'He's a prat, quite frankly,' said the Villa manager John Gregory, admirably of his player rather than the referee, though.

It was all a little harsh on Villa ultimately, though it pointed up the difference between the very top teams of the Premiership and the sides who aspire to be. In Paul Merson, back on the ground where he plied his trade for 12 years, Villa have a player capable of moments of ingenuity but little out of the ordinary as support in the attacking third of the pitch. David Ginola remains injured and short of match fitness.

By contrast, Arsenal have half a dozen - two of them even starting on the bench in Sylvain Wiltord and Kanu, along with the rested Martin Keown - so that they always look able to turn a match in which they are not at their most fluent.

They had an early chance, David James saving brilliantly with one hand at his near post a shot by Dennis Bergkamp, but thereafter Ian Taylor, Merson and Hendrie assumed control of midfield, where Patrick Vieira, after his five-match suspension, looked off the pace.

Duly, Villa carved out some reasonable opportunities. Gareth Southgate, back in towering form for his club in his right position, as one tackle on Henry in full flight showed, twice tested David Seaman, the goalkeeper saving his volley with his legs before tipping away a shot across goal after Southgate had met Merson's free-kick.

With Villa protecting possession well and passing the ball accurately, Arsenal were denied the chance to do damage by sending Henry clear, Bergkamp being closed down quickly when on the ball. Frustrated, they were forced to resort to long shots, James clutching to his midriff one 30-yarder by Silvinho.

Villa needed to score in this purple patch and one sensed they could be made to pay for not doing so. The feeling grew in the second half when Hendrie shot lamely across goal after Julian Joachim had slipped him through and Tay lor missed his kick on the six-yard line.

And so it happened. Pires pushed the ball forward to Henry in the inside-right channel and he swivelled to send a low shot through Alpay's legs and into James's far corner. After that, and Hendrie's delayed red card, it was clear there would be only one winner.

It could, too, have been by a bigger margin as Villa left gaps chasing the game. Henry drove just wide, Bergkamp saw his shot clipped over James cleared off the line by Southgate, and Wiltord mis-kicked from 10 yards.

'You look at their bench and think, "We can't match that",' lamented Gregory. The answer to the lack of finishing power, he said, is to 'go out and spend money. We can't do that'. It does ignore, however, the fact that he has spent considerably on a clutch of average players rather than invested it in one quality striker.

Arsenal, through Wenger's acumen, certainly have one, which is one of the reasons they are unbeaten since the first day of the season, with a 100 per cent home record to boot. Even jaded, 15 of their squad having been on international duty, they can eke out results when the spectacular eludes them.

webTitle: Graham hit by lack of Sol

fields.headline: Graham hit by lack of Sol
fields.trailText: A week after Kevin Keegan resigned from his job as England coach, Tottenham's supporters were urging their manager, George Graham, to do the same following this latest away defeat, their fourth in five league games.
fields.body:
A week after Kevin Keegan resigned from his job as England coach, Tottenham's supporters were urging their manager, George Graham, to do the same following this latest away defeat, their fourth in five league games.

Fans lived up to their pre-match promise of protests against Graham and the club's chairman Alan Sugar, and the early light-hearted chants of 'Graham for England' quickly turned to more angry calls by half-time, with Spurs 2-0 down to a Coventry team that had not previously won at home in the league.

Although Spurs improved and scored early in the second-half, they still could not overcome a side reduced to 10 men when Carlton Palmer was sent off in the 71st minute for a violent kick at Chris Perry in an off-the-ball incident.

Palmer may face disciplinary action from the FA after having to be pulled away from referee Peter Jones by fellow players, but both managers agreed he deserved his fate.

'I'm a big fan of his but he had to go - you can't defend that sort of thing,' said Gordon Strachan. 'I was watching golf all morning but I never saw as good a swing as that - I expected Perry to be pitched out of the ground.'

Graham, meanwhile, bemoaned the fact that the dismissal gave Coventry renewed spirit just as Tottenham threatened to equalise. 'The referee got it spot on, but I wish the sending-off hadn't happened because we were playing better against 11 men than we did against 10. They got players behind the ball and made it very difficult.'

Tottenham's defence was all at sea during the first half. Graham is notorious for creating tight defensive units, but he needs better raw material than he has here. Ramon Vega is no substitute for the injured Sol Campbell, while former Wimbledon pair Ben Thatcher and Chris Perry are out of form. To make it worse, the players in front of them - Tim Sherwood and Steffen Freund - are playing increasingly poorly, leaving Tottenham as soft-centred as a marshmallow.

'We're not solid at the back, which is not like my teams,' said Graham. 'We look good going forward but we keep giving soft goals away, and you can't give a Premiership side a two-goal start away from home and expect a result.'

The problems started in the 12th minute when Thatcher went AWOL at left-back, allowing John Aloisi time and space to control a crossfield pass, cut in from the right and unleash a terrific left-footed shot into the top corner of goal. Worse was to come 14 minutes later when Ramon Vega allowed Craig Bellamy to take the ball off him inside the penalty area and square it across goal for John Eustace to fire home a simple goal.

Spurs started the second half more strongly and pulled a goal back quickly when Richard Shaw's slip allowed Oyvind Leonhardsen to put Sergei Rebrov through. Tim Sherwood then headed against the bar in stoppage time, but Coventry hung on for a rare home win to leave Graham hoping Campbell makes a quick recovery.

webTitle: Blues recover to rob Dodd

fields.headline: Blues recover to rob Dodd
fields.trailText: A game that did nothing to support the Premiership propagandists who would have us believe this is the world's best domestic product did, however, add to Everton's growing problems.
fields.body:
A game that did nothing to support the Premiership propagandists who would have us believe this is the world's best domestic product did, however, add to Everton's growing problems.

One victory in eight league and cup games, including the embarrassing Worthington Cup exit to Bristol Rovers, allied with seven potential starters on the treatment table, have Everton casting a glance at the relegation places with a degree of mild concern.

'We could certainly do with a win,' said manager Walter Smith. 'It's not the easiest period for us, but we will have to try and overcome these little problems. Actually, they're big problems!'

They would have been one point bigger had it not been for an inexplicable foul from behind by Kevin Davies on Alex Nyarko that presented Michael Ball with an 80th-minute penalty equaliser.

That cancelled out the one moment of rare quality in an appalling game, five minutes earlier, when Southampton full-back Jason Dodd opened the scoring with a tremendous 25-yard volley after Steve Watson's headed clearance had fallen to him.

The goal capped a workmanlike, if uninspired, South-ampton performance with a lone striker, Marian Pahars, operating with Hassan Kachloul and Davies making supporting runs from deep. Had defender Tahar El Khalej succeeded with a header that struck the bar in the dying seconds of the first half, the remainder of the game may have been transformed.

Instead, the second period followed the same monotonous pattern. Mis-hit passes, poor use of the ball by Everton, the occasional South-ampton counter-attack that all too often led to nothing.

The most promising, in the 58th minute, required Paul Gerrard to sprint off his line and beat Pahars to a superbly judged Kachloul through-ball.

'It's that cutting edge that's missing,' said manager Glenn Hoddle. 'But sometimes that's a £10 million player you're talking about and we don't have those resources at the moment.

'We're improving as a team, coming away and dominating games like this. But with the way we're playing we should be picking up more points.'

webTitle: A grim tale of two Cities

fields.headline: A grim tale of two Cities
fields.trailText: After the elation of Premiership survival last season, it has been downhill all the way for Bradford since. The league's least prolific team resoundingly failed to score again, despite numerous chances, and could yet end the weekend at the bottom of the table. To judge on this performance, it is where they deserve to be.
fields.body:
After the elation of Premiership survival last season, it has been downhill all the way for Bradford since. The league's least prolific team resoundingly failed to score again, despite numerous chances, and could yet end the weekend at the bottom of the table. To judge on this performance, it is where they deserve to be.

Manchester City have yet to acclimatise fully to the top flight, and like their visitors came into the game in poor form. They may be a mediocre Premiership side but they were, figuratively speaking, in a different league to Bradford. And if the Bantams fail to reverse their fortunes it won't be long before they actually are in a different league.

Manchester City started nervously, but once they realised just how weak their opponents were, at least in attack, their confidence grew. The turning point came in the 30th minute when Mark Kennedy, who had been played out of position and without great effect on City's right wing, switched to the left. Within 90 seconds his cross, via David Wetherall's head, found Paul Dickov unmarked in the area to volley home.

It capped a wonderful week for the sometime striker, who won his first two full international caps for Scotland before taking the man-of-the-match award here.

'It's a lovely story,' said a glowing Joe Royle. 'He wasn't a regular in the Second Division, or in the First, but he's scored vital goals, goals that have got us into the Premiership. We've bought other strikers in the last couple of seasons but, in the nicest possible way, he just doesn't go away. That goal would have been in the stands a couple of years ago, when he tried to kill every ball that came near him, but even at 27 he's still improving.'

With Dickov at the heart of their best moves, the home side dominated the rest of the half, and extended their lead on the stroke of half-time. Stuart McCall was penalised for handling Paulo Wanchope's chipped through-ball just outside his area, and Bradford's assistant manager suffered further as Alf Inge Haaland's shot from the resulting free-kick hit him on its way into the net.

Having scored only once on their travels this season, Bradford always seemed unlikely to come back from a 2-0 half-time deficit. Even more so when, within seconds of the restart, Peter Beagrie's cross found Ashley Ward six yards from goal but, with the away fans already celebrating, his header bounced wide.

'If that goes in it gives you half a chance to get back in the game,' said the Bradford manager, Chris Hutchings. But it wasn't the worst of Bradford's misses. 'We probably had about five headers but the keeper never had to make a save.'

The worst miss came courtesy of Dean Windass, who raced into the area to meet Benito Carbone's cross only to miscue his header wide. 'If there's anyone in the club you want coming in on a cross, it's Windass,' said Hutchings, 'but he scuffed it.'

The home side also missed chances, but they could afford to. 'We've had chances in all the games we've played,' said Hutchings, 'We've just got to keep plugging away, and hopefully we can turn the tide.' For now, though, Bradford look all at sea.

webTitle: Who kicked the cat?

fields.headline: Who kicked the cat?
fields.trailText: How was it for you? Was your first experience of an England football international televised on pay-per-view as pleasurable as you hoped?
fields.body:
How was it for you? Was your first experience of an England football international televised on pay-per-view as pleasurable as you hoped?

There has been plenty of anecdotal feedback - ranging from my own, which was a hitch-free experience in a pub in Battersea, to stories of cats being unceremoniously booted across living rooms (or, in Harry Redknapp's case, across his office at West Ham).

u>direct, the independent pay-per-view broadcaster who parted with £3 million for the rights to Finland v England, have always been coy about disclosing the number of viewers. They would say only that everyone who registered at least 20 minutes before kick-off - and provided their correct details - saw the match without any problems, but some of those who left it until the last minute experienced delays.

'We hope customers in the future will understand that early registration is essential,' said Roger Hall, u>direct's marketing manager.

So, do they have a future? Quite possibly. Global Sportnet, the Hamburg-based company who were responsible for delivering the Finland-England match to u>direct, have replaced CSI Octagon as agents for the Greece-England game next June, which is the only World Cup qualifier still to be allocated to a TV broadcaster and is now likely to be a key fixture on the qualifying road to the 2002 World Cup finals.

Thomas Martens, the head of Global Sportnet, was still evaluating the reaction to the Helsinki match when I spoke to him, but said: 'It is not impossible that the match [Greece v England] will be broadcast on pay-per-view again. At the moment, it is open.

'The Finland match was an experience, a trial, not so much for us as for England and u>direct. We'll have to see, but I believe that it could have an impact on future matches being broadcast on pay-per-view, not only those involving the national team but also club games in Europe.'

If Global Sportnet decide to seek a pay-per-view partner, u>direct will find they have few rivals to do the broadcast. Sky are letting it be known that they are not interested in screening England on a p-p-v basis.

In the long run, of course, the success of pay-per-view broadcasting will depend on how many of us encourage those responsible by subscribing to it.

While Finland's footballers were frustrating England last Wednesday, the Finnish FA were driving executives of the online betting site, Eurobet, to distraction.

Eurobet, the internet arm of Coral's, had booked perimeter advertising space inside the Olympic Stadium, but the Finns barred their boards from being displayed, saying there were legal problems with regard to the state lottery, Velkkaaus, who just happen to be one of the main sponsors of Finnish football.

The fact that the match was a double production, and the pictures beamed to the UK were not seen by viewers in the host nation, made no difference to the Finnish authorities' stubborn stance.

Greg Dyke played some fairly aggressive frames, it seems, during the negotiations that have ended up with the BBC keeping the world snooker championship until 2006.

Reports reach me that the director general faced down the World Snooker Association's attempts - led by the now departed chief executive Peter Middleton - to more than double the money they receive from the Beeb for the world event plus three other tournaments.

In the end they had to settle for around £23 million, which was only a modest increase on the £18.8m they received for the previous five-year deal.

Also, Dyke has insisted on retendering the production contract after next year's world championship. At present it is held by TWI, who have also been responsible for the TV negotiations.

webTitle: Said & Done

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Observer Sport today launches an exclusive new live football stats service - stage one in the most sophisticated system of its kind in European football. With real-time live stats, IQ Sports will be providing the Observer and footballunlimited.co.uk with an unprecendented level of analysis of patterns of play, turning points and key battles.
fields.body:
Observer Sport today launches an exclusive new live football stats service - stage one in the most sophisticated system of its kind in European football. With real-time live stats, IQ Sports will be providing the Observer and footballunlimited.co.uk with an unprecendented level of analysis of patterns of play, turning points and key battles.

Observer IQ features on page four today. Over the course of the season, IQ will be expanding to take in the Champions League, and supplying similar stats to managers and national associations.

Follow the progress of Observer IQ exclusively in Observer Sport and football unlimited.co.uk.

Helsinki: it was great, really

Finland 0-0 England ('We're so stinky in Helsinki', The Mirror ) was always going to be stale - but there were plenty of off-field diversions for the travelling 3,000. Sky's morning news headlines two days before the match led the portents: 'Trouble in Middle East' (image of violence in Palestine); 'Scientists say they can revive dinosaurs' (image of dinosaur); 'Wilkinson to lead England in Helsinki' (image of dinosaur). A day before kick-off Fins began unfurling banners like the one above as fans made their own entertainment. Adam Crozier revealed his vision of a brighter future for England by leading the attack as England's press team beat the Fins 3-1 thanks to goals from a three-man, all Scottish strikeforce. So when the 0-0 happened, no-one minded too much. The trip's most diverting off-field incident came at the end, though, in Wilkinson's putting-things-in-perspective post-game post-mortem. 'I tried to give them a shape and a plan,' he explained. 'But God got seven days, I got three.'

World news

BRAZIL: Brazilian league referees have been equipped with new high-tech aerosol sprays to mark the distance between ball and wall at free-kicks. New this season in all official matches, the dye evaporates from the grass within 60 seconds, but makes spotting encroachments easier. If the device works, the Brazilian FA hope Fifa will approve the scheme worldwide.

NIGERIA: Kwara United fans have mounted a fierce prayer-led attack on the referees they say brought about their relegation last season. 'Lord humiliate them,' chanted 250 last week. 'Lord punish those who punish us and Lord shame those who put us to shame.' The prayers followed days of riots during the Pepsi Professional League season, seven days of fasting and attacks on adminsitrators homes. A fans spokesman explained they would only stop when they saw 'divine wrath' inflicted on all officials.

PERU: Official reports that Newcastle's Nolberto Solano was stripped of the Peruvian captaincy after a poor performance in the recent defeat by Bolivia don't square with reports from Lima. According to the Peruvian press, Solano was in fact demoted for playing a prominent part in smuggling 'many drunken women' into the squad's training camp for pre-match 'entertainment'. 'The press are following me everywhere,' Solano said. 'I'm persecuted.'

Competition winners

Last week's winners: 54,075 surfers visited euro200.org instead of Sportal's euro2000.org website during the summer - Julie McCarthy of Hackney, London, wins two tickets for AC Milan v Juventus, including flights and hotels. The £3,000 tickets for the AXA final ball Wembley showpiece on 2 November were won by Carl Leppard of Eastbourne - the White Horse Cup final horse was called Billie, not Alf. Tickets for the event are available on 020 8947 1881.

Tales from the Tabs

PHILLIPS WANTS OUT: England reject Kevin Phillips has sparked a massive £15m transfer scramble by revealing he wants to swap Sunderland for a bigger club in an effort to win caps. 'Deep down, you have to start thinking it's your club, not your form that's the problem,' says the striker. 'I love Sunderland, but I feel like an England outcast.'

VIALLI: I'M STAYING Gianluca Vialli is ready to return to Premiership management after missing out on a move to Inter Milan last week - but only if the job's in London. 'I love the city,' says Vialli. 'There's no reason for me to move away just because I'm not at Chelsea anymore. Managing a top club is very stressful, I do miss it.'

GIGGS PAY HITS £12m Ryan Giggs' new four-year Manchester United contract is set to earn him £12m - £52,000 a week plus a £1m testimonial - after agents upped the pressure on Old Trafford bosses. 'I think it'll all be agreed fairly soon,' says Giggs, 'hopefully by Christmas.' A £21m, £80,000-a-week deal is also close for David Beckham.

Danish club B93 are ready to sell defender Per Kroldrup to Arsenal : 'We could do business tomorrow,' says director Finn Kokholm.

 Aston Villa have firmed-up their interest in Celtic's Johan Mjallby. On-loan Gilles de Bilde, meanwhile, says he's 'ready to enjoy life' away from Sheffield Wednesday.

 Bradford could move again for Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee after the winger rejected a move to Bolton.

 Grimsby are ready to bid for Charlton's Clive Mendonca.

 Chelsea have again knocked back Paris St Germain's interest in Marcel Desailly.

 Coventry have put Carlton Palmer up for sale - Gordon Strachan failed to shift him in part-exchange for Blackburn's Lee Carsley last week.

 Derby hope to sign a central defender after today's game with Liverpool: Steve Staunton, Christian Dailly and Celtic's Alan Stubbs are top targets.

 Everton's Paul Gascoigne says he won't play for England again: 'I've done well for Everton and still wasn't picked, but I'm not bothered.'

 Ipswich defender Wayne Brown could join Wimbledon for £700,000.

 Leeds could rival Sunderland for Sporting Lisbon's Ghana forward Kwame Ayew.

 Leicester are still looking for takers for Stan Collymore.

 Liverpool's deal for Croatian star Igor Biscan will be finalised tomorrow - the midfielder will arrive in December.

 Man City are back in for Newcastle's Laurent Charvet and Torino's Fabio Galante.

 Man United's Phil Neville says he'll play the same however much stick he gets: 'I'll just rise above it'.

 Middlesbrough are planning a three-way transfer splash: Aussie Simon Colosimo, Milan's Zvonimir Boban and Villa's Ugo Ehiogu are targets.

 Newcastle are back in for Portuguese defender Helder. Bobby Robson also wants Honduran international Milton Jocon Reyes.

 Rangers have bid £1.5m for Southampton target Robert Douglas - the Dundee keeper is also a target for Celtic.

 Sunderland's Thomas Butler has joined Darlington on loan.

 Tottenham's interest in Simon Downer has cooled after the Leyton Orient defender signed a new contract.

 West Ham are ready to sign Danish keeper Lars Winde if a one month trial goes well.

webTitle: Rangers braced for a scare

fields.headline: Rangers braced for a scare
fields.standfirst: Glenn Gibbons on a chilling message from Galatasaray
fields.trailText: Glenn Gibbons on a chilling message from Galatasaray.
fields.body:
High expectations of victory for Rangers over Galatasaray in Tuesday's Champions League match at Ibrox may be founded on suspect evidence. The widespread assumption that Dick Advocaat's team will fully exploit home advantage seems to derive from the risky practice of taking at face value their performance in the later stages of the 3-2 defeat by the Turkish champions in Istanbul 18 days ago.

There is no denying how close Rangers came that night to extracting an impossible draw from a game in which they had trailed 3-0 with only 20 minutes remaining. Not only did the goals from Andrei Kanchelskis and Giovanni van Bronckhorst expose Galatasaray's previously unsuspected nervousness, but they had other scoring opportunities during those frantic closing minutes.

But closer scrutiny of the circumstances in which the Scottish champions rattled the home side tends to reveal that the form is not entirely trustworthy.

Galatasaray started that game without four first picks, the Brazilian defender Capone and the three most influential midfielders in the side, Gheorghe Hagi, Buruk Okan and Kaya Suat were missing because of a combination of illness, injury and suspension.

In addition, the outstanding player on the field, Emre Belozoglu, had to leave because of ankle damage just two minutes after Rangers had scored their first goal. Emre had virtually controlled the game single-handed, an impression confirmed by Advocaat on Friday, when he agreed that his departure had caused virtual disintegration among the Turks.

'He was the best player, all right,' said the Rangers manager. 'We had our own Turk, Tugay, marking him, but Tugay never got near him. It was no coincidence that we came more into the game after Emre left.'

At that point, Galatasaray were effectively without five of their best players. Four of them are expected to be in Glasgow this week - Emre is said to be still unavailable because of his injury - and it was no surprise to hear their coach, Mircea Lucescu, offer a rather chilling observation at the Ali Sami Yen Stadium a few minutes after he had concluded the official press conference.

Standing in a corner of the media room, Lucescu, who had been extremely personable when talking to the assembled corps - answering questions from the locals in French through an inter preter and switching to polite English for the benefit of the visiting journalists - became very serious when it was suggested that he would have a much stronger team for the visit to Scotland. 'Oh, yes,' said the Romanian, 'Rangers should be very scared of us in Glasgow.'

It would be an exaggeration to claim that Advocaat and his players will be cowering at the mention of Lucescu's warning, but the little Dutchman is realistic enough to know that a reversal of fortunes will be no formality. Especially as Rangers themselves will be without seven players who could have been called probable starters.

Lorenzo Amoruso, the central defender and captain, is suspended and the others - fellow central defender Craig Moore, full-backs Arthur Numan and Fernando Ricksen and forwards Michael Mols, Rod Wallace and Neil McCann - are incapacitated by injury. The goalkeeper, Stefan Klos, is no certain runner, troubled by ankle damage that has required painkilling injections to allow him to play for the past five weeks. His deputy, Lionel Charbonnier, is also unavailable, and Rangers could yet be forced to field the inexperienced 19-year-old, Mark Brown.

Advocaat, mustering all of his force ful self-belief, almost bridled at the suggestion that he was in charge of a weakened team, perhaps an attempt to stoke the confidence of the likely stand-ins, strip them of any possible apprehension.

'If you're a member of Rangers' squad,' he said, 'you have to be a good player, able to do the job. They've done it in the past, so I'm not concerned about the players who are likely to come in. We have enough cover for Tuesday's match.'

Even so, Advocaat is aware of the likely difficulties in breaking down a Galatasaray team who, in essence, operate with five men in midfield, leaving only the extraordinary Mario Jardel in attack. The Rangers coach emphasises they play with an extra man in the middle to accommodate the luxury known as Gheorghe Hagi.

'He is 35 and still one of the best players in the world with the ball,' said Advocaat of the celebrated Romanian. 'Without it, he is not too interested in defending. That's why they have that extra man. Yes, it will be difficult to break them down, but we will get chances in the match, that is for sure. Much will depend on how we deal with those opportunities and on how many chances we allow them.'

It is in the matter of rationing openings to the Turks that Jardel becomes a significant factor. When, some years ago, the Brazilian was on the point of signing for Rangers, the then Ibrox captain, Richard Gough, testified that Jardel in training was so bad that he was quite frightening. The Rangers squad in general were relieved when the transfer fell through because no work permit was available and it was not possible to secure for him a Portuguese passport.

Jardel still looks for most of the time as though he has never played before, but his 26 goals in Champions League matches and his four successive years as top scorer in Portugal with Porto confirm that he is a scoring machine. Rangers need no reminding, having been the victims of his ability to find the net while apparently doing little else during the match in Istanbul.

Rangers will draw encouragement from Galatasaray's poor form in their only away match in Group D, losing 3-0 to Strum Graz. But they should have the good sense not to stray towards complacency.

webTitle: Patched-up tartan is top material

fields.headline: Patched-up tartan is top material
fields.standfirst: Glenn Gibbons sees the Scots' spirit defy logic again
fields.trailText: Glenn Gibbons sees the Scots' spirit defy logic again.
fields.body:
A spectator wearing a Balaclava back to front could spot the characteristics that distinguish Scotland's national football team from more powerful, technically superior opponents who have failed in recent times to achieve victories over them that - the form book would suggest - should have been mere formalities.

Craig Brown's squad is suffused with a resilience, a willingness to work for each other and a refusal to be subdued which frequently discourages those who would seek to run them over.

In their latest demonstration of stubborn resistance against the odds, the 1-1 draw with Croatia at the Maksimir Stadium in Zagreb last Wednesday night, the Scots racked up their eighth away match without defeat. The five victories and three draws have embraced apparently quixotic jousts with England, Germany, the Republic of Ireland - all won - and Holland, as well as Croatia.

In the match against the Irish in Dublin last May, when Brown was able, by and large, to select the team of his choosing, Scotland gave an exhibition that bordered on virtuosity, comprehensively outplaying Mick McCarthy's side - admittedly without the ferocious, prompting influence of Roy Keane - on their way to a 2-1 win.

Nor was the 1-0 success against England in the Euro 2000 play-off at Wembley last November merely the product of a team relying solely on blood and guts. The difference in character was, however, almost palpable, several English friends in the media and others not professionally involved declaring their admiration for the Scots' spirit and their lamentation over their own team's lack of it.

Nor does it seem to matter the players Brown has at his disposal. Between the announcement of his 26-man squad for the double-header against San Marino and Croatia and their arrival at the Maksimir last midweek, the manager lost seven players through injury or, in the case of the Rangers striker Billy Dodds, having to return home when his expectant wife went into labour. At least five of them - the Celtic midfielder Paul Lambert, his sidekick Barry Ferguson of Rangers, Blackburn defender Christian Dailly, Rangers winger Neil McCann and Dodds - would have been virtually certain first picks.

There was also the possibility that Dominic Matteo, the Dumfries-born Leeds United left-back, would have started had injury not denied him the opportunity to show his capabilities against San Marino, a match that Brown had already said would feature the player's international debut. In the event, the supposed skeleton staff, which had to be ranged against a Croatian side who had finished third in France 98, proved to be gratifyingly meaty.

Having begun the match seemingly on edge, the Scots appeared to be heading for an embarrassment when Alen Boksic underlined the home team's blatant superiority with an exceptional goal after only 16 minutes. But the response of Brown's players was so emphatically defiant that they not only equalised through Kevin Gallacher, but discouraged the Croatians so deeply that Miroslav Blazevic's side lurched towards a near-fatal uncertainty.

Don Hutchison and Colin Hendry missed the two most convertible chances of the game during the second half - the marvellous drive with which Robert Prosinecki hit Neil Sullivan's right-hand post was the result of brilliant individualism, as opposed to a contrived, close-range scoring opportunity - to deprive the Scots of a victory at which not even Blazevic could have carped.

None of this should surprise anyone who regularly accompanies Scotland on these seemingly hazardous assignments - they had already shown their unmatched esprit de corps in London and against Germany in Bremen - but it does almost invariably leave us astonished.

When I asked Brown on the eve of the match whether his usual optimism had been affected by the disruption, he looked a little puzzled. 'No, I never go into a game thinking we could lose,' he said. 'Sure, it's a bit of a nightmare losing so many players, but mainly because it leaves us short of rehearsal time with the new men.

'For instance, our regular guys know how to form a defensive wall. We even choreograph the jump by the wall and they all have it so well timed that we have never lost a goal by the ball going through, over or around that wall. But there will be no loss of spirit or camaraderie. The guys who come in will, as usual, work for each other as they always do.'

On the way home, Brown expanded on the theme of togetherness. 'No new player comes into the group like a stranger. Colin Cameron of Hearts, for example, has been around the squad and he slots in very comfortably. His performance in Zagreb was exceptional. Paul Dickov has now made just a couple of substitute appearances, but he has been welcomed and feels part of the whole thing. That's what makes it work.'

Now in a clear lead at the top of Group 6, Scotland may prove as difficult to remove as Excalibur from the stone.

webTitle: Lebanon's Asian odyssey

fields.headline: Lebanon's Asian odyssey
fields.standfirst: Battered Beirut has been rejuvenated by football, finds Matthew Beard
fields.trailText: Battered Beirut has been rejuvenated by football, finds Matthew Beard.
fields.body:
For a nation on its knees barely 10 years ago, Lebanon has undergone a remarkable recovery from the ravages of a 15-year civil war. And in the sporting arena, too, this once benighted country is now making impressive progress.

As tension in the Middle East threatened to spiral out of control in Israel last week - and with a major flashpoint a mere 100 miles away on his southern border - the Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, welcomed Fifa's high command, including president Sepp Blatter, to the start in Beirut of Asia's premier football tournament, the 12-nation twelfth Asian Cup.

The opening ceremony at Sports City - rebuilt after its 1982 destruction by Israeli bombers - may not have boasted the technical wizardry of the Sydney Olympics, but as a celebration of a nation's ability to overcome adversity it was unrivalled.

Security for the event verged on the paranoid. Four hours before Lahoud's arrival, hundreds of soldiers set up a cordon a kilometre from the stadium. Spectators and journalists were subjected to searches of clothes, bags and even pen tops. In the VIP area, Fifa officials and Lahoud sat nervously behind bulletproof screens surrounded by soldiers as army helicopters circled overhead.

But the Lebanese crowd had cause to wave their national flags with extra vigour to toast a hat-trick of sports successes that is the envy of its oil-rich neighbours. In addition to staging the Cup, Lebanon is also poised to become the first Middle Eastern country to host the world rally championship and shortly the Lebanese rugby league side travel to Britain for the World Cup.

But it is the Asian Cup that represents the biggest coup and offers this beautiful country the chance to establish itself again on the tourist map through sport, even though it has no professional teams.

The government hopes the three top-class stadiums in Beirut and newly built, 25,000-seater venues in the Mediterranean towns of Saida and Tripoli, all with running tracks, will attract more events.

'The Asian Cup is the biggest event this country will ever host,' the sports minister, Mohammed Yousef Baydoun, said. 'For each activity, the infrastructure is a must. If you don't have an opera house you can't have a symphony orchestra.

'It is very important for Lebanon to have hosted this event, but the real meaning lies in the billions of people in Asia and other continents who will be following the games on television.

'They will see another Lebanon from what they were used to between 1975-90. The word "Lebanisation" entered the dictionary with the meaning of a trou bled country in civil war. But, with this event, the word may now stand for stability, security and a chance of prosperity.'

Lebanon could not have done it without the support of their Arabic neighbours, who backed the 1996 bid to stage the tournament - defeating the highly rated bid from China.

Fifa executive committee member Mohamed bin Hamman of Qatar headed a campaign supported by Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and the United Arab Emirates, who all argued that Lebanon would be the politically correct choice considering all they had overcome.

The Asian Football Confederation overcame financial constraints applied when a new government halved investment in the tournament to around £18.5 million. Then on the eve of the tournament, as the Middle East crisis deepened, the AFC had to plead with teams not to pull out as Israeli fighter jets screeched over Beirut's concrete skyline.

In an inauspicious start to the tournament, the Lebanese Broadcasting Corporation's coverage of the opening game between Iraq and Thailand - watched live by just a few hundred Palestinians supporting Iraq in the 25,000-seater Saida stadium - was interrupted to broadcast news of the lynching of two Israelis in Ramallah. Then a power cut at Sports City plunged the crowd into darkness as the hosts prepared to play Iran.

As Western media threatened to evacuate journalists, the government was eager to dampen fears, claiming the tournament was not a target. Baydoun said: 'This is not a Lebanese event - it is an Asian event. I can't see Israel doing anything as teams such as China, Japan and Korea are simply not targets.'

Whether Lebanon's coup in staging the event can be matched by surprises on the pitch is a matter of intense local speculation, but realists tip Japan and reigning champions Saudi Arabi - both in Group C - to contest the 29 October final.

If England are forced to attempt World Cup qualification through the play-offs then they are almost certain to face one of the 12 nations taking part in the Asian Cup whose standard has improved in recent years through lessons learned in Europe by players such as a trio of Iranians in the Bundesliga, AS Roma's Hidetoshi Nakata (Japan), Charlton's Karim Bagheri (Iran) and Sami Al Jaber (Saudi Arabia).

Lebanon will almost certainly not be among the contenders. They have never before qualified for the Asian Cup and lost their opening game 4-0 to Iran, but still have a chance of going to the quarter-finals if they finish ahead of Thailand.

Recently, the host nation have gone from rank outsiders to dark horses under the charge of Croatian Joseb Scoblar, a former Olympique Marseille goalscoring hero. His quest has been boosted by a £625,000 handout from the Lebanese FA and his search for a star has yielded expatriate Mohamed (Michael) Reda from Australia and Brazil's Malteron Barana.

Relaxing the eligibility rules is not unique among the 12 nations. It is, though, an approach that Lebanon has adopted with great success in establishing a rugby league side who play under the national flag but is unknown even to the sports minister in its native country.

The side for the Lincoln World Cup, starting in the Britain later this month, will be in a group with Wales, New Zealand and the Cook Islands. They are all Australian expatriates and have yet to play on home soil.

webTitle: Last-minute sub comes on, scores ... and is sent off

fields.headline: Last-minute sub comes on, scores ... and is sent off
fields.trailText: League review.
fields.body:
Watford, one of only two Nationwide League teams with unbeaten records, gave the other side with that distinction - Fulham - something to think about by taking over from them at the top of the First Division.

With Jean Tigana's high-profile troops striving to maintain their 100 per cent record today at home to Blackburn, Watford took their own total of wins to nine in 10 matches at the expense of QPR. Perhaps the only surprise was that the player who did most of the damage to the QPR defence was a defender, Neil Cox. The full-back, not known for his scoring prowess, scored their first two goals. Although Karl Ready replied to give the visitors a glimmer of hope, Gifton Noel-Williams made it 3-1.

As Watford manager Graham Taylor pointed out: 'Our lead might only last for 24 hours, but you cannot dismiss the sort of start we have had.'

QPR's manager, Gerry Francis, did not disagree. At the same time, though, he suggested that Watford had been fortunate that QPR's striker Chris Kiwomya had not been fit to play. He explained: 'The Watford defence can be upset, as we saw today, and I think his pace would have caused them problems.'

The other leading teams to collect maximum points were Bolton, Birmingham and Pre ston. Birmingham recovered from a penalty miss by their captain, Martin O'Connor, and Crystal Palace taking the lead through Andy Morrison, to win 2-1. Their goals came from substitutes Mark Burchill and Dele Adebola.

Preston owed their 1-0 win over Tranmere to a Steve Basham goal. But the afternoon ended in misery for Basham, who suffered a broken leg in a 50-50 challenge with Jason Koumas.

At the other end, Sheffield Wednesday slumped to their seventh successive league defeat in going down 2-1 at Portsmouth. It was quite a day for Steve Claridge, who marked his first match as Portsmouth's player-manager by playing a big part in their first goal from Thomas Thorgersen, and grabbing the other.

Wednesday's manager, Paul Jewell, said: 'We are lacking in confidence at the moment and it showed today. The one thing I was pleased about was that the players did not succumb to a heavier defeat after going 2-0 down.'

The most exciting match was unquestionably the eight-goal thriller at Wimbledon, where the home team twice came from behind to lead 4-3 but eventually had to settle for a draw through a Carl Asaba goal.

Another contest to satisfy goal gluttons was Nottingham Forest's 4-3 win at Barnsley. The fact that two of Forest's goals came from their captain, Chris Bart-Williams, must have been bad news for Forest's first-team coach, Steve Wigley. According to Bart-Williams, Wigley has promised him a new shirt from Harrods every time he scores and Forest go on to win.

As a former striker, Millwall's new manager, Mark McGhee, says that he is particularly excited about working with the club's 23-year-old centre-forward, Neil Harris.

'What I like about him is his movement, his ability with the ball at his feet and his back to the goal,' he explains. webTitle: Better NHS is 10 years off - top surgeon

fields.headline: Better NHS is 10 years off - top surgeon
fields.standfirst:
Bleak decade predicted for patients

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: One of the Government's most eminent advisers on the health service has admitted that patients will not have an NHS they can be proud of for another decade.
fields.body:
One of the Government's most eminent advisers on the health service has admitted that patients will not have an NHS they can be proud of for another decade.

Barry Jackson, president of the Royal College of Surgeons and a member of the Government's Modernisation Board, said change was so slow it would be 2010 before the public could be happy with the service they were getting.

In an interview with The Observer, Jackson said fears about lower training standards, the arrival of foreign doctors to practice cardiac surgery and a lack of nurses was putting patient care at risk.

He said he expected another winter crisis this year if there are high numbers of flu sufferers and said morale in the service had fallen under the Government, rather than risen.

The bleak assessment of the future of the NHS comes at a particularly embarrassing time for Tony Blair who will speak to a meeting of the Royal College on Tuesday.

The Prime Minister has put the improvement of the NHS at the heart of the New Labour project. If it fails to improve, Downing Street strategists admit that it will have a bad effect on the mood of voters.

In his keynote speech, Blair will argue that progress has been made but that much more needs to be done for patients. He will say that surgeons and consultants must be willing to change.

'There is an enormous degree of disappointment that the National Health Service has just slowly become less and less good,' Jackson told The Observer.

'When people of my generation joined we thought that the NHS was wonderful. I'm afraid that feeling just doesn't exist anywhere in the profession any more.

'Turning it around is going to be slow. I see it as being 10 years plus before we see that it is really turned round.'

Jackson is the sergeant surgeon to the Queen and is also on the influential Standing Medical Advisory Committee. He represents 4,000 of the most senior medical practitioners in the country.

He said that although there was much to praise in the Government's National Plan for the NHS, he had 'major misgivings' about parts of it.

'We don't have enough consultants in the national health service. That is a fact. We are really quite woefully short of doctors. It is the patient who might be in pain who has to wait which really cannot be justified.'

Although Jackson has signed up to the 10 main principles of the plan, he said the Royal College had yet to endorse it because of its concerns.

'There is an enormous shortage of nurses in the National Health Service,' he said. 'Some of the suggestions in the plan appear to deplete an already depleted cadre of essential staff. The shortage of nurses is a very major issue which has got to be addressed.'

He said that changes in training procedures for consultants could have a knock-on effect for patients.

'We have to ensure that the consultants of the future are of a standard that you would expect if they are going to operate on you,' he said. 'If the standards of training of the consultants of the future are not up to the standard that we currently come to expect it will inevitably have the potential for impaired standards of patient care.'

Turning to the Government's record on health, Jackson said that agreeing to stick to the Conservative spending plans had meant that problems in the NHS had not been tackled quickly enough.

webTitle: England's waiting game

fields.headline: England's waiting game
fields.trailText: England could have a caretaker manager for the next eight months, after the FA's announcement that they are prepared to wait until next summer for the right man to replace Kevin Keegan to become available. It could leave the way open for Bobby Robson to take over part-time while Arsene Wenger sees out the season with Arsenal.
fields.body:
England could have a caretaker manager for the next eight months, after the FA's announcement that they are prepared to wait until next summer for the right man to replace Kevin Keegan to become available. It could leave the way open for Bobby Robson to take over part-time while Arsene Wenger sees out the season with Arsenal.

'It's more important to get it right for the next few years than to jump in and take someone who is available,' said Adam Crozier, the FA's chief executive. 'That's not knocking anyone who is available but it is to say the right person is important, rather than getting them this second.'

Crozier will meet the caretaker, Howard Wilkinson, tomorrow to discuss arrangements for the friendly against Italy in Turin on 15 November. A long-term appointment is unlikely before then.

The meeting will form part of an FA programme of up to two weeks consulting professionals in the English game before drawing up a list of candidates.

It could be that the right candidate is in a job but would consider the position full-time at the end of the season. That might interest Wenger, who could then work with a caretaker, be it Wilkinson, Robson or even Jack Charlton, who is believed to be interested in helping out, in the international weeks early next year. After the friendly against Spain in February and World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March, the new man could take over for the qualifier in Greece in June.

Wenger has said he is not interested in the job now, though he would consider it when his contract expires in 2002. The FA believe it is one thing turning down a job that has not yet been discussed, but quite another when a firm offer is made. 'I remember Kevin Keegan saying a number of times that he didn't want the job before he took it,' said Crozier.

The new coach will not be receiving quite the £3 million a year reported earlier this week. 'I nearly applied for it myself when I read that,' said Crozier. 'But we recognise that we will have to pay the going rate. We are well able to do that. If the England team is successful, money comes in from all sorts of different directions.' He estimates that the FA will have £125 million to plough back into the game next year. Keegan will be seeing none of it. Asked if the former coach would be receiving a financial settlement, Crozier replied curtly: 'None whatsoever.'

One man who backs Crozier's decision not to rush into making an appointment is Aimé Jacquet, who led France to World Cup glory in 1998. Jacquet, now overseeing a football structure that is the envy of the rest of the world, believes the FA should not underestimate the abilities of Wilkinson in restructuring the game here.

While Wilkinson is not a serious contender to replace Keegan, he can play a key role in reviving English football, says Jacquet.

'I know Howard Wilkinson - a good friend of Gerard Houllier - knows how it works in France. But he might put something together which is even better than us.'

Jacquet, talking exclusively to The Observer, suggests the FA would be better off pioneering a formula suited to the British character: 'You have to take what's good for you, but not an entire system.'

First, though, they must persuade everyone in the game to work together. 'You have to want to do it,' he says. 'Everyone in football's family has to agree in this.'

Jacquet also backs up what Wilkinson said last week - England might have to miss a major tournament, in this case the 2002 World Cup, in order to start afresh.

'You need patience,' says Jacquet. 'The only people who were ready to be patient [when the French overhauled their structure] were people from the football world, who appreciated what I was doing. The fans and the media didn't understand.'

webTitle: Brewing corruption scandal leaves Brazilian hot seat too hot

fields.headline: Brewing corruption scandal leaves Brazilian hot seat too hot
fields.standfirst: Unbelievable as it may seem, no one is interested in taking charge of the troubled four-time world champions
fields.trailText: England - without a coach and suffering from a run of poor results - can take some comfort from the knowledge that they are in illustrious company. Brazil are in the same, rudderless boat.
fields.body:
England - without a coach and suffering from a run of poor results - can take some comfort from the knowledge that they are in illustrious company. Brazil are in the same, rudderless boat.

Three weeks after coach Wanderley Luxemburgo's dismissal was prompted by the Olympic team's quarter-final defeat to Cameroon, the four-time World Cup winners are without a replacement. No one, it seems, wants the job.

If the pressure of being England coach is overwhelming, the weight of responsibility is perhaps even greater in Brazil - where football defines national identity more than any other nation. Only winning the World Cup is good enough.

But this time pressure is only half the story. Football in Brazil is going through its most serious crisis in years. At national and domestic levels, stadia are empty, fans are disillusioned, and competitions are badly run.

For the first time, parliament is getting involved. This week preparations were being finalised for two congressional investigations into corruption in the Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF).

Ricardo Teixeira, the CBF president, has two headaches. Not only must he choose Luxemburgo's successor but he must also prepare his empire's defence against a parliamentary drubbing. As Teixeira shuttles between Brasilia and Rio de Janeiro, Brazil are still without a coach and the show trial of the CBF - to be broadcast live on television - is pencilled in for November.

In the past fortnight, Teixeira has post poned naming Luxemburgo's successor so many times that the decision looks more distant than ever. This week he extended the temporary contract of Luxemburgo's deputy, Candinho, until after November's World Cup qualifier against Colombia.

The popular choice, Luis Felipe Scolari, quickly ruled himself out; other names touted include Carlos Alberto Parreira, who coached the World Cup side to victory in 1994, Dunga, captain of that team and the man who coached Jamaica to France 98, Rene Simões.

But none has expressed more than muted enthusiasm. Tostão, who won the 1970 World Cup alongside Pelé, wrote in his newspaper column that Teixeira asked him to be technical coordinator. 'I did not accept. I told him that the main reason was that the CBF, as supreme power, is the main organisation responsible for the current disorder in football.'

Zico also confirmed he was contacted - and confirmed he refused. The inquiries will probe possible irregularities with Nike's CBF contract, money laundering, tax dodging and corruption in selling players to European clubs.

webTitle: Reds decant double Sheri

fields.headline: Reds decant double Sheri
fields.trailText: Under-strength champions too much for Leicester in top-of-the-table clash.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor's rapidly rising managerial stock and Leicester City's first visit to the top of the league in 37 years were put into perspective by Teddy Sheringham's sixth and seventh goals of the season, which lifted a barely-recognisable Manchester United into a more familiar position at the top of the Premiership.

'No complaints - they are more experienced at big games than we are,' Taylor said. Prior to this game Leicester had conceded only two goals all season, though 34-year-old Sheringham could easily have had a hat-trick, shooting over in the second half and going close with a header from a corner before coming off after 70 minutes. The player so mystifyingly withdrawn in Helsinki also played his usual supporting role, most notably in setting up Dwight Yorke for a shot which brought the save of the game from Tim Flowers. 'He's having a great season,' Sir Alex Ferguson said. 'I only brought him off because he has a slight calf strain and I want him for PSV on Wednesday'

Considering Ole Gunnar Solskjaer added a third in stoppage time, City must have been glad they were playing only half the champions. Andy Cole, Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs were rested, but the player United missed most was the injured David Beckham. Suddenly the visitors needed two or three passes to transfer the ball across the pitch instead of just the one, and too many failed to find intended targets.

The home side were guilty of the same offence in a scrappy and forgettable first half-hour, and would ordinarily have been punished. But when Matt Elliott leant on Quinton Fortune to give away a free-kick on the edge of the penalty area, there was no Beckham to bend a shot over the wall and consequently little danger. Leicester did better with one of their own midway through the half, when Neil Lennon's free-kick found Gary Rowett at the far post. But he missed from close range with a side-foot volley.

That was as close as Leicester came before half-time, by which stage they were grateful to be just one goal down. Their defensive concentration wavered in the 36th minute when Sheringham rose in front of Rowett to glance in Denis Irwin's cross for the breakthrough, then three minutes later Solskjaer supplied a low centre which Fortune was only inches from turning in.

Leicester had a couple of chances to equalise right at the start of the second half, but Rowett hit the side netting and Darren Eadie's weakly-hit effort was smothered by Fabien Barthez. Leicester had to chase the game and they were hit by a classic United counter-attack. Leicester claimed a penalty when Wes Brown and Robbie Savage went for the same ball, but though the United player made contact with the man, he could not possibly have predicted Savage's arrival and Paul Durkin's corner verdict was probably correct. Predictably Leicester sent Elliott and Co forward, only to be caught when Fortune raced 60 yards almost unchallenged to supply Roy Keane. His first effort was blocked, but he found Irwin, and Sheringham pounced again when Tim Flowers failed to hold the Irishman's thunderous drive.

Giggs came on for the last 20 minutes, in time to see Flowers fingertip a Solskjaer header over the bar and Nicky Butt hit a post, though Leicester refused to give up and could have had something out of the game with better finishing in the final minutes. Savage shot wide when Barthez was caught out of his ground, but when Richard Cresswell rounded the goalkeeper from Lennon's defence-splitting pass in the 81st minute, there was less excuse for the substitute missing an empty net.

There was very little chance of Solskjaer missing when Yorke gave him an opportunity in the closing seconds. Leicester will need to get sharper if they are really going to challenge for honours, especially as they don't have Beckham, Cole and Scholes to come back.

'I was criticised for my last selection against PSV, and it would have been the same had we lost here,' Ferguson said. 'But there were 10 internationals in that team and I have to trust them. We have PSV on Wednesday then Leeds on Saturday. It's a hectic programme for us.'

webTitle: Gudni makes good

fields.headline: Gudni makes good
fields.trailText: By normal standards, Bolton have made a great start to the season. An average of two points per match is usually the accepted level for promotion - but this is no ordinary season.
fields.body:
By normal standards, Bolton have made a great start to the season. An average of two points per match is usually the accepted level for promotion - but this is no ordinary season.

In any other year, 24 points from the first 11 matches would probably be enough for a place in the top two, but such is the dominance of Watford and Fulham, that Bolton trail in third place by some distance, and have played a game more. The prospect of the play-offs for the third season in succession must not fill anyone at the Reebok Stadium with relish.

Manager Sam Allardyce said: 'We can't worry about anybody else. We have just got to think about what we do, and hope others slip up. Today, we might not have played brilliantly for 90 minutes, but it was the quality of the goals that won us the points and I'm very happy with the result.'

Dean Holdsworth scored the first goal, picking up the ball from Gareth Farrelly 25 yards out and unleashing a superb, dipping volley that Michael Oakes could do nothing about. The second came when captain Gudni Bergsson played a neat one-two with Ian Marshall, and advanced incisively into the box to chip past Oakes.

Wolves did more than enough to earn at least a point. They scored from the spot through Tony Dinning when Michael Branch was pulled down by Mark Fish, but created half a dozen other clear-cut chances, including a tremendous goal-bound header by Ludovic Pollet that the players claimed was handled by Dean Holdsworth on the line.

Wolves have sold Robbie Keane and Ade Akinbiyi for a combined fee of £11 million over the past 13 months and manager Colin Lee said: 'How I wish those two could have played for me. webTitle: Celtic maintain title drive

fields.headline: Celtic maintain title drive
fields.trailText: They may not be winning emphatically at present but results are going for Celtic in a way that has been all too rare in recent years. Chris Sutton and Henrik Larsson struck to give Martin O'Neill's side victory over St Mirren and keep them top of the Premier League, while champions Rangers fell further behind with defeat at second-placed Hibernian.
fields.body:
They may not be winning emphatically at present but results are going for Celtic in a way that has been all too rare in recent years. Chris Sutton and Henrik Larsson struck to give Martin O'Neill's side victory over St Mirren and keep them top of the Premier League, while champions Rangers fell further behind with defeat at second-placed Hibernian.

O'Neill gave Didier Agathe his long-awaited competitive debut against the men from Paisley as the clubs returned to league action after the mid-week international break.

The former Hibernian striker came in for the suspended Bobby Petta, while the only other change from the side that drew at Aberdeen was Lubomir Moravcik, who replaced the injured Jackie McNamara.

St Mirren manager, Tom Hendrie, gave a start to goal keeper Derek Scrimgour, who was making his first appearance in 20 months and produced some impressive saves in the visitors' goal.

Celtic looked fresh from the start and it took them just two minutes to create their first opening. Paul Lambert found Agathe down the right flank and the striker delivered an excellent right-foot cross to Larsson, but the Swede headed just over the bar.

They should have taken the lead four minutes later when Larsson played a perfectly-weighted ball over the top to Moravcik, whose run took him past Hugh Murray, but the Slovakian's right-foot effort curled just over the bar.

Celtic continued to apply the pressure, with Agathe proving St Mirren's main tormentor; in the 22nd minute he got to the right-hand by-line before playing the ball across the face of goal, but defender Iain Nicholson made a vital interception with Thompson lurking at the far post.

The home side's pressure was rewarded in the 33rd minute with a simple goal from Sutton. Moravcik's in-swinging corner came to the £6million forward and he headed home at the far post despite the despairing efforts of the St Mirren defenders on the line.

Scrimgour did well to keep the deficit at just one when he saved well from Moravcik in the 36th minute and Larsson four minutes later.

St Mirren stirred early in the second half with Nicholson's 52nd-minute shot flashing just over Jonathan Gould's crossbar and Mark Yardley hitting a close-range effort straight at the keeper.

Celtic should have have killed the game off in the 64th minute but Agathe proceeded to squander the best chance of the game. Larsson played the ball through for the striker and he took it round the keeper only to thump it into the side-netting with the visiting defence struggling to get back.

Victory was secured, though, with just six minutes to go and it was Larsson who made up for his earlier wastefulness as he drove home a crisp right-foot free-kick from 20 yards out.

webTitle: Buoyant Baggies deflated

fields.headline: Buoyant Baggies deflated
fields.trailText: It has been quite a sporting autumn for West Bromwich already, what with local star Denise Lewis winning an Olympic gold medal. But Albion fans who had been seeing this as an encouraging portent for the season ahead after their team's own recent successful run were left feeling as deflated as Lewis does at the end of an 800 metres after a late goal by Darren Kenton gave Norwich victory against the run of play.
fields.body:
It has been quite a sporting autumn for West Bromwich already, what with local star Denise Lewis winning an Olympic gold medal. But Albion fans who had been seeing this as an encouraging portent for the season ahead after their team's own recent successful run were left feeling as deflated as Lewis does at the end of an 800 metres after a late goal by Darren Kenton gave Norwich victory against the run of play.

It was the third time the visitors had taken the lead in the match and this time it was decisive. But Norwich's manager, Bryan Hamilton, was at least gracious enough to admit that his side had enjoyed the better luck,

West Brom had every reason to feel optimistic after a run of eight league matches undefeated, which had seen them climb from bottom of the table to fifth.

But it took only 10 minutes for that optimism to be punctured by a struggling Norwich side with a goal that exposed alarming frailties in West Brom's defence.

Fernando Derveld picked the ball up 25 yards from Albion's goal and strode purposefully forward. He was unchallenged as he swapped passes with Chris Llewellyn and went on to hammer a shot past the home keeper, Ryan Jensen.

Indeed, it looked as if West Brom were going to go through the half without creating a clear-cut chance, despite all their possession, when Neil Clement brought them level in the 39th minute. Receiving the ball 25 yards out as Norwich sought to clear, he duly smashed it back over the head of Andy Marshall into the net.

Optimism restored among the Baggies supporters, it took Norwich only another five minutes to deflate it again. Steen Nedergaard's low cross was allowed to find its way to the unmarked Llewellyn, who slid a shot past Jensen to restore his side's advantage.

Whatever was slipped into the teams' half-time cuppa was certainly potent stuff because they both came out snorting and snarling. For two sides whose cuddly mascots are a throstle and a canary, there was nothing cute about what followed.

In one six-minute spell, there was a mass brawl and five names went into the referee's notebook. This period of frantic activity was capped in the 63rd minute when Craig Fleming was penalised for a push on the substitute Bob Taylor, enabling Lee Hughes to draw Albion level from the penalty spot.

The introduction of cult hero Taylor had galvanised his side, lending Albion the cutting edge that had been absent all afternoon. Four times in nine minutes he had the chance to put them ahead, on three occasions being denied by Marshall and once firing over from 18 yards.

They proved to be costly misses because five minutes from the end Norwich punctured Albion's optimism once and for all as Gaetano Giallanza's free-kick was defended half-heartedly and Kenton forced the winner home from six yards.

Megson had some harsh words to say to his side. 'I'm very angry with the manner in which we lost it,' he said. 'We had more corners than them, we had more opportunities and we should have won. It's the same old problem of defending set pieces.'

webTitle: New England, old school values

fields.headline: New England, old school values
fields.standfirst: To get to know the friendly and helpful people of Massachusetts, you can walk into a bar or diner - or have a car crash. Guess which  Robert Yates did
fields.trailText: To get to know the friendly and helpful people of Massachusetts, you can walk into a bar or diner - or have a car crash. Guess which Robert Yates did
fields.body:
It was never part of the plan. But as an introduction to smalltown New England, a minor car crash has its virtues. Not that they were immediately obvious when a local car decided to get intimate with our Dodge as we approached Deerfield in Massachusetts.

We seemed fine but seeming fine proved not good enough for the paramedics, who decided Lisa - top navigator/girlfriend - needed to be lifted out in a strait-jacket. 'It was bound to happen some day,' she quipped, 'but I'd hoped not just yet.' The banter was not entirely out of place since it became obvious that none of the paramedics felt there was anything to worry about. 'Just for safety's sake,' they repeated as they strapped Lisa up. In the land of the litigious, 'safety's sake' is the only option.

By this stage a local police officer had turned up and we were having a chat about the accident's 'other party' (also unharmed) who, it turned out, was the sister of his colleague. (It's a two policeman town). He loaded our bags into his patrol car and invited me for a cup of coffee. 'Shouldn't you be out fighting serious crime,' I wondered. 'What serious crime?' he retorted.

Back in the police 'station' - a desk in the back of what looked like a cub scout hut - the sergeant overheard my difficulties persuading the car hire company back in Boston that I needed a replacement vehicle. He picked up the phone, scoldedthe car hire assistant for his inhospitable big-city ways and ordered him to drive out to the sticks immediately, complete with a new Dodge.

One coffee later, I was back in the patrol car to collect Lisa from hospital. There we ran into the mother of the 'other party' who, after we turned down her dinner invitation, insisted that the sergeant took us to a motel. A motel where, naturally, we got a discount (Crash Victim special tariff?) to 'brighten up the day' in the words of the receptionist.

Maybe we got lucky, bumped into a run of unusually helpful people, but I'd bet not. As natives of America's 'history pocket', New Englanders seem to view themselves as custodians of old school values. At its most routine, this results in a congenial daily fabric. In diners and bars, people are friendly and helpful, but in a sober Yankee fashion.

At its most peculiar, this obsession with tradition throws up a place like Deerfield, a sort of museum village, a series of handsome houses from the sixteenth and seventeenth century, decorated in period 'dress' and open to the public. But amid these model homes are others, home to living and breathing twenty-first-century folk. Spotting the divide between the two is not always simple.

At its most striking, 'custodial' New England offers a town such as Stockbridge, in the heart of the Berkshires, the gentle hill country in central Massachusetts. The Berkshires - metropolitan gone bucolic, a sort of inland Hamptons - is where smart New Yorkers and Bostonians come to cool off in summer. The late, great Norman Rockwell, whose illustrations obsessively detailed smalltown America, made Stockbridge his home for the final 25 years of his life. His comment 'I just love Stockbridge, Stockbridge is the best of America', adorns the local tourist material; the compliment is returned with an impressive Rockwell museum outside town.

The place to stay in Stockbridge is The Red Lion Inn; at dusk, residents gather on the porch, grab a rocking chair and a Bloody Mary, and settle down to watch passers-by. It's a glorious spot, but after a few days Stockbridge begins to feel a little stifling.

As a counter, we set off for the rough and ready coast, north of Boston. New England, with its Ivy League colleges and cultural history, offers plenty of opportunities for literary pilgrimage. Amherst sells itself as 'Emily Dickinson town' while Lenox is home to Edith Wharton's pleasure palace. Our pretext for visiting the port of Gloucester was a more recent literary success, The Perfect Storm , Sebastian Junger's true-life account of the disappearance of the Andrea Gail with its Gloucester crew. Our trip preceded the release of the film.

The Crow's Nest was the drinking haunt of the Andrea Gail fishermen, portrayed in the book as unvarnished and peopled by hard drinkers. At the door, we get cold feet. The trip suddenly feels a bit ghoulish, so we pop next door where we get talking to one of the late fishermen's family. Don't be foolish, she says. Nobody in the bar will take offence. And she was right. It remained the place I'd read about, a slice of blue-collar New England that we hadn't come across on our travels inland. And this time around, it didn't take a car crash to get to know the locals.

Great East Coast films

Moby Dick (1956)
John Huston's classic adaptation of Herman Melville's tale of obsession set in a New England whaling town.

Jaws (1975)
More maritime horrors: a man-eating great white shark brings terror to holiday- makers bathing at Martha's Vineyard and meets his match in Roy Scheider.

On Golden Pond (1981)
Study of family relationships starring Katharine Hepburn and Henry Fonda, filmed at Squam Lake, New Hampshire.

Witness (1985)
Harrison Ford's murder investigation brings havoc to Amish community in Pennsylvania. Australian director Peter Weir's first American film won eight Oscar nominations.

The Crucible (1996)
Film adaptation of Arthur Miller's play about the Salem, Massachusetts witch trials, capturing the claustrophobia of a closed society in which blame and hysteria flourish.

The Cider House Rules (1999)
A young man leaves his orphanage home and his mentor to learn about life and love on an apple farm in Maine.

 Discover New England operates a Visitor Information Line, tel. 0906 55 88 555, weekdays 9.30am to 6pm.
