webTitle: Himalayas is top of the world

fields.headline: Himalayas is top of the world
fields.standfirst: The restoration of a 700-year-old fort in a project that breathed new life into an historic Himalayan village has won the British Airways Tourism for Tomorrow global Award
fields.trailText: The restoration of a 700-year-old fort in a project that breathed new life into an historic Himalayan village has won the British Airways Tourism for Tomorrow global Award.
fields.body:
The Karimabad and Baltit project on the terraced slopes of Hunza, part of the Karakoram range in northern Pakistan, was one of six section winners in the awards which recognise environmental responsibility in the tourism industry. It was chosen as the global winner by a panel, chaired by Professor David Bellamy, which included 17-year-old Leeds sixth-former Lizzie Ashworth who was chosen as the young judge in an Observer competition.

Professor Bellamy said that Lizzie made a crucial contribution in the decision by a panel that included Sir Crispin Tickell, convenor of the UK Government Panel on Sus tainable Development, and Ross B. Simmons, director of the Smithsonian environmental research centre.

The £1 million project, developed by the Aga Khan Trust for Culture, restored the Baltit Fort as a museum and cultural centre, creating new income and opportunities for the 5,000-strong village. It attracts 20,000 visitors a year, half of them from outside Pakistan. Access is limited to pedestrians and only 25 visitors are allowed at a time. The fort earned £30,000 in fees from visitors but brought indirect revenue of around £110,000 to the community.

The restoration was part of a wider regeneration of the area. Meltwater from a glaciers was captured to allow the cultivation of terraced fields and orchards, an arts and crafts centre created jobs for villagers and a new waste system was introduced.

webTitle: Translatlantic shopping in Boston

fields.headline: Bought in, sold out
fields.standfirst: Sheryl Garratt goes on a transatlantic shopping trip and finds great things to buy but discovers she'd rather be sightseeing
fields.trailText: Sheryl Garratt goes on a transatlantic shopping trip and finds great things to buy but discovers she'd rather be sightseeing.
fields.body:
It's a hot autumn day in the North End of Boston, and a group of us are loitering sheepishly on the narrow pavement while Michele Topor dives into a greengrocer's. The shop is too small for us to follow her, so she bobs back outside waving a pair of aubergines - which she proceeds to sex for us. The one with the line mark opposite the stem is female; the one with a dot is male. The male of the species is superior, she explains: it's less bitter.

It's one of many new things I learned during Topor's three-hour culinary tour. A passionate guide, she marched us in and out of specialist stores, introducing chefs, shopkeepers and characters while producing a continuous stream of recipes and anecdotes. The North End is Boston's oldest neighbourhood, dating back to 1630 when the first English Puritans settled. A first stop for many European immigrants, it became Jewish, then Irish. By 1910, however, the area was 90 per cent Italian - which is how it stayed until recently, when developers began turning run-down buildings into luxury flats and young professionals began making their homes here. More change looms as harbourside redevelopment marches on.

But the shops are still defiantly small, local and Italian. You can still buy fresh-filled cannoli (a Sicilian dessert) at Maria's Bakery on Cross Street and sticks of liquorice root in Polcari's Coffee on Salem Street - a shop opened in 1932, which is probably also when it was last decorated. Almost everywhere we visited produced something for us to try - delicious pumpkin fudge, cheeses, biscuits, marzipan, balsamic vinegar, slivers of ham.

Across the Charles River in Cambridge, the shops and cafés clustered around Harvard Square give a taste of what may be to come for the North End. Over a huge breakfast at Henrietta's Table in the Charles Hotel, the restaurant's director Tom Daley says that many locals are unhappy with the way the area is changing. The university owns most of the property, and many leases came up for renewal at the start of this year. Rents went up and some of the oldest retailers moved out, letting the big chain stores in. For now most of the shops are still small and funky, with pricey but interesting clothes and shoe shops as well as the highest concentration of bookshops in the world.

Proof that not all change need be bad can be found back across the river in the Quincy Market/Faneuil Hall area, where 10 million tourists shop every year. It was redeveloped in the 1970s at the same time as London's Covent Garden, with much the same aim: to reinvent the grand buildings of the main produce market. A food court now runs down the centre of Quincy Market selling seafood and every kind of ethnic cuisine imaginable: a great place for a pit-stop on the retail trail. The stalls of the North Market are a great source of unusual toys and trinkets.

Across town, Newbury Street is Boston's equivalent to the King's Road. Posh designer stores are clustered at one end by the Public Gardens, and the shops on this long tree-lined street get smaller and more innovative as it heads west. It's a great place for people-watching and at Christmas the lights make it a magical walk, but this street, too, is losing its capacity to surprise.

It seems like only yesterday (1992 in fact) when I walked into a Starbucks, ordered a frappuccino and thought it was the coolest caffeine hit I'd ever experienced. Now you can get this frozen coffee confection on almost any UK high street, in a Starbucks with the same pictures on the walls as in Boston. Sunglasses Hut, Baby Gap, Niketown and Foot Locker have similarly lost their power to thrill the visitor.

In 1620 a group of religious dissenters called the Pilgrims sailed from Plymouth on The Mayflower to start a new life. They landed at Cape Cod, finally settling in Plymouth, Massachusetts, and founding the first British colony. There is a recreation of the settlement at Plimoth Plantation.

Boston Tea Party
In protest against crippling taxes by the British government, colonists emptied the cargo of three tea ships into Boston Harbour in 1773, igniting the revolution. The Boston Tea Party Ship and Museum tell the story.

Declaration of Independence
Colonial leaders met in Philadelphia to sign the Declaration of Independence on 4 July 1776, leading to the Revolutionary War. Independence Hall is one of the most visited historical attractions in the US.

webTitle: Falling for the colour

fields.headline: Falling for the colour
fields.standfirst: Pennsylvania's autumn display stuns  Joanne O'Connor
fields.trailText: Pennsylvania's autumn display stuns Joanne O'Connor.
fields.body:
There's something very soothing about tramping through a forest after rainfall. As we followed the trail between the 200-year old white pines, maples and hemlocks of Cooks Forest, there was a satisfying mulch of damp leaves underfoot and a cool smell of glistening black bark. We emerged from the trees onto Seneca Point, a huge boulder giving endless views over one of Pennsylvania's oldest tracts of virgin woodland.

Seen against a sky the colour of Pittsburgh steel and shrouded in pockets of mist the autumn leaves, ranging in colour from palest yellow to deepest red, seemed to generate a light of their own.

More than half of Pennsylvania is covered in forest, and during the month of October it offers up a show of colour to rival New England's. Like a creeping rash the change begins in the northern reaches of the Allegheny National Forest, spreading south to reach the parks and gardens of Pittsburgh by the time November comes.

The northwest corner of Pennsylvania has more trees and fewer people than any other part of the state. It wasn't always this way. Oil and coal were the area's black gold, spawning towns such as Oil City and Pithole in the wilderness and stripping bare the forests to build houses and railroads.

A huge tree planting exercise during the Great Depression of the 1930s put to work Pittsburgh's legions of unemployed and restored the woodlands. The elk which once roamed Pennsylvania had disappeared with the trees but an attempt to relocate a herd from South Dakota has proved so successful that the area now boasts the biggest free-roaming herd east of the Mississippi. We drove for miles on unmade roads in search of the herd only to come upon a giant elk chewing up a front lawn in downtown Benezette.

One of the best ways of seeing the fall foliage is to drive Route 6. This coast to coast highway crosses Pennsylvania's northernmost reaches, cutting through the Allegheny forest and quaint towns such as Warren and Smethport where the lumber and oil barons built their mansions.

Like New England these towns have plenty of all-American clapboard houses with rocking chairs on porches and Halloween pumpkins in windows. Unlike New England at this time of year the roads are free of tourists - just you and the occasional squashed skunk.

Alternatively you could give the skunk a break and take a trip on the Knox & Kane Railroad. The steam-hauled train originally carried coal but now carries tourists on excursions across the Kinzua Bridge. Built in 1882, the spindly 300-ft high viaduct gives heartstopping views over the Kinzua State Park.

As the train rattled through the forest and over the bridge the three Amish girls who had been sitting quietly behind me jumped out of their seats to get a better view.

With near-perfect timing the sun made a brief appearance from behind the clouds and the trees turned from copper to gold. England looked greener than ever as we flew back into Gatwick.

Who are the Amish?

The Amish settled in Pennsylvania in the 1720s fleeing religious persecution in Europe. Attracted by state founder William Penn's promise to create a colony where all could worship freely, the Amish shun the outside world and its conveniences, choosing gas lamps over electricity and horse-drawn buggies over cars. They speak an old German dialect and refer to outsiders as 'English'.

The biggest concentration of Amish is around the city of Lancaster in towns such as Intercourse, Bird in Hand and Paradise. The men are famed for carpentry and the women for quilt-making.

 US Airways flies daily from London Gatwick to Pittsburgh. Accommodation at the Gateway Lodge in the heart of Cooks Forest is from $135 a night for a room and from $165 a night for a log cabin. For further information contact Pennsylvania Tourism on 0207 738 9422.

webTitle: Fall in lottery takings harms causes

fields.headline: Fall in lottery takings harms causes
fields.trailText: The shambles surrounding the battle to run the National Lottery is causing the public to abandon the game and is threatening the amount of money raised for good causes.
fields.body:
The shambles surrounding the battle to run the National Lottery is causing the public to abandon the game and is threatening the amount of money raised for good causes.

An analysis by The Observer of ticket sales since the process was plunged into chaos two months ago reveals that the public spent £2.4 million less on lottery tickets for the main Wednesday and Saturday draws compared to the same period last year.

Despite the Olympics raising the profile of the lottery, with money donated to athletes such as Denise Lewis and Stephen Redgrave, analysts say the downturn shows how damaging the delays to the decision on who will run the lottery next year are.

'Evidence from around the world shows that image is vital when it comes to the lottery,' said Denis Vaughan, head of the Lottery Promotion Company and the man credited with first suggesting the idea of a lottery for the arts to John Major when he was Prime Minister.

'When that image is damaged it becomes difficult to retain players. Chris Smith [the Secretary of State for Culture with overall responsibility for the lottery] must bring this sorry episode to an end.'

Since the Lottery Commission announced at the end of August that they would only talk to Richard Branson's People's Lottery with regard to the licence, there have been a series of damaging rows over the lottery's future.

First, Camelot took the Commission to the High Court which said that the decision was unfair.

Then, three weeks ago, The Observer revealed that the bidding process was in chaos and that Camelot was threatening further legal action over what they perceived as a lack of transparency and fairness at the commission.

Three days later, the commission's chairman, Dame Helena Shovelton, resigned.

Lottery experts argue that the delays in making a decision means that the lottery itself is at risk because there will not be enough time to get the new lottery up and running by next year's October deadline. For every day that the lottery doesn't run, up to £4 million could be lost to good causes.

The Observer analysed 13 Saturday and Wednesday draws from the end of August to last week and compared them to last year. In 1999, £524 million worth of tickets were sold. This year that figure had dropped to £521.6 million.

Yesterday, Camelot took out full page adverts in national newspapers directly linking the success of the British rowing team to lottery money which helped to fund their training.

Stephen Redgrave and Matthew Pinsent are pictured holding a medal which says £10.5 billion has been raised for good causes by the lottery.

Camelot are set to meet the new chairman of the lottery, Lord Burns, this week. They will ask him to re-evaluate both of the bids from scratch because of evidence that they have not been treated fairly.

webTitle: Space-age trains take the strain on Gatwick run

fields.headline: Space-age trains take the strain on Gatwick run
fields.standfirst: Gatwick Express is replacing its 25-year-old rolling stock with a fleet of hi-tech trains that have more legroom and more space to store luggage
fields.trailText: Gatwick Express is replacing its 25-year-old rolling stock with a fleet of hi-tech trains that have more legroom and more space to store luggage.
fields.body:
The first of the new trains is now in service on the 30-minute non-stop journey between London Victoria and Gatwick Airport. 'They have been designed with the air traveller in mind. We have made the journey more comfortable and the trains are brighter and more spacious,' said Gatwick Express managing director Peter Cotton.

The redesign aims to make the train journey reminiscent of air travel with streamlined 'cabins', airline-style seating and livery and air-conditioning. There are also plans to extend check-in facilities at Victoria station to help ease congestion at Gatwick.

webTitle: High Fives

fields.headline: High Fives
fields.standfirst: Nigel Lloyd  picks the top slopes on the East Coast
fields.trailText: Nigel Lloyd picks the top slopes on the East Coast.
fields.body:
Killington is the largest ski area in the east with 87 miles of trails split equally between beginner, intermediate and advanced skiers. The 32 lifts include the longest in the States. Mogul lovers can test themselves down the steep, long Outer Limits. There are three half-pipes, two fun parks and a boarder-cross course for snowboarders. A cheerful, lively resort at night.

Cascades Lodge, room and breakfast, seven nights starting 6 January, scheduled flights, £659, including hire-car. Lotus Supertravel (020 7962 9933)

Smugglers' Notch got its name when embargoed English goods came in from Canada over this Vermont pass. Seven lifts access 67 trails, half intermediate. There's some testing skiing too - it even boasts a triple diamond black. Snowboarders have two fun parks and a 400ft half-pipe. There are no hotels, this is 'condo' land. Smuggs is the local name for this child-first resort (voted No 1 for families in the US), and kids will love it.

The Village at Smugglers' Notch, room only, seven nights starting 6 January, scheduled flights and transfers, £715. (First child free, second child £215). Ski the American Dream (020 8552 1201)

Stowe has great style both on and off the mountain. The eighteenth-century village has a touch of class not found in more modern resorts. The slopes on 3,640ft Mt Mansfield are seven miles up the road; long, narrow, twisting runs through the trees put paid to overconfidence. A quarter of the 48 trails are black, 60 per cent are intermediate. The 11 lifts have been improved but don't expect detachable six-seaters. Snowboarders have a couple of fun parks and a half-pipe. Green Mountain Inn, room only, seven nights starting 6 January, scheduled flights, £499, including hire car. Ski Independence (0870 555 0555)

Loon Mountain may raise a smile, but it has some of the most convenient accommodation in New Hampshire. The skiing is improving, with better lifts, including a gondola and a high-speed quad, 43 trails and an area for beginners. There are plenty of intermediate runs; experts head for North Peak with its vertical drop of 2,100ft. Lift tickets are interchangeable at Waterville and Cranmore.

The Woodwards Inn, room only, seven nights starting 6 January, scheduled flights, hire car, ski pass, equipment hire, and ski tuition, £840, including insurance. Equity Total Ski (01273 298298).

Sunday River likes to boast about its snowmaking: 1,500 snowguns make it the largest and most advanced snowmaker in the east. There are 127 trails spread over eight interconnected peaks in this Maine resort, and 18 lifts. Best for intermediate and beginner skiers, even though 40 per cent of the terrain is black. There are half-pipes, boarder-cross and fun parks for snowboarders. For apres-ski head for nearby Bethel.

Summit Apartments, self-catering studio, seven nights starting 6 January, scheduled flights to Boston, £570, including car. Neilson (08705 141414).

webTitle: Small glimpses of giants below the surface

fields.headline: Small glimpses of giants below the surface
fields.standfirst: Sheryl Garratt joins the whale watchers
fields.trailText: Sheryl Garratt joins the whale watchers.
fields.body:
Leaving Boston's inner harbour, you get a fine view of the Custom House clock tower, its oldest skyscraper. A pair of endangered peregrine falcons have made their home on its peak, a fitting symbol of the way America's oldest city has blended its modernity with New England's natural beauty.

It was one of many sights pointed out in a breezy, informative commentary as our whale-watching boat left on its hour-long journey to Stellwagen Bank, a shallow, plankton-rich area of water that provides a feeding ground for so much marine life it's been made a nature sanctuary. It is home to both humpback and minke whales, and sightings are guaranteed from April to November. Then the animals show their intelligence by migrating to the Caribbean for winter.

As we neared the bank, our guide's commentary was interrupted by two large, black shapes rising out of the sea surprisingly close to the boat. They were humpbacks. When one dived giving a clear view of the distinctive markings on the underside of its tail, our guide identified her as a female known as Tornado, accompanied by her young calf. The pair went into a deep dive leaving a 'whale footprint' - a still, glassy circle on the choppy sea. The boat moved on, heading for one of the many sets of breathing spouts we could see on the horizon. (The spout is not, as I'd assumed, sea water. It is condensation made as the whale exhales, its warm breath showing in the air as our own does on a cold day.)

As the whales dived and resurfaced around us, our guide explained what we were seeing: from spectacular tail-flips and kicks on the surface perhaps to get rid of barnacles and parasites, to feeding activity and dives both shallow and deep. What struck me most was the apparent indifference these mighty animals had to human activity: great for those of us wanting to see them, but no so good for the whales themselves - even in these protected waters they are often fatally injured in tangles with trawlers' fishing nets.

As we moved away, our guide said it had been one of the best sightings for weeks. But up on the surface, you never get a real sense of these huge sea mammals. Just a tiny, humbling and exhilarating glimpse into an existence completely apart from our own.

 New England Aquarium Whale Watches cost $26.50 for adults, $19 for youths (12-18) and $16.50 for children (up to 11). For reservations call 00 1 617 973 5281. They run every weekend until November 5, and begin again in April next year.

webTitle: The man who gave politics a good name

fields.headline: The man who gave politics a good name
fields.standfirst: Scotland was robbed of one of her favourite sons last week but Donald Dewar's long shadow remains, says Andrew Marr
fields.trailText: Scotland was robbed of one of her favourite sons last week but Donald Dewar's long shadow remains, says Andrew Marr
fields.body:
Donald Dewar was irascible, sarcastic, grumpy and a stranger to tact. He worked like a horse and he ate like a horse. Like many an old Labour right-winger, he was incurably partisan; yes, he had friends in other parties, he forged the Edinburgh coalition with the Liberal Democrats and worked closely with the Scottish Nationalists during the Scottish referendum, but basically he thought anyone who wasn't Labour was guilty of a shaming moral lapse. He could be exceedingly, chillingly, rude. So why did his sudden death cause such a shudder of sadness throughout Scotland and British politics? Puzzled interviewers asked correspondents and colleagues again and again - what made Donald Dewar any different. They - we - struggled to explain.

It is hard. You have to come at it crabwise. My scuttle starts with some lines from the final speech he made a couple of weeks ago. 'Recently,' he announced, 'I was accused of being an animadverter - someone who talks reasonably fluently, looking at a subject from every side but coming to no very obvious conclusions. It is an art form and one I have been practising for many years without necessarily achieving competence. I have no intention of changing my habits tonight.' Can anyone name another politician who would dream of describing himself in such a circular, self-mocking way? If politics is thought of as the pretenders' profession, a trade for accent-shifters, bobbing and ingratiating populists, people who are ever less than they seem on the surface, then Dewar was a living refutation. Behind the gangling, fastidious shell was an awesomely cultured, witty, often tortured mind and a will of steel.

He was deeply soaked in Scottish literature and art, a genuine lover of Glasgow and her people who disliked Abroad and for a long time didn't even hold a passport; a dry wit who was also hilarious and shocking in the safety of a small circle of close friends. Like many another in British public life he sought refuge in withering self-deprecation, once comparing himself to Kerensky as 'a middle-class man who reads books and did not make it'.

Clearly, given that he became Scotland's first First Minister, having finally achieved through parliamentary slog and popular campaigning, the parliament he had wanted most of his adult life, the final bit is wrong. He did make it. But he was indeed bookish, high-brow and solitary.

Yet this, too, gives the wrong impression. Of all the politicians I have watched on the campaign trail, Dewar was among those who enjoyed it most, stalking into a pensioners' lunch club in Glasgow to hear songs, swap rude stories and reminisce about local characters, or being button-holed by some eccentric whose comments he'd repeat all day. Having the inner confidence not to talk down, or disguise his middle-class culture, meant 'Big Donald' was in turn regarded as far more 'of the people' than many posturers from poorer backgrounds. And in that, too, he came from another age. His hero was Hugh Gaitskell and the unapologetic 'bourgeois oblige' of the post-war Labour government hung about him all his life.

But again, I have missed it. This suggests that he was a pure Labour figure, living inside the party and its urban heartlands, a man out of time. Yet it was also Dewar who was able to incur the anger of the London Blairites by allying himself with the SNP leader Alex Salmond to win the 'yes, yes' vote in the Scottish referendum. Searching for his goal, he could do the entirely unexpected. Without him, it might have been very different.

It is, frankly, too early to judge how strong is the new Scottish polity he helped create. The coalition with the Liberal Democrats required a lot of personal work by Dewar and the Labour group, though it has good people, is very inexperienced and weak now he has gone. He suffered from the political leader's curse of assuming that nothing would go right unless he was personally in charge of it - though it has to be said, given the Edinburgh Parliament's first year, with some justification.

If the Scottish Parliament is really a solid achievement, putting to sleep the nationalist threat, then why is the accident of his removal from the scene such a blow to it? Alternatively, perhaps his long shadow had simply kept others in the dark, unable or unwilling to grow properly themselves.

Those questions will be answered before very long. Like many others, I felt sick when I heard that Donald Dewar was now the subject of that universal, inexplicable slide of the tense from 'is'; to 'was'. But the one person not to feel sorry for is the man himself. He was assailed from all sides in his final weeks. But he changed the world around him, stamped himself on his country's imagination and then died quickly from his chosen addiction, which was politics.

webTitle: Scotland enters uncharted water

fields.headline: Scotland enters uncharted water
fields.standfirst: Successor to Dewar will be forced to embrace a more nationalistic agenda
fields.trailText: Successor to Dewar will be forced to embrace a more nationalistic agenda
fields.body:
Next Saturday, 81 senior members of the Scottish Labour Party will convene at Viewforth, the baronial-style headquarters of Stirling council. There, in the shadow of Stirling Castle, the 53 MSPs and 27 members of the party's Scottish executive will deal with one item of business: the election of Donald Dewar's successor as party leader and First Minister of Scotland.

It is a near certainty that two candidates - Henry McLeish, the Enterprise Minister, and Jack McConnell, the Finance Minister - will be nominated from the floor. But whichever man emerges from that room as the victor, one outcome is guaranteed. The tragic events of last week mean the United Kingdom is about to experience the most profound shift in its constitutional settlement since the Scots voted to establish the Holyrood Parliament in 1997.

'Donald's death is going to have a huge impact on the relationship between Edinburgh and London,' said one senior Labour MP at Westminster. 'You would have to be an idiot not to believe it is now a very different game.'

At 12.18pm last Wednesday, the moment Dewar was pronounced dead, the whole of the UK, not only Scotland, entered uncharted and perilous constitutional waters. While Dewar was at the helm, the transition to devolved government had been relatively smooth and unthreatening. With his Westminster pedigree and Cabinet big-hitter status, he formed the crucial bridge between the old, unitary UK and the new, devolved system.

In Scotland, he was respected as the driving force behind change; in Downing Street, he was trusted as the safe pair of hands to keep that change firmly anchored in the wider Labour vision of Britain. Open conflict between Holyrood and Westminster has been almost non-existent. But with Dewar's passing, the realities of dividing power between two different parliaments will quickly become apparent.

For whoever takes over from Dewar will immediately be confronted with the unenviable task of moving the Parliament out from beneath the late First Minister's shadow. To do so, they will almost certainly have to adopt a more nationalistic agenda.

According to recent polls, fewer than one in four Scots want independence, while more than half support devolution. But at the same time, the SNP has established a fairly solid lead over Labour when it comes to Holyrood voting intentions. The implication is clear: voters might not want to break up the UK but they want a Scottish Executive ready to rough it up with Downing Street.

'The idea that the British state has ever been homogeneous is flawed, but never more so than now,' said James Mitchell, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. 'The real test of devolution was always going to come post-Dewar, and we are now moving into a much more realistic phase for the Scottish Parliament.

'Without Dewar, it is going to have to stand up, establish itself and work.'

So McLeish or McConnell will have to be prepared to break away from the path dictated by London party policy, a task that may come more naturally to McConnell. He was a founder of the Scottish Labour Action group in the 1980s and represented Labour on the Constitutional Convention. McLeish, by contrast, was a Westminster MP for 13 years, during which time he served as a UK Minister. But even he will want to start thumping a more overtly Scottish tub if he wins. One minefield the new First Minister will almost certainly have to cross involves the question of greater powers for Holyrood, in particular over raising its own finances.

More importantly, Dewar's successor will have to be seen to secure a few victories against London. And that may create further problems for Labour in Scotland. There are fears in some quarters that neither man has the stature to take on Downing Street over a major issue of policy and win. 'The relationship between London and Edinburgh is going to be much more fluid,' said Mitchell. 'Dewar was somebody who could go to Blair, if not as an equal, then damn near it, and the loss of somebody who was such a big player on the British field is going to have a serious effect. Dewar was able to smooth things over, and none of the potential candidates is going to be able to do that.'

Some leading Labour MSPs agree. One told The Observer : 'Downing Street will be concerned because Tony Blair knew Donald well and so did Gordon Brown. Whatever relationship they have with whoever takes over will not be the same.'

All this will make life difficult for Downing Street. The movement of power away from London fits in with Blair's philosophical support for decentralisation. But it runs counter to his centralising instincts that the 'only way to get things done' is for him and his staff to get involved. He has had to learn, from the debacle of Ken Livingstone's successful campaign to be Mayor of London to the mess over Alun Michael in Wales, that devolving power means losing power.

In an interview with The Observer in the spring, he admitted that he had to learn to let go.

That decision will be tested now. Much like Margaret Thatcher, Blair has never really 'got' Scotland. He left it to the likes of Dewar, one of the few people he felt politically in awe of. Now he no longer has that luxury. 'The best way to describe it is that devolution is a big juggernaut Blair could live with so long as Donald was driving,' said a senior Scottish Labour MP. 'He knew its path would be predictable and it would only really have one gear. But now the fear is the juggernaut will run out of control.'

A senior Labour Party figure with close connections to Downing Street said Blair was 'totally relaxed' about leaving the decision to Scotland. Downing Street has poured cold water on claims it intended to parachute in a senior Cabinet figure - names mooted included that of Alistair Darling, the Social Security Secretary, and John Reid, the Scottish Secretary - to take Dewar's old job.

The fact is the potential Scottish front-runners do not fill Blair with the dread with which he greeted the news of Livingstone running for London and Rhodri Morgan running for Wales. A Downing Street source said a decision had been taken that Scotland and Wales should be left to their own devices.

Many in Scotland are not convinced by these protestations. 'Tony Blair's problem is he doesn't have much understanding of the rest of the UK, which is surprising given that he spent time at school in Edinburgh,' said Mitchell. 'He has devolved institutions, but he still has a unitary state mindset.'

Even taking a back seat may turn out to be a dangerous strategy. Blair, if his majority is cut drastically at the next election, will still be relying on Westminster MPs from north of the border to keep him in power. If Labour at Holyrood suffers a meltdown, there would be a knock-on effect on the UK-wide elections.

That is why Blair will ensure Gordon Brown has a key role. The Chancellor, who enjoys enormous influence in Scotland, will step in to ensure the handover is smooth. 'Nobody with an English accent in Downing Street will get involved in this, but Brown will still be pulling strings,' said a Scottish MP.

The potential pitfalls of this tactic were already emerging within 36 hours of Dewar's death. Supporters of McLeish were spinning that Brown had endorsed their man's bid to be anointed as party leader without a contest in the interests of party unity. The reaction from other Labour politicians and the Scottish media was predictable outrage. Yet again, Downing Street was implicated in a botched attempt to stitch up the contest.

But the implications of Dewar's death are not limited to the Executive benches. Three weeks ago, the SNP's own big-hitting frontman, Alex Salmond, stepped aside after 10 years at the helm.

The SNP, too, is adjusting to having a new, relatively inexperienced and untested leader in John Swinney. 'We used to have two real heavyweights slugging it out,' one MSP said last week. 'Now it is going to be two featherweights.'

And if the new First Minister does pull off a few victories against London, the nationalists may well see their opinion poll leads evaporate. 'It is just too early to say what sort of effect this will have on the Parliament and on our strategy,' said Swinney, who was able to take on Dewar at question time only once since being installed as leader.

'Obviously, I had not expected to be facing a new Labour leader this quickly, although I thought there was a possibility there would be a new one by the time of the Scottish general election in 2004. The one thing I would say is that political culture is shaped by people and the way people interrelate within institutions.' In the next few months, Scotland and the rest of the UK will find out how deep that change will run.

webTitle: Observer review: Diaries by Alan Clark

fields.headline: Pooter in Parliament
fields.standfirst: Alan Clark's diaries reveal him as a raconteur, a roué... and a fascist. Thank heavens no one took him too seriously
fields.trailText: Alan Clark's diaries reveal him as a raconteur, a roué... and a fascist. Thank heavens no one took him too seriously
fields.body:
Diaries: Into Politics
Alan Clark
Weidenfeld and Nicholson £20, pp452
Buy it at BOL

It is Tuesday, 8 December 1981. Alan Clark has been lunching with Frank Johnson, then, and now again, a parliamentary sketch writer. Johnson seems to be less interested in talking about the Conservative Party than in Clark's views about the Nazis. 'Yes, I told him, I was a Nazi; I really believed it to be the ideal system, and that it was a disaster for the Anglo-Saxon races and for the world that it was extinguished.' Johnson, by Clark's account, gulps and grins and suggests he can't really mean it.

'Oh yes, I told him, I was completely committed to the whole philosophy. The blood and violence was an essential ingredient of its strength, the heroic tradition of cruelty every bit as powerful and a thousand times more ancient than the Judaeo-Christian ethic.' Johnson persists in disbelieving Clark. And what does he confide to his diary? That it was, indeed, a bit of a joke? No. He complains that Johnson and others take 'refuge in the convention that Alan-doesn't-really-mean-it. He-only-says-it-to-shock, etc. Frank said that people simply will not allow the reality that a "toff" could be serious about these views...'

Alan doesn't really mean it. There is the nub of the problem. At some level, he clearly did mean it and this selection of his earlier diaries, running from 1972-1982 when his famous Diaries begins, makes Clark's fascist views very clear. On several occasions, he toys with the idea of defecting to the National Front. Two NF members come to his constituency surgery; he chats to them and muses: 'How good they were, and how brave is the minority, in a once great country who keep alive the tribal essence.'

The NF won't stand against him, he reassures his Tory Plymouth officials 'because they know I'm the nearest thing they're likely to get to an MP'. He frequently compares his personal situation with Hitler's, recording, for instance, in 1976: 'Obsessed with the fall of the Reich. This is 1944, one year left.' He fantasises about being called to lead the country at a moment of collapse.

So what are we to make of it all? Was Alan Clark sinister, despite his brilliant prose talent and his irresistible wit? For those who never knew him, the best clue comes in a passage from 1979, when he is intriguing to become a Tory whip which, he concedes, would be 'second best from the original concept of galloping across the countryside on a white horse, drawn sword in hand, rousing the populace - but I would settle for it'.

Yes, it is Mr Pooter. If he can't be a darkly handsome Nazi leader, he would settle for the Conservative whips' office. In the end, Alan Clark and his diaries are engaging and tolerable because we will not, cannot, grant him the thing he most wants from his audience - we cannot take him seriously.

This is Pooter with a castle, a collection of cars straight from Toad's garage, a ferocious sexual urge and a deep strain of hypochondria. We laugh with him, some of the time, but more often we laugh at him. He came to realise it, which must have been almost intolerable. For all the swagger and swish, the style and the curled lip, he was a comic figure and knew it.

The comedy, as with other comic diarists, depends heavily on the repetition of key themes. He is constantly giving up backgammon and just as constantly, a few days later, losing yet more money at it. He is always on the sexual prowl, generally unsuccessfully, and finds the oddest things provoke his turbulent libido.

To my eye, one of the least explicable, funniest moments comes during an assessment of his bodily decay ('eyes puffy' etc): 'A bit stiff, can get quite unpleasant twinges from shoulder if, eg, turning round while holding up phone.' And then, apropos of nothing: 'Being 51 makes me feel quite lecherous.' What? Run that past us again?

Similarly, below the show-off remarks, his politics are simply incoherent. He is pro-Nazi but also proud of the 'Spitfire summer'. He is violently anti-European but entranced by that original Europeanist, Harold Macmillan. He is utterly committed to Margaret Thatcher and the Tory right wing except when he is buttering up her sworn Cabinet enemy and leading 'wet', Francis Pym, telling him he'll be Prime Minister in two years if he resigns and takes her on. Does this seem just a little odd, even to him? It does.

'What a rich, endlessly varied and exciting world politics is for those who are addicted to it,' he gushes. 'And how inextricably woven are the different strands of greed, ambition, cowardice and idealism. No one's motives are pure; certainly not mine.' Yes, it's that man again - Mr Pooter goes to Parliament.

Perhaps it is impossible to be a great diarist without being enough of a fool to play Everyman at his weakest moments as well as at the tender ones. Clark's desperate lechery, repeatedly broken promises to himself to reform, his snobbery, his political inanities, his low moments of self-rebuke and even his hypochondria are all very reminiscent of that great diarist, James Boswell and, at times, of Samuel Pepys himself. The diaries of the high-minded and consistent cannot be nearly as amusing.

This volume is duller than the first, later one, simply because less happens to Clark during it; he is not so central to political life and has less to reveal. Debts, health, his lack of real political success and his gloom about his children and properties produce a whining note at times which grates. The high comedy is here - his buying-off of a former mistress with the help of Jonathan Aitken and a briefcase with a bugging device is one for the anthologies - but it is less rich than the previous volume.

Alan Clark wanted to make the world gasp and tremble. In the end, he made it gasp and giggle instead. The answer to the 'Nazi question' was less that Alan-didn't-really-believe-it, more that no-one-really-believed-in-him.

That, I suspect, was a source of real private pain, too private, even, to be recorded in his diaries. Good news for the rest of us, though.

 Andrew Marr is political editor of the BBC

He is constantly giving up backgammon and just as constantly, a few days later, losing yet more money at it. He is always on the sexual prowl, generally unsuccessfully, and finds the oddest things provoke his turbulent libido. To my eye, one of the least explicable, funniest moments comes during an assessment of his bodily decay ('eyes puffy' etc): 'A bit stiff, can get quite unpleasant twinges from shoulder if, eg, turning round while holding up phone.' And then, apropos of nothing: 'Being 51 makes me feel quite lecherous.' What? Run that past us again? Similarly, below the show-off remarks, his politics are simply incoherent. He is pro-Nazi but also proud of the 'Spitfire summer'. He is violently anti-European but entranced by that original Europeanist, Harold Macmillan. He is utterly committed to Margaret Thatcher and the Tory right wing except when he is buttering up her sworn Cabinet enemy and leading 'wet', Francis Pym, telling him he'll be Prime Minister in two years if he resigns and takes her on. Does this seem just a little odd, even to him? It does. 'What a rich, endlessly varied and exciting world politics is for those who are addicted to it,' he gushes. 'And how inextricably woven are the different strands of greed, ambition, cowardice and idealism. No one's motives are pure; certainly not mine.' Yes, it's that man again - Mr Pooter goes to Parliament. Perhaps it is impossible to be a great diarist without being enough of a fool to play Everyman at his weakest moments as well as at the tender ones. Clark's desperate lechery, repeatedly broken promises to himself to reform, his snobbery, his political inanities, his low moments of self-rebuke and even his hypochondria are all very reminiscent of that great diarist, James Boswell and, at times, of Samuel Pepys himself. The diaries of the high-minded and consistent cannot be nearly as amusing. This volume is duller than the first, later one, simply because less happens to Clark during it; he is not so central to political life and has less to reveal. Debts, health, his lack of real political success and his gloom about his children and properties produce a whining note at times which grates. The high comedy is here - his buying-off of a former mistress with the help of Jonathan Aitken and a briefcase with a bugging device is one for the anthologies - but it is less rich than the previous volume. Alan Clark wanted to make the world gasp and tremble. In the end, he made it gasp and giggle instead. The answer to the 'Nazi question' was less that Alan-didn't-really-believe-it, more that no-one-really-believed-in-him. That, I suspect, was a source of real private pain, too private, even, to be recorded in his diaries. Good news for the rest of us, though.  Andrew Marr is political editor of the BBC

webTitle: Unspoilt by stardom

fields.headline: Unspoilt by stardom
fields.standfirst: Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard may be the summer playground of the rich and famous but  John Brunton  finds room at the country inns at moderate prices
fields.trailText: Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard may be the summer playground of the rich and famous but John Brunton finds room at the country inns at moderate prices.
fields.body:
As the ferry steams out of the tiny New England harbour of Wood's Hole, it takes less than an hour's sailing through the choppy Atlantic waters to have a first sight of the island of Martha's Vineyard, which along with its neighbour, Nantucket, is one of the most sought-after holiday destinations in North America. These islands have hardly changed since the first colonial settlers arrived 350 years ago, the architecture preserved, the natural landscapes protected from any kind of development.

These wild, out-of-the-way isles adapt to the seasons like chameleons. In spring and autumn they are peaceful, perfect for walking and cycling through wetlands and miles of silvery beaches and sandy dunes. There will be plenty of room at the picturesque 'country inns', refined guesthouses oozing traditional New England style, generous hospitality and attractive prices. There is never any problem booking a table at gourmet restaurants, and this is a great time for being casual, with nothing better than a famous 'clambake' at the beach, a feast of locally-caught clams, mussels and lobsters.

In midsummer the islands are transformed into an exclusive playground for the rich and famous. Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket are the long-time vacation home of the Kennedys and more recently the favourite escape for Bill Clinton and his family, and in July and August, half of Hollywood - from Sylvester Stallone and Dustin Hoffman, to Sharon Stone and Cameron Diaz - descends. There is a price to pay for rubbing shoulders with movie stars at the bar of the renowned Black Dog Tavern, or waiting in line next to a famous rock singer to choose an exotic sorbet at Mad Martha's ice cream parlour.

The population of the islands grows 10-fold in summer, accommodation rates double, and suddenly everyone is vying to get dinner reservations at exclusive dining spots such as L'Etoile on Martha's Vineyard or the Chanticleer in Nantucket, where the bill will come to a lot more than one for the clambake. Whenever you decide to visit - and the islands are ideally situated between New York and Boston - a detour takes you to a different world, a different pace of life, where there's no crime, no traffic lights, no stress, and just lots of laid-back entertain ment, with regular music, art and cinema festivals, farmers markets, bargain antique stores, and village fairs.

Outside the peak summer period, hotels on the island offer deals - lower midweek prices, large off-season discounts. Try to negotiate the best price when making a reservation. Although you will discover some of the most luxurious 'country inns' in the US, there is a range of reasonably priced accommodation too. There are few modern hotels thanks to a strict environmental policy: the historical eighteenth and nineteenth-century clapboard wooden houses have been renovated for today's visitor.

Here are some addresses to suit different pockets. The prices quoted are for a double room, from low to high season. Most include a traditional American breakfast, so large you can usually forget about lunch. There are also recommendations for the best evening dining on both islands

Martha's Vineyard

Where to stay

Hob Knob Inn
128 Main Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 9510, fax 00 1 508 627 4560, email: hobknob@vineyard.net).
$100-500
Ultra-luxury country inn, where John Kennedy once stayed. Sumptuous rooms, gourmet breakfast and traditional afternoon tea - including freshly squeezed lemonade. There is also a spa and fitness centre, and organised boat trips for sports fishing.

Tuscany Inn
22 North water Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 5999, fax 627 6605, email: tuscany@vineyard.net).
$100-395
Perhaps the most beautiful inn on the island, a Tuscan villa style transplanted into a traditional wooden Vineyard cottage. Chic Italian Laura Sbrana presides as guests enjoy frittata, homemade biscotti and strong espresso for breakfast. On some weekends she runs a gastronomic cooking school.

Daggett House
59 North Water Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 4600, fax 627 4611, www.mvweb.com/daggett
$100-155
Built in 1660 as the first tavern on Martha's Vineyard, the Daggett House has some intriguing rooms, including one in the attic reached by a secret passage. It is just off the busy part of Edgartown, overlooking the harbour, and has a fine restaurant.

Charlotte House
27 South Summer Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 458, fax 627 4652, charlotte@relaischateaux)
$200-400
The ultimate address for stars and celebrities to escape the crowds, the Charlotte Inn is a beautifully restored white clapboard house, whose opulent interiors resemble an English country manor.

The Colonial Inn
North Water Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 4711, fax 627 5904, www.colonialinnmvy.com
$100-150
More like a hotel than the island's classic country inns, the turn-of-the-century Colonial Inn is reasonably priced, and there is a delightful top floor terrace for sunset drinks overlooking the harbour of Edgartown.

The Edgartown Inn
56 North Water Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 4794, fax 693 9420, www.edgartowninn.com).
$70-120
Built 200 years ago as a whaling captain's residence, this charming inn retains the feel of a private home. The living room is filled with sailing mementos or the snug kitchen with checked tablecloths and vases of freshly cut flowers

The Oak House
 Seaview Avenue, Oak Bluffs (00 1 508 693 4187, fax 696 7385, www.vineyard.net/inns).
$120-180
A spectacular wooden mansion overlooking the ocean and sandy beach at Oak Bluffs, this is slightly expensive, but each room is individually decorated in quaint, kitsch style. Lovely seaview porch with rattan rocking chairs.

The Oak Bluffs Inn
 Pequot Avenue, Oak Bluffs (00 1 508 693 7171, fax 693 8787, bmyguest@oakbluffsinn.com).
$120-150
Recently renovated by a friendly young couple, this picturesque, brightly painted bed and breakfast has nine charming rooms, mixing Victorian style with modern amenities. Looks out over the famous Gingerbread houses of the Tabernacle.

The Ship's Inn
18 Kennebec Avenue, Oak Bluffs (00 1 508 693 2760).
$65-100
On a popular back road, squeezed between a Mexican restaurant and the popular Offshore Ale Brewery, this simple, but comfortable inn offers economical prices, though for once, breakfast is not included in the room rate.

Vineyard Harbor Motel
Beach Road, Vineyard Haven (00 1 508 693 3334, fax 693 0320, www.mvy.com/vharbor).
$65-100
Vineyard Haven may be the most exclusive resort on this island, but it also has some of the cheaper accommodation too, especially this old-fashioned motel with harbour views .

Where to eat and drink

Black Dog Tavern
Beach Street Extension, Vineyard Haven (00 1 508 693 9223).
The most famous bar and restaurant on the Vineyard, where all the celebrities, Bill and Hillary Clinton included, come to hang out and supposedly be ignored by the rest of the summer tourists. So the staff have attitude, and there's a lengthy queue to get a table. But not to be missed.

The Offshore Ale Brewery
 Kennebec Avenue, Oak Bluffs (00 1 508 693 2626).
Best spot on the island, a vast barn whose first floor has been converted into a microbrewery, brewing excellent beer, while the downstairs is an eclectic mix of noisy pub, hearty restaurant and late-night live venue for local blues, funk and rock bands.

Seasons
19 Circuit Avenue, Oak Bluffs (00 1 508 693 7129).
Cheap and friendly bar and restaurant where the portions - especially the spare ribs - are enormous. Not the most stylish venue, but good fun. You might even see local resident singer Carly Simon, and friends like Billy Joel, come in to check out the band.

L'Etoile
27 South Summer Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 4751).
Definitely the most fashionable - and expensive - restaurant on Martha's Vineyard. The cuisine is an interesting mix of French, Italian and native American influences, especially dishes featuring pheasant, lobster and crab. If cost is no problem, this is the place to sample some of the finest American wines.

The Newes from America Pub
23 Kelley Street, Edgartown (00 1 508 627 4397).
Many Americans eat early in the evening - even at 5pm - and this packed pub down by the waterfront is one of the few spots serving up until midnight. Classic deli dishes - pastrami on rye, oyster 'po'boy' sandwiches, clam chowder - and they serve lethal cocktails.

Nantucket

Where to stay

Jared Coffin House
29 Broad Street (00 1 508 228 2400, fax 228 8549, jchouse@nantucket.net).
$115-160
This is the leading luxury inn on Nantucket, and also has one of the island's most elegant restaurants. For once, this historic stately home is redbrick rather than wooden, and the 'country inn breakfast' of dishes like eggs benedict or light fish cakes is exceptional. There are 60 rooms in all.

Roberts House
11 India Street (00 1 508 228 0600, fax 325 4046, RHInn@aol.com).
$100-200
The grand white colonial façade of this ancient lodging house, with the US flag flying above the porch, hides a very laid-back place. Covering a whole block, with lovely gardens, the Roberts House consists of four different inns, with different price ranges.

Cliff Lodge
9 Cliff Road (00 1 508 228 9480, www.cliff_lodge.com).
$105-150
A great discovery, this converted 1771 whaling master's home is on a high road out of town with spectacular views over the busy harbour and ocean. Breakfast is served in the flower-filled gardens. Book early - there are only 13 rooms.

The Nesbitt Inn
21 Broad Street (00 1 508 228 0156).
$65-95
The best bargain spot on Nantucket. Run by the homely Dolly Noblit, whose family have owned the inn for a century, the Victorian house is filled with authentic antique furnishings. Just remember that bathrooms are shared and breakfast is 'Continental' rather than hearty 'American'.

Centerboard Guest House
8 Chester Street (00 1 508 228 9696, fax 325 4798, centerbo@nantucket.net).
$110-185
Only six rooms, all beautifully decorated, in this tiny wooden guesthouse just out of the town, must book well in advance.

Periwinkle Guest House
9 North Water Street (00 1 508 228 9267, fax 325 4046, www.oneweb.com/nantucket/).
$75-125
Its wooden walls painted a beautiful pastel yellow, the friendly Periwinkle has a wide range of rooms to suite different budgets, and a smaller cottage next door.It is just behind the Whaling Museum.

Centre Street Inn
78 Centre Street (00 1 508 228 0199, fax 228 8676, inn@nantucket.net).
$75-150
Dating back to 1742, this is one of the oldest houses on Nantucket, perfectly preserved today. The 13 guest rooms cover a wide price range, and there's a lovely summer patio and lounge.

The Inn at Captain's Corner
89 Easton Street (00 1 508 228 1692, captainscorner@nii.net).
$60-100
The Captain's Corner is just five minutes walk away on the outskirts of the main town, which explains its moderate room rates. Feels as if you're really staying in a friendly family home.

Le Languedoc
24 Broad Street (00 1 508 228 4298, fax 228 4682, www.lelanguedoc.com
$60-150
Just as well-known for its gourmet French restaurant as its comfortable rooms, the Languedoc spreads over two adjoining houses, just off the water front.

Martin House Inn
61 Centre Street (00 1 508 228 0678, martinn@nantucket.net).
$65-150
Originally a mariner's home, built in 1804, this romantic spot has grand bedrooms with lace curtains and four-poster canopy beds, and also cosy, lower priced rooms.

Where to eat and drink

Nantucket Tapas
15 South Beach Street (00 1 508 228 2033).
Original designer restaurant on the waterfront, where young chef Terry Noyes creates dishes that mix Spanish tapas with sushi, Chinese wok-fried vegetables with fresh Nantucket seafood - tuna carpaccio, shrimp dim sum, lobster ravioli, steamed clams and mussels, cold smoked scallops.

The Chanticleer
Sconset Village (00 1 508 257 6231).
Hidden in the idyllic village of Sconset, the Chanticleer is in a different league from other island eateries. French chef Jean-Charles Berruet has lived in Nantucket for more than 20 years, and his cuisine attracts the likes of Michael Douglas and Henry Kissinger. In summer, there is the most beautiful flower garden imaginable.

The Brotherhood of Thieves
25 Broad Street (00 1 508 228 2400)
Atmospheric bar echoing the colourful past of Nantucket, serving inexpensive meals. Pretty garden in summer, often with live music at night.

The Tap Room
29 Broad Street.
In the basement of the Jared House, this all-wood tavern could be inside an ancient whaling ship. Tourists sit round dark tables while colourful locals crowd round the long bar, noisily discussing the season's fishing.

Dave's Soda Fountain
 47 Main Street.
Inside the quaint Congdon's Pharmacy, step into America's past with red plastic swivel stools round the old fashioned soda fountain. All of town stops off for morning coffee and a gossip update.

webTitle: An East Coast hotel owner reveals all

fields.headline: An East Coast hotel owner reveals all
fields.standfirst: Maggie White, owner of The Hob Knob Inn, Martha's Vineyard
fields.trailText: Maggie White, owner of The Hob Knob Inn, Martha's Vineyard.
fields.body:
Why Hob Knob Inn?
It was named after my grandparents - my grandmother's initials were H.O.B. - and when we bought the Inn it seemed right to reposition it with a family name. I also had some nice family heirlooms.

So you brought some historical baggage?
Yes. I used to live in Colorado and I also brought 14 head of cattle, which I breed here. The Hob Knob is in Edgartown, which is one of six distinct towns in Martha's Vineyard. It is a traditional old whaling port, and the most pristine town on the island. The architecture is wonderful: the seafront is full of captains' houses and there are walkways on the roofs, called widows' walks, from which the women used to watch their husbands return from whaling trips. The island itself is 28 miles long and seven miles wide and is very rural, like Ireland. The climate at this time of year is like England: cold and wet. The Kennedys, President Clinton and various celebrities have really put Martha's Vineyard on the world map. They come here because it is very private and since the inhabitants are sophisticated and have money they are not going to pester them for autographs.

What about a day out?
I would suggest you rent a Jeep to drive round the island. You could stop for a lunch of fresh steamed lobster in the classic fishing village, Menemsha. Fishing is very popular here: you mainly catch striped bass and bluefish, but further out you can find tuna and shark. The water is so clean that you can't believe you are just off the coast of Boston. Guests can then relax in our spa before going out.

So, what do you recommend?
We just serve breakfast and afternoon tea, but there must be 15 excellent restaurants in Martha's Vineyard. Atria is good, as is Sweet Life Cafe in Oak Bluff. Years ago James Taylor and Carly Simon started the Hot Tin Roof club which has performers from all over the world.

The Hob Knob Inn: 00 1 508 627 9510
Rooms from $100 from 1 November

Atria: 00 1 508 627 5850
Hot Tin Roof: 00 1 508 693 1137
Sweet Life Cafe: 00 1 508 696 0200
Martha's Vineyard Chamber of Commerce

The architecture is wonderful: the seafront is full of captains' houses and there are walkways on the roofs, called widows' walks, from which the women used to watch their husbands return from whaling trips. The island itself is 28 miles long and seven miles wide and is very rural, like Ireland. The climate at this time of year is like England: cold and wet. The Kennedys, President Clinton and various celebrities have really put Martha's Vineyard on the world map. They come here because it is very private and since the inhabitants are sophisticated and have money they are not going to pester them for autographs. What about a day out? I would suggest you rent a Jeep to drive round the island. You could stop for a lunch of fresh steamed lobster in the classic fishing village, Menemsha. Fishing is very popular here: you mainly catch striped bass and bluefish, but further out you can find tuna and shark. The water is so clean that you can't believe you are just off the coast of Boston. Guests can then relax in our spa before going out. So, what do you recommend? We just serve breakfast and afternoon tea, but there must be 15 excellent restaurants in Martha's Vineyard. Atria is good, as is Sweet Life Cafe in Oak Bluff. Years ago James Taylor and Carly Simon started the Hot Tin Roof club which has performers from all over the world. webTitle: Life in a luxury coma

fields.headline: Life in a luxury coma
fields.standfirst: Stephen Bayley, the design guru dubbed last week 'the most opinionated man on earth', turns his beady eye on the Hamptons
fields.trailText: Stephen Bayley, the design guru dubbed last week 'the most opinionated man on earth', turns his beady eye on the Hamptons.
fields.body:
You approach East Hampton from the west, from New York. There are slow trains and, for the endemic rich, their own fast planes - a local form of pollution - but it's part of the ritual to go by road on the atrocious Long Island Expressway. The suffering turns a simple 100-mile journey into a rite of passage for true believers. It's a brutal and unedifying experience: as the traffic swarms out of the sewer-like Midtown Tunnel there are two hours of bottleneck and bad tempered graunching and parping before the surly bonds of NYC let go, releasing the traveller into a landscape of farms, shingle houses and oceanic skies.

Most people go by car, although there is a bus: the famous Hampton Jitney. Only in such an absurd principality of privilege as East Hampton would the logic of inverted snobbismo turn a very ordinary motor coach into cult transport. Paul McCartney was seen getting off recently. Jitney is old Jewish slang for nickel, hence any thing cheap. But that's changed: it's now $43, yet they nicely maintain the ethnic association with a complimentary bag of pretzels to help fill the great vacancies of a journey that follows a perverse reverse migration with Manhattan as the old country, and East Hampton as the beckoning New World.

East Hampton is not a resort, it's a dormitory. So it's a bit like a mirror image Ellis Island, although - it must be said - rather more exclusive. There are few hotels as these would encourage non-members. The Maidstone Arms, smugly claustrophobic in a Home Counties way, is an exception. It was run by Gordon Campbell Gray before he returned to London to create the quintessentially urban hotel, Number One Aldwych. Yet although East Hampton's summer population swells enormously, few of the local property owners holiday there. No, they are in France or Italy leaving $50m houses empty during August. Instead, East Hampton is for weekenders.

An East Hampton weekend goes like this. It begins in Manhattan half way through Friday when Mr Millionaire leaves his Manhattan office in his limo. This takes him to JFK where his Gulfstream jet is waiting for the 15-minute journey to East Hampton Airport where another limo whooshes him to the security of his own property. Once safely on his estate our millionaire changes into shorts, and sits it out on his deck entertain ing other celebrities who have undertaken similar journeys. The socialising complete, the process is repeated in reverse on Monday morning : limo, jet, limo, long trousers. Capitalism refreshes itself and moves on.

This weekending has been going on since the Fifties, when the distinction between 'drifts' and 'bumpkins', as the demotics were uncharitably described, was established. An early drift was abstract expressionist painter Jackson Pollock - Jack the Dripper - who borrowed $5,000 from Peggy Guggenheim to buy a small house on Fireplace Road up in Springs and then gracelessly killed himself in a 1956 drunk car wreck outside the front door. Another aspiring drift was Jimmy Kirkwood, author of A Chorus Line.

Figures like this helped establish an extraordinary reputation for East Hampton, a place different from Eastbourne in the same way that New York is different from London. Each city is big, busy and successful, but only New Yorkers have that insufferable air of self-congratulation. God we're clever to be here! They bring this choking smugness with them to the dorm, making East Hampton perhaps the most self-conscious place on the entire planet. In so doing, they have turned a wince-makingly pretty village into a journalistic obsession: celebrity voyeurism and the appetites of the eccentric rich make great copy. This came to its moment critique in the giddy Eighties when the village was known as Cash Hampton. Hamptonites like playing it down, saying no it's not smart, it's just, like, the place we chill out. We kick back, hang loose, don't care. If only.

This is disingenuous: they love saying, 'You'll never see Steven Spielberg, he's just a regular guy' (with a regular $64m house on West End Road). Although, naturally, they are pleased to be able to tell you this. Artifice and dissimulation are everywhere. People struggle to maintain unnatural gardens: they import things and maintain monsoon sprinklers at Wall Street only knows what cost. If grass won't grow, why not try something else? But the extreme cost of the fastidious gardens is the point: to be effective, conspicuous consumption must tread the line between obscure reticence and vulgar display. Pets have personal trainers. Feel my Saab. Not another Porsche.

The Hamptons is more than one particular village. It's a generic term for the eastern part of Long Island, but there are important qualifications. No one does snobbery quite as well as the Americans and geographic signifiers are very specific: to qualify for membership as a Hamptonite you have to be on the South Fork of the island and, not only that, you have to be south of the very noisy Route 27. Within the Hamptons, there are further nuances. Bridgehampton just about qualifies, but is contaminated by a large shopping mall (Hamptonites much prefer cuteness). Continuing east you get to Sagaponack. Kurt Vonnegut lives here, so this is very smart. Southampton follows. This is old money: Tom Wolfe, always much more a conservative southern gent than a hip new journalist, has a house on South Main Street. Diverting briefly north, there is Sag Harbor with its boaty flavour and annoying shops. Then comes East Hampton, pretty near the centre of the area, the distillation of its essence, and very much new money (even if it was founded by travellers from Kent in the 1640s). Continuing east you come to Amagansett, more rustic, less fraught. Last, at the most oriental extremity of the Island, is Montauk: rougher, wilder and more maritime.

East Hampton operates an exclusion policy. Most obviously, this finds expression in parking. There are no parking garages and, unless you have a resident's permit or are renting for the season, you cannot leave your car for more than two hours. This discriminates against visitors so the Hamptonites have the place to themselves. Compare with St Tropez where anybody bold enough can park his 15-year-old motor-home smack in front of La Pinède at no cost and no risk.

On the streets a sort of communism de luxe operates in a mysteriously orchestrated dress-down operation. Everyone is in shorts. Only the police wear long trousers. Trainers with white socks are universal. While Ralph Lauren's Polo Country store is busy selling used Levi jackets for $595 and paint-spattered Wrangler jeans (Style of Pollock) for $795, people don't wear them. At least, not in public. Instead, the weekend street is both sartorially and socially an extension of the gym, sweaty rich people in athletic apparel mill about or do stretch exercises against trees. It is horrible.

The arrangement of East Hampton's shops is like a diagram of America in the same way as Dante's Circles of Hell was a diagram of late medieval cosmology. On the two main shopping streets, Newtown Lane and Main Street itself, there are modest façades, but cavernous back-of-house operations stuffed with merchandise and staffed by tanned and toned girls or preening preppy boys. Thus the Polo, DKNY and Banana Republic shops are a symbol of East Hampton itself: effacing on the surface, but in substance very showy. Yet this twee perfection gives way a block back to a different sort of retail experience: here white trailer trash, temporarily imported during working hours as gastarbeiten, work in grim copy shops, dry cleaners and liquor stores which would not look out of place in Fort Wayne, Indiana.

The defining shop in East Hampton is, of course, a deli. In this case, The Barefoot Contessa, a continuous cauldron of social activity and you wonder: what sort of strange compulsion to be humiliated makes millionaires wear silly clothes and stand in line for half an hour to buy a coffee? It suddenly becomes evident that one of the biggest distinctions between Europe and the US is America's lack of café life. It is a measure of the suffocating atmosphere that Ina - Barefoot - Garten's plan to put tables on the streets so millionaires can sit down with their lattes is considered revolutionary. The East Hampton Beaches - with their remarkable light, vast extent, clean sand and Atlantic rollers - are among the finest in the world and anywhere else would have charming bars and seafood restaurants. Here they do not. A remarkable transformation takes place when the lifeguards go off duty at five. Slowly and gingerly, like wild animals tentatively emerging from the jungle, 4wds - headlights on even in the sunshine - step on to the beach (permits required!) with the sophisticated load of equipment required for a primitive clambake. Pits are dug. Easy light charcoal is lit. Corn is roasted. Clams are baked. The music plays. Wine is drunk (in flagrant contravention of the prissy East Hampton Village Beach Rules). One Saturday night I saw in quick succession, Salman Rushdie (alarming in shorts), Stella McCartney, Kim Basinger and Christy Turlington.

The houses of the Hamptons are a unique phenomenon: imagine Virginia Water with a magnification of x100. Harper's reports that 0.93 new ones are built every day. The convention among local realtors is that the hierarchy goes cottage, house, estate and, beautifully, an estate becomes a 'compound' if it has guest cabanas. The most sophisticated have up to 12 different heating and air-con zones, so as to complete the entirely hermetic effect the very rich seem to want. Hamptons Online presents the following league table:

Adelaide de Menil, oil heiress, 56 acres on Further Lane: $136m
Carl Icahn, corporate raider, 8 acres on Lily Pond Road: $99m
Bruce Wasserstein, banker, 26 acres on Further Lane: $98m
Lary Gagosian, art dealer, 18 acres on Further Lane: $41m

And the pitiable: Howard Schultz, Starbucks, 4 acres on Lily Pond Lane: $17.5m

East Hampton is irresistibly reminiscent of Ira Levin's 1972 horror classic, The Stepford Wives . From under a surface of fatiguing perfection, terrible currents and tensions threaten to emerge. It is in a luxury coma. Here are the noises of the village, heard solo or in concert: a bizjet on final approach, the thwush-thwush of lawn sprinklers, the bark of an oversized rotary mower handled by a bad tempered Chicano, a strimmer, the rumble of a passing V-8, air-con, the pool pump, a chopper, the penetrating ring of an American phone, a distant television. Here are some of the sights: in the rear view mirror - a matt salmon pink '57 Plymouth Savoy (with roof-mounted surfboard); the car park of the Catholic (ie poor people's) Church egregiously lacking standard-issue luxury 4wds; pale bankers from Paine Webber and Merril Lynch queuing up in the archaic stationery shop to send faxes back to Money HQ; arthritic joggers; parking attendants in day-glo battle fatigues; middle-aged polychromed Lycra-clad Manhattanites over-doing it on carbon-framed racing bikes.

The Pleasantville flawlessness and ease is not comforting, it puts you on edge. East Hampton has none of the gradations, sex and style of Europe: there is only one way to fit in and that is to have lots of money. And even that is not enough: you have to abandon all independent thought and expression. Then, enjoy!

The excess is nauseating and so is the territorialism. When Time Warner's Steve Ross died in 1992 his widow bought 110 burial plots around the grave, so he wouldn't feel crowded. Martha Stewart, a scary mixture of Richard Branson, Terence Conran, Delia Smith and Mr Motivator, who is Earth Mother around here, petulantly abandoned a landmark house project when a neighbour built a fence and threatened intrusion.

There is something infinitely melancholy about being in America, and typical is the haunting, lowing sound of a goods train at night. This you get in the Hamptons as drivers on the quiet Long Island Rail Road respond sympathetically to Hamptonites' sentimental longing for kitsch Americana. No matter how mature US civilization becomes, it never acquires depth. Charles Dickens said in 1834 that it all looked as though it had been built yesterday. Now it just looks as though it was bought yesterday. A vengeful God, cross about complacent consumerism, could do worse than start here.

I expressed my distaste to a frequent English visitor, sitting on the swing chair on the stoop one sunny evening, glass of Sag Pond Chardonnay and $40 cheese straws to hand. He said, 'You're either an East Hampton person or you're a Rome person. You get it or you don't.' I said, 'Ciao.'

 'General Knowledge' by Stephen Bayley is published by Booth-Clibborn Editions, £19.95.
