'So many people have suffered wrongful convictions, the mental scars go deep. 'I have no respect for South Wales police. I hate every one of them. They are given a job to investigate crimes fully. But again and again they had tunnel vision. 'They targeted one person and built a case around them. They convinced themselves someone is guilty and ignored any evidence that points to other perpetrators. That is a strong pattern with all the cases. Yet innocent people, and the victims' families, have their lives ruined.' Wayne Darvell, 35, and his brother Paul were jailed for life for the 1985 murder of Swansea sex shop assistant Sandra Phillips, 38. Wayne had a history of confessing to offences he could not have possibly committed.The pair were cleared in 1992. Three South Wales officers involved in the case were later charged with conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. Tony Paris, Yusef Abdullahi and Stephen Miller were sentenced to life in 1990 for the murder of Cardiff prostitute Lynette White. Two others who were charged spent months in jail on remand before being acquitted at the trial. Investigative author Satish Sekar exposed serious concerns about the police inquiry and the three were released by Court of Appeal judges in 1992. In 1994 Jonathan Jones was convicted of murdering his girlfriend's parents, Harry and Megan Tooze, at their isolated farmhouse. His conviction was ruled 'unsafe' in 1996. 'What took place still has a big influence on my life,' he said. 'All those certainties about honesty and integrity and our police force being the best in the world are shattered.' He believes the campaign for an inquiry may soon succeed. 'It would be difficult for the Home Secretary to ignore a cross-party group of assembly members,' he said. One lawyer told The Observer : 'When you are seeing people walking out of the Court of Appeal on such a regular basis it's got to merit a public inquiry. The legal community here has been very concerned for years about a general attitude of contempt for justice by certain officers, and we all knew who they were.'

webTitle: Coke's Russian invasion fizzles out

fields.headline: Coke's Russian invasion fizzles out
fields.standfirst:
Drinks giant goes native to halt losses as Soviet-era flavours flourish

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Kvas is it - or so beleaguered Coca-Cola executives in Moscow have persuaded themselves.
fields.body:
Kvas is it - or so beleaguered Coca-Cola executives in Moscow have persuaded themselves.

Production lines in Siberia, which once spewed out sparkling fountains of Coke, have been converted to make a new line of traditional Russian soft drinks - like kvas, a cloudy brown, alcohol-free yeast drink flavoured with the peculiar aroma of fermented stale rye bread.

In a reverse of the cultural imperialism of Coca-Cola's aggressive invasion of Russia in the early Nineties, the firm has been forced to make concessions to local demand as it struggles to recoup huge losses in the region.

Last week's announcement of a move into nostalgic Soviet-era drinks marks the business's latest attempt to squeeze a profit out of Russian consumers who are increasingly apathetic towards Coke itself.

In addition to the fizzy, sugary version of kvas already under production, the company's management are reproducing Tarkhun, also a Soviet favourite (and an acquired taste with its electric emerald colour, acrid herbal flavour and strange chemical smell) and Buratino, another old recipe.

The writing on the bottles is in Cyrillic script, pandering to a perceived consumer shift towards Russian-made goods. 'Coca-Cola' is printed in tiny letters by the ingredients.

Inadvertently revealing the issue at the heart of the company's troubles in Russia, a spokeswoman says the new drinks are 'affordable beverages' - which Coke, a 'premium brand', is not.

The venture is a practical response to difficult times. The past 18 months have been unspeakably tough for the company's Russian arm. Staff in the Moscow headquarters are believed to have been cut back to around 35, from 300 in the mid-Nineties. Between 40 and 60 per cent of Coke's workers across Russia have been laid off in 16 months, say company sources.

Russian enthusiasm for Coke has dwindled to such an extent that most of the 11 factories are not working to full capacity. This summer a franchise plant in Voronyezh ceased production of Coke altogether, saying it was far more profitable to make beer.

Six years after the company triumphantly opened its first Russian factory, management is realising that the brand's appeal - perceived from behind the Iron Curtain as a glamorous symbol of Western freedom - has faded.

Moscow's kiosks illustrate the problem. A bewildering variety of bottles are labelled with a bemusing range of prices: 1.5 litres of a black liquid called FanCola costs 9 roubles; a smaller 1.25 litre bottle of Coca-Cola costs more than double that.

A bottle of Russian beer costs the same as a can of Coke and for most Russian teenagers (the target buyers for colas) the choice is simple: with beer you have the added excitement of getting drunk. The beer market has doubled in the past four years.

The company explains that the 'state of the art technology' and the high-quality sugar and water which go into making Coke explain why it is more expensive. But Russia's increasingly sophisticated consumers are no longer infatuated with Western goods as status symbols, and will not pay extra for American colas when Russian ones cost so much less.

No one within the company will confirm what everyone suspects - that after investing around $750 million in the country, Coca-Cola's Russian arm is running at a loss. 'Our initiatives are long term,' a spokesman said.

The reason for Coca-Cola's fortunes in Russia are manifold - the 1998 economic crisis, the growing strength of local products, and the inability of big companies to respond quickly enough to the rapidly changing Russian market.

Initially, the company's attack on Russia went smoothly. Sales rose steadily as huge geographical areas were seized by distributors. Popular Russian drinks like tarkhun and kvas were virtually killed off by Sprite and Fanta. More and more money was invested in ambitious expansion programmes.

The disastrous collapse of the rouble in August 1998 marked a turning point, although problems had emerged earlier.

Consumers were suddenly poorer and sugary drinks not a necessity. Across the board, monthly retail turnover is still far below its pre-1998 levels: in July of this year it stood at $6.5 million, down from $12.7 million in July 1996. As Western firms struggled, Russian rivals fought back - making cheaper drinks. They realised there was money to be made in reviving Russian flavours.

'For a while Coke represented the winds of change in Russia. It was a key investor and the name carried great authority. It no longer does,' a former employee commented. To begin with, Coca-Cola's influence was huge. It sponsored the Bolshoi ballet, the Hermitage, Russia's national football team, the Russian Olympic team; most of these have been cut back.

'Coca-Cola ignored the local market,' he added. 'And it reacted too slowly to change. If we wanted to put a new label on a product, we'd have to wait for permission to come through from Atlanta, which could take six months. By the time permission had come through, Russia's government, its banking system and its President would all have changed.'

Other big manufacturers like Pepsi also suffered from the crash, but responded more quickly. Pepsi has already diversified into kvas-like drinks. There was uncertainty about whether Coca- Cola's new flavours would reverse the company's fortunes. 'If there are problems with the sales of Coke, they should sort those out, not start making something new,' said Greg Thain, a Moscow retail analyst.

But the nostalgia for Soviet tastes has worked for Irn-Bru, which has recently become a surprise success in Russia. 'We discovered that Irn-Bru tastes very like the famous Soviet soft drink, Buratino,' Jerry Labour, the company's director in Moscow, said. 'People picked up on it straight away - and I'm sure it's helped sales.'

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Those old school ties

fields.headline: Those old school ties
fields.trailText: School reunions are little more than a communal explosion of egomania masquerading as affectionate nostalgia. You assume that people want to see you again. You assume that people wanted to see you in the first place.
fields.body:
There is just no pleasing some people. After receiving a tentative email from a 'boy' I went to school with, I instantly and efficiently responded by demanding the contact details of everyone he's kept in touch with, and then firing off 10,000-word epics to all four corners of the globe.

'Let's have a school reunion,' I say. 'Come on, it'll be fun. You find that person, you find the others. Somebody (not me, I'm too busy) should sort out the time and venue, and rustle up some free booze. Look, maybe it would be for the best if everybody (bar me) gave up their jobs temporarily to accommodate my vision of how this reunion should be. I'll just sit here and oversee things. I'll be the mastermind, the boss, the one everyone applauds at the end of the evening with tears of gratitude in their eyes. Yes, yes, nice to hear what you've been up to (all very fascinating if I happened to be your mother). Now do please get a move on, as I'm already excited about my plan, and all the glory coming my way.'

And what I do get for all this effort, all this inspired brainstorming and selfless chivvying? Attitude, that's what I get. Attitude and mutiny.

Of course, I'm into the idea of a reunion. I was drop-dead popular at school. Everyone loved me, everyone thought I was incredibly pretty and clever. I was forever fighting off suitors with hockey sticks and being walked around the sports field by eager young lads with shining eyes and blushing cheeks. Oh no, hang on a minute, that was my friends. But at least I was there when it happened to them. Sometimes, I got to hold their satchels as they counted their valentine cards.

It wasn't my fault I was ugly, or, as local parlance had it, 'grim'. To be honest, it took me a while to notice. That's my advice to 'unpretty' young girls - blithely ignore your physical shortcomings, make ugliness your friend. More importantly, make friends with people who aren't ugly because that way, you spend your life, wading through a sea of boys who'd all like to get to know your friends better. A simple strategy, and not without pathos, but it definitely worked for me.

There's always some people who try to spoil the party. When I spoke of my plan, a friend retorted that school reunions were a cruel bourgeois convention, all the more unkind because certain people might have fallen on hard times - lost their jobs, looks or health, or have just generally been crushed by life. The rest, he seemed to think, would be swanning around, bragging and posing about how well they'd all done, and patronising the masses. All melodramatic rot, if you ask me. We're talking about a Rutland comp, not Gordonstoun.

Moreover, anybody trying to swan around on the back of attending our local sixth-form college (a low-rise monument to the cowboy building industry) would look very foolish indeed. I also take exception to the assumption that people I went to school with would have it in them to be vile braggarts and spiteful bullies. That was always my department. Everyone else seemed pretty nice.

Saying that, I would concede that school reunions are little more than a communal explosion of egomania masquerading as affectionate nostalgia. You assume that people want to see you again. You assume that people wanted to see you in the first place. The fact that you might be forgotten doesn't enter your head. Even considering the possibility is painful - it means that you have to confront your own irrelevance, it means they were lying in It's A Wonderful Life.

Anyway, nothing ventured, nothing gained. So, come on, all you people from Casterton Community and Oakham Sixth Form, do you remember me? Of course you do. After all, who at Casterton could forget myself, Sadie Murdoch, Jeremy Robinson and Sara Parry, taking over the school assembly to explain the nuclear threat: 'Bombs are very bad things [giggle, giggle]. They kill you. And that's not very nice [fidget, hair twiddle]. That's all [tee hee].'

That day, we changed lives. At sixth form, we changed more. It was Tim English, Nick Cook, 'Jock' and Graeme Parsons who discovered that Star Bars tasted really great dunked in hot chocolate. Where are those brave boys now? And where are Kent Cotton, Ali Westwood and, for that matter, Paul Knapman and Sally Brooks? Where are Lizzie, Maxine and Genevieve (no, forget them - too pretty).

The point is, if any of these names mean anything to you, then you should contact me at the address below for the party to end all parties. You might even end up organising it (I really am incredibly busy). The faint-hearted should remember that they can take everything else, but the past belongs to us. We have nothing to lose but our dignity.

webTitle: @large

fields.headline: @large
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText:
Fate untempted
The UK's dotcom companies seem to be shedding their lemming-like characteristics after they shunned Friday the 13th last week. Despite it being results season, not a single new media fledgling reported financial figures. Perhaps they were mindful of the fact that the fickle hand of stock market fate, which is giving them a solid slapping at the moment, needs no encouragement. However, one account manager at a top city PR firm denied any superstitious strategy: 'Everyone's been too busy to notice,' he said... as a grand piano fell on his head from great height.

Fate untempted
The UK's dotcom companies seem to be shedding their lemming-like characteristics after they shunned Friday the 13th last week. Despite it being results season, not a single new media fledgling reported financial figures. Perhaps they were mindful of the fact that the fickle hand of stock market fate, which is giving them a solid slapping at the moment, needs no encouragement. However, one account manager at a top city PR firm denied any superstitious strategy: 'Everyone's been too busy to notice,' he said... as a grand piano fell on his head from great height.

Full Marx
The internet as communist bolthole? This was one of the unlikely conclusions to be drawn from the UK Internet Summit held in London last week. Both Dave Stewart, the musician, and Martin Sorrell, chief executive of WPP, the giant marketing multinational, invoked Karl Marx when discussing the impact of the net. Stewart, one half of now reformed band Eurythmics, said the internet was all about returning the means of production to the workers. Well returning it to those who work as pop stars or ad industry execs. Hardly the dictatorship of the proletariat.

Knicker wars
Despite last week's liquidation of Boxman, @large was delighted to see spasms of life in small internet companies. Surpriseyourwoman.com a smooth, sophisticated, 'Arena-like' website peddles presents for laydeeeez - the Craig David of the business. But it faces a battle with a rough 'n' ready Liam Gallagher of a competitor called Giftsforbirds.com. Class war hits the net again. Except Surpriseyourwoman.com will feature tasteful shots of women in lingerie, just so you can see whether the 'surprise' will look good on your woman. Honestly.

webTitle: Blue-collar Motown is key to victory

fields.headline: Blue-collar Motown is key to victory
fields.standfirst:
Candidates seek make-or-break support from 'Reagan Democrats' of Detroit's car industry, writes Ed Vulliamy

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As dawn breaks, Mack Meyer, clutching his lunch box and with a bellyful of coffee from the all-night drive-thru, stomps reluctantly into the Chrysler assembly plant in North Jefferson, on the edge of Detroit.
fields.body:
As dawn breaks, Mack Meyer, clutching his lunch box and with a bellyful of coffee from the all-night drive-thru, stomps reluctantly into the Chrysler assembly plant in North Jefferson, on the edge of Detroit.

Mack looks the epitome of the downtrodden all-American working man in thrall to the factory whistle. The truth is that he earns $100,000 with overtime, owns two cars and an upstate hunting cabin, and cannot decide whether to vote Democrat - as his union insists he must.

He thinks he'll vote for Bush, 'but I feel kinda bad about it. It's not right for a working man to vote Republican'. But he worries about too much gun control and thinks Bush is 'better on family values and a whole lot better on taxes'.

Mack is what is known as a 'Reagan Democrat', which means he will vote Republican when he thinks the time is right and believes that 'Ronald Reagan knew how to talk to us; he had an empathy for the working man'.

He would have felt very lonely at the headquarters of Local 245 of the United Auto Workers last Wednesday night, in the suburb of Dearborn, the heart of Ford country. Members of the research and engineering branch of the union had gathered here to watch the television debate between Bush and Gore.

Sitting next to his father, Brett McDonald is the latest of three generations to have worked in the Detroit car industry since the Thirties. 'I guess you could say our family's built the finest automobiles the world's ever seen,' says Brett's father, Owen, now retired.

Brett can't understand why everyone is criticising Gore for the last debate. 'He's good when he's fighting, gets angry - that's the man we need. Now, people are saying he's done better this time; but I don't think he's done so good being Mr Nice Guy.

'This election means a lot to us. If Bush wins, that's a disaster for the American workers.'

'Take that silver motherfucking spoon out your mouth!' comes an angry shout from behind, not at McDonald but at Bush on screen.

As polls in America's deadlocked presidential election seesaw to the point of meaninglessness, the mathematics are simple: the presidency rests in the hands of thin slices of voters in a handful of battleground states.

It will be decided by Florida retirees, farmers and suburbanites of Pennsylvania and Missouri, by blue-collar workers in Ohio and by the swing state of Michigan. Both candidates have bombarded that state with advertising and both made a beeline for it as soon as Wednesday's TV debate was over.

Gore arrived in Dearborn to prepare for his rally today in Detroit. Bush was shoring up his stronghold in wealthy Grand Rapids on the rural western side of the state before heading for the car factories of Pontiac, to woo the 'Reagan Democrats'.

US leaders have owed a great deal to Michigan this century; the state has picked the President in every election bar one and come within 1 per cent of national figures for three of the past four. Demographically, the 'Wolverine State' is a mini-America, with inner cities, suburban sprawl and miles of open farmland.

But Michigan's distinguishing feature is that 30 per cent of its 5 million voters live in 'union households'; Michigan's trade unionists are credited with electing Reagan in 1980 and 1984 and Bill Clinton in 1992 and 1996. And of those 1.8 million or so trade unionists, 460,000 belong to the United Auto Workers.

In this razor-edge election, they could swing Michigan either way, putting the state's 18 electoral college votes - and potentially the presidency - in the hands of the UAW.

Motown - capital of the auto trade and the UAW - is a city where past, present and future meet. There is a famous frieze by Mexican artist Diego Rivera in the city art museum, commissioned by the Ford family, expressing the pain and glory of man's relationship with industrial progress and the machine - the history of Detroit and also the story of the US working class.

Nowhere in the Western world is there such a landscape of factories and steel mills - spanning hundreds of square miles and spilling across the river into Canada - through which weave a tangle of railroad tracks and freeways, laden with carriers stacked with cars.

The industry rode the recession (just), not least because of the resources available to the 'Big Three' - Ford, General Motors and Chrysler - and Americans' stubborn taste for their own cars and trucks.

Yet the streets around GM's new downtown headquarters are among America's most decrepit and dangerous. Bricked-up stores, are arraigned like rows of tombstones, bearing names of businesses that have died like 'Sarah's Pretty Nails and Braiding - Human Hair'.

The car factories themselves are flanked by others that are no more than shells of red brick and smashed windows. In places, grass grows through the street tarmac of the great city that gave the world the Ford Mustang and 'Mustang Sally'.

Neither Gore nor Bush will waste time in the slums that line Michigan Avenue, near the abandoned Detroit Tigers baseball stadium. They know that the registered voting populace there is minimal. This is where people like Calvin Williams work, in the lone remaining fried chicken joint on the West 3000 block. Going to vote? 'No sir'. Registered? 'No sir'. Why not? 'Ha Ha! Want some chicken, or what?'

In the UAW's famous local office Russ Leone keeps a copy of Rivera's frieze and walks corridors lined with photos of the hunger marches against the Ford Rouge plant during which five workers were shot dead, of the great strike of 1941, and of Nelson Mandela's recent visit to pay homage to the courage of plant workers past.

Now, Leone admits: 'We've put some of our workers into the top 10 per cent wage bracket. They earn more than $100,000 and think they're capitalists and will vote Republican. Stupid suckers.'

Mack looks the epitome of the downtrodden all-American working man in thrall to the factory whistle. The truth is that he earns $100,000 with overtime, owns two cars and an upstate hunting cabin, and cannot decide whether to vote Democrat - as his union insists he must. He thinks he'll vote for Bush, 'but I feel kinda bad about it. It's not right for a working man to vote Republican'. But he worries about too much gun control and thinks Bush is 'better on family values and a whole lot better on taxes'. Mack is what is known as a 'Reagan Democrat', which means he will vote Republican when he thinks the time is right and believes that 'Ronald Reagan knew how to talk to us; he had an empathy for the working man'. He would have felt very lonely at the headquarters of Local 245 of the United Auto Workers last Wednesday night, in the suburb of Dearborn, the heart of Ford country. Members of the research and engineering branch of the union had gathered here to watch the television debate between Bush and Gore. Sitting next to his father, Brett McDonald is the latest of three generations to have worked in the Detroit car industry since the Thirties. 'I guess you could say our family's built the finest automobiles the world's ever seen,' says Brett's father, Owen, now retired. Brett can't understand why everyone is criticising Gore for the last debate. 'He's good when he's fighting, gets angry - that's the man we need. Now, people are saying he's done better this time; but I don't think he's done so good being Mr Nice Guy. 'This election means a lot to us. If Bush wins, that's a disaster for the American workers.' 'Take that silver motherfucking spoon out your mouth!' comes an angry shout from behind, not at McDonald but at Bush on screen. As polls in America's deadlocked presidential election seesaw to the point of meaninglessness, the mathematics are simple: the presidency rests in the hands of thin slices of voters in a handful of battleground states. It will be decided by Florida retirees, farmers and suburbanites of Pennsylvania and Missouri, by blue-collar workers in Ohio and by the swing state of Michigan. Both candidates have bombarded that state with advertising and both made a beeline for it as soon as Wednesday's TV debate was over. Gore arrived in Dearborn to prepare for his rally today in Detroit. Bush was shoring up his stronghold in wealthy Grand Rapids on the rural western side of the state before heading for the car factories of Pontiac, to woo the 'Reagan Democrats'. US leaders have owed a great deal to Michigan this century; the state has picked the President in every election bar one and come within 1 per cent of national figures for three of the past four. Demographically, the 'Wolverine State' is a mini-America, with inner cities, suburban sprawl and miles of open farmland. But Michigan's distinguishing feature is that 30 per cent of its 5 million voters live in 'union households'; Michigan's trade unionists are credited with electing Reagan in 1980 and 1984 and Bill Clinton in 1992 and 1996. And of those 1.8 million or so trade unionists, 460,000 belong to the United Auto Workers. In this razor-edge election, they could swing Michigan either way, putting the state's 18 electoral college votes - and potentially the presidency - in the hands of the UAW. Motown - capital of the auto trade and the UAW - is a city where past, present and future meet. There is a famous frieze by Mexican artist Diego Rivera in the city art museum, commissioned by the Ford family, expressing the pain and glory of man's relationship with industrial progress and the machine - the history of Detroit and also the story of the US working class. Nowhere in the Western world is there such a landscape of factories and steel mills - spanning hundreds of square miles and spilling across the river into Canada - through which weave a tangle of railroad tracks and freeways, laden with carriers stacked with cars. The industry rode the recession (just), not least because of the resources available to the 'Big Three' - Ford, General Motors and Chrysler - and Americans' stubborn taste for their own cars and trucks. Yet the streets around GM's new downtown headquarters are among America's most decrepit and dangerous. Bricked-up stores, are arraigned like rows of tombstones, bearing names of businesses that have died like 'Sarah's Pretty Nails and Braiding - Human Hair'. The car factories themselves are flanked by others that are no more than shells of red brick and smashed windows. In places, grass grows through the street tarmac of the great city that gave the world the Ford Mustang and 'Mustang Sally'. Neither Gore nor Bush will waste time in the slums that line Michigan Avenue, near the abandoned Detroit Tigers baseball stadium. They know that the registered voting populace there is minimal. This is where people like Calvin Williams work, in the lone remaining fried chicken joint on the West 3000 block. Going to vote? 'No sir'. Registered? 'No sir'. Why not? 'Ha Ha! Want some chicken, or what?' In the UAW's famous local office Russ Leone keeps a copy of Rivera's frieze and walks corridors lined with photos of the hunger marches against the Ford Rouge plant during which five workers were shot dead, of the great strike of 1941, and of Nelson Mandela's recent visit to pay homage to the courage of plant workers past. Now, Leone admits: 'We've put some of our workers into the top 10 per cent wage bracket. They earn more than $100,000 and think they're capitalists and will vote Republican. Stupid suckers.'

webTitle: A club the cyber-subversives wouldn't want to be part of

fields.headline: A club the cyber-subversives wouldn't want to be part of
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The most intriguing question about the internet is whether it will turn out to be a genuinely subversive technology or whether en-trenched power structures - governments, transnational corporations, cultural establishments - will eventually get a grip on it and subvert it to their own ends.
fields.body:
The most intriguing question about the internet is whether it will turn out to be a genuinely subversive technology or whether en-trenched power structures - governments, transnational corporations, cultural establishments - will eventually get a grip on it and subvert it to their own ends.

Cyber-libertarians have never been in any doubt. Their view was summed up in John Gilmore's dictum that 'the internet interprets censorship as damage and routes around it'. Libertarian suspicion of the evil establishments of the 'real' world was tempered by the consoling thought that these institutions were also irredeemably stupid.

The collective IQ of the net was always going to be greater than anything the FBI, GCHQ, Microsoft or the legal profession could muster. And whatever the forces of darkness came up with, the net community could easily circumvent, disrupt or subvert. The balance of power between freedom and control had been irrevocably shifted - and so the internet became a uniquely subversive technology.

In principle, this argument remains valid. The technology of the net, and the fact that software is pure 'thought-stuff', means that the subversive creativity of the internet community cannot be snuffed out. There will always be 16-year-old hackers capable of inventing ingenious mouse-traps which can be distributed globally within minutes. Short of banning the use of computers, shutting down the global telephone network and shooting all 16-year-olds on sight, there is little any authority structure can do about it.

Where the libertarian com munity errs is in thinking that this is all that matters. So long as the internet remained a virtual playground for geeks, Gilmore's mantra did indeed apply. It still does.

But once the net became a mass medium, accessed and used by hundreds of millions of 'ordinary' people and firms - for email, entertainment and commerce - the complacent optimism of the libertarian position began to look like a philosophy of denial.

The difference is that established power structures are able to exert much more leverage on a mass medium than they could on a geek playground. Most internet users now are 'ordinary' folk, who lack both the talent and the motivation to cock a snook at authority. They access the net through internet service providers, companies run by accountants who carry no torches for liberty or anarchy.

And e-commerce companies aspire to the same status: they are after profits, stability, and the protection of their intellectual property. Few of the key players in the mass-internet want trouble with the established order; in a way they want to be part of it.

The Napster case illustrates this. The libertarian position is that it doesn't matter what happens to Napster in the courts because the peer-to-peer (P2P) networking genie is out of the bottle.

This is true but beside the point, which is that the moment somebody runs away with these subversive technologies they become something different - and are suddenly more vulnerable to legal attack.

The thing about Napster, remember, is not so much that it had zillions of users, but that it wanted to become a billion-dollar company on the backs of those users. This is why the recording companies are so interested in it.

'File-sharing means we have to think about a fundamental change of the business model,' Sony's chairman and chief executive told the Financial Times recently.

The companies want to destroy Napster not because they desire to stamp out its disruptive technology, but because they want to deploy it for their own ends.

Who are the real subversives now?

webTitle: Heather Connon: Nasty surprises - tread with care

fields.headline: Nasty surprises - tread with care
fields.trailText: If you believe in omens, start panicking now. The FTSE All-Share index has just fallen for the third quarter in a row for the first time since the great bear market in 1973.
fields.body:
If you believe in omens, start panicking now. The FTSE All-Share index has just fallen for the third quarter in a row for the first time since the great bear market in 1973. Anyone unlucky enough to have had money in shares then will remember that it took 20 years for them to recover their value in real terms.

The FTSE 100 index is roughly where it was in July 1998, its longest sideways spell since the 1987 crash. As Tony Jackson, equity strategist at Charterhouse Securities, points out, it took five years for the markets to recover from that setback.

So should investors be piling out of the stock market? For some it is already too late. Shares in companies such as ICI, Marks & Spencer, Whitbread and British Airways have fallen by between 50 and 75 per cent in the past three years.

If your money is in companies such as Vodafone, Capita, Misys or CMG, you will be wondering what all the fuss is about. These have seen their shares at least double - and, in the case of CMG, rise more than six-fold - in the past two years. These rises have roughly compensated for the falls in traditional stocks to make it look as if the market has gone nowhere for two years.

There are now worrying signs that the advance of the new economy is faltering. Nasdaq, the US hi-tech market, and Techmark in the UK have both fallen by around a fifth since the start of September. Everyone agreed that the collapse in both markets in April was a sensible correction after a period of irrational exuberance: the fear is that the recent falls represent a gradual realisation that the new economy is not providing the spectacular growth which had been billed. If that view becomes more widespread, the bears warn, the prop that has made the market look steady could disappear. The result could be a crash which makes the bear market of 1987 look tame.

Others are more san guine. They attribute the current declines in technology shares to nervousness following the sharp falls in the spring. Buyers are reluctant to pile into technology stocks until it is clear that the sharp falls in the spring were a one-off.

So far, however, the emphasis has been on unpleasant surprises. Luc- ent, Intel, Apple - all stalwarts of the new economy in the US - have warned that growth will be lower than expected.

Add in fears that telecoms companies, which have powered much of the growth in world markets in the past two years, are borrowing too much, and it is easy to make a bear case for shares.

It would certainly be rash to pile too heavily into the market. Those with cash to invest should drip it in gradually. And careful stock selection is key. Many have burnt their fingers by buying M & S because it is cheap. Look for those which have demonstrated they can succeed, such as Tesco, Capita or Pace Microtechnology.

webTitle: No killing the Napster hydra

fields.headline: No killing the Napster hydra
fields.standfirst:
The internet company may lose to the record industry in court, but others will spring up to take its place, write Nick Paton Walsh and Jamie Doward

Net news
fields.trailText: The internet company may lose to the record industry in court, but others will spring up to take its place, write Nick Paton Walsh and Jamie Doward
fields.body:
David Boies was not having the best of days. It was an August afternoon, and he was in the lounge of a Los Angeles airport, waiting for American Airlines to sort out a flight that had been oversold.

Recognised by his peers as one of the biggest-hitting lawyers in the US, Boies is used to dealing with the foibles of big business. When the US government wanted to take on the corporate behemoth of Microsoft in the anti-trust trial, it hired Boies. And after a few lengthy stints before the judge, he caused the biggest company in the world to consider breaking up.

But he could have been forgiven for thinking this airport delay was just another sign that his luck was turning. His current client, Napster, the internet company that invented a piece of software so powerful it threatened to swamp the world with pirated music, was being sued by the Record Industry Association of America (RIAA).

The case was not going well. Boies had lost the first court battle, and, with this huge challenge in the balance, he was stuck in a departure lounge. The flight was blighted by one mechanical problem after another, and they were paying people not to board.

Once finally on the plane, Boies became aware of a man repeatedly turning to look at him. Eventually, the stranger asked: 'Hey, aren't you the Napster lawyer?' Boies assented, and then his inquisitor stood up and announced: 'Napster's lawyer is on the plane.' A cheer rose among the tired crowd of passengers. For the first time that day, perhaps, Boies knew that, even if not in the legal sense, he was backing the winning side.

The court battle between the reactionary RIAA and the copyright-insolent Napster is set to reach its climax within the next couple of weeks. Whichever way the judgment goes, though, Boies's airborne experience is as clear a sign as any that the war is already lost for the RIAA.

Three things are clear about Napster. The first is that it lets anyone copy and share MP3 files - files that use special compression techniques to digitise music so that it can be downloaded over the internet - with alarming ease and at virtually no cost. The second is that many of these duplications or 'exchanges' break time-honoured copyright rules, the laws that ensured the artists got their royalties when the record company sold their music. The third is that people love it. More than 35 million people are now fully fledged converts to the church of Napster. And, after years of paying through the nose for CDs, they don't mind breaking the law to visit it.

It has divided some of the biggest names in the music world. Anti-Napster band Metallica have criticised their fans for enjoying the service too much. The Corrs are also in the anti-Napster camp. Radiohead, however, were far more sanguine when their latest album, Kid A , popped up on Napster prior to its massively hyped launch. Perhaps Radiohead's stoicism is the best way to deal with Napster.

The court case may eventually force Napster to shut down, but it has spawned a host of imitators who are not going to disappear. In fact, the International Federation of Phonographic Industries estimates that there are currently at least 25 million illegal music files on the internet, producing up to 5 million downloads every year.

Take Gnutella, for example. Gnutella is basically the internet's answer to Frankenstein's monster. It was developed as an unofficial project by a team of programmers at America Online who released it onto their website in March, only to realise the consequences of what they were doing and shut it down 24 hours later.

Too late: the Gnutella code was out in the wild wild web and significantly it was a serious improvement on Napster. Unlike its predecessor, Gnutella doesn't have a central data base. This is crucial. Napster's central catalogue of music directs users to various sites where they can download records of their choice. Gnutella, however, constructs a labyrinth of virtual private networks which means there is no one point of reference - making it almost impossible for the music industry to kill it via legal action.

'There's no one body hosting the index, so there's nobody the industry can sue. It's extremely difficult to prevent Gnutella from existing,' said Jay Marathe, head of consulting with technology investment firm Durlacher.

Significantly, Napster, too, is using the index argument as a defence. The company no longer pools music on a centralised database, only directions as to where to find different artists located on various servers in cyberspace. Napster's critics, however, argue that this index is clearly designed to enable people to pirate music.

The music industry is not the only business sector that is watching the Napster case with great interest. Scour.net and DIVX, two daring deviants to Napster which allow users to download film and video clips, are currently attracting an enormous following.

The music industry now tacitly accepts that, if Boies has to retire a beaten man, another Napster variant is likely to spring up and take over the mantle. In a sign of weary recognition, Paul Russell, head of Sony Music Europe, conceded that it would be possible to accept the likes of Napster - if it used its online advertising revenues to pay and promote artists.

'If they came along and said, "We are smarter than you. We are going to sign up artists and we are going to invest in their careers and we are going to put their music up and invest in their careers" I could live with that,' Russell said earlier this year.

But the real challenge for the record labels is to create a viable online alternative to the likes of Napster which, while never being able to kill online piracy, will prevent it from dominating the industry.

The future is not totally gloomy. After all, the record able audio cassette didn't kill the LP or the CD. For similar reasons the online pirates might not end up ruining the music industry.

'At present it's very difficult to find the tracks that you want using Napster. It's often very slow, the names of the artists are sometimes wrong, it sends you to hard drives that are not that reliable. If I wanted to create my own compilation of tracks it's a long, hard slog. If the music industry could offer these sort of improved services, I believe that people would be willing to pay for the service,' Marathe said.

But so far the music industry has been slow to react, choosing simply to swat the pirates with legal action. This is not a viable strategy for the future. The major record labels know that, whatever the Napster court case ruling, the judgment will ultimately change nothing. Other sites will always spring up to take its place.

It may well be that Napster is heading for an early demise. So what? Long live Napster.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Gene row victors face compassion test

fields.headline: Gene row victors face compassion test
fields.trailText: Insurers may be smarting from the endowments scandal, but overall the industry must be feeling smug about its tussles with consumers and the Government.
fields.body:
Insurers may be smarting from unhappy homeowners' refusal to be cowed over the endowments scandal, but overall the industry must be feeling smug about its tussles with consumers and the Government.

Successful lobbying must have helped to limit the nature of the endowments clean-up, and now insurers are getting their own way over genetic testing. They have the Government's blessing to demand that customers tell them the results of the first of what is likely to become a string of genetic tests.

The insurers, of course, are keen to put forward the idea that someone who can show a negative result will be able to get cover without difficulty. True, but it is ques tionable that this will be a sustained advantage to potential sufferers of hereditary illnesses because those who have not already had tests may be deterred from doing so.

A delicious irony would be to see genetic testing become so widespread that companies destroyed their market by rejecting virtually all potential customers, but we are a long way from that. The insurers must now prove themselves worthy of their latest lobbying victory by seeking ways to insure individuals with risky genetic backgrounds at reasonable rates, and dealing with them sensitively.

If they are unwilling or unable to do so, they must make this clear so that alternative forms of protection, perhaps backed by the Government, can be set up.

Start an early New Year's resolution list with the words, 'change bank'. From January the banks will streamline systems for switching accounts, and Halifax plans a high-paying current account.

Consumers can finally shake the monopoly of the high street dinosaurs.
fields.bodyText: Insurers may be smarting from unhappy homeowners' refusal to be cowed over the endowments scandal, but overall the industry must be feeling smug about its tussles with consumers and the Government. Successful lobbying must have helped to limit the nature of the endowments clean-up, and now insurers are getting their own way over genetic testing. They have the Government's blessing to demand that customers tell them the results of the first of what is likely to become a string of genetic tests. The insurers, of course, are keen to put forward the idea that someone who can show a negative result will be able to get cover without difficulty. True, but it is ques tionable that this will be a sustained advantage to potential sufferers of hereditary illnesses because those who have not already had tests may be deterred from doing so. A delicious irony would be to see genetic testing become so widespread that companies destroyed their market by rejecting virtually all potential customers, but we are a long way from that. The insurers must now prove themselves worthy of their latest lobbying victory by seeking ways to insure individuals with risky genetic backgrounds at reasonable rates, and dealing with them sensitively. If they are unwilling or unable to do so, they must make this clear so that alternative forms of protection, perhaps backed by the Government, can be set up. Start an early New Year's resolution list with the words, 'change bank'. From January the banks will streamline systems for switching accounts, and Halifax plans a high-paying current account. Consumers can finally shake the monopoly of the high street dinosaurs.

webTitle: Phil Hogan: Below the black belt

fields.headline: Below the black belt
fields.trailText: I've got nothing against forking out for karate lessons twice a week, but I'd like to know which enlightened master of the ancient practice of timetabling thought it would be such an excellent idea to hold the yellow-belt exams right in the middle of Football Focus.
fields.body:
I've got nothing against forking out a sumo wrestler's weight in yen for three sets of karate lessons twice a week, because God knows we could do with a bit of Oriental-style inner harmony and mental discipline with seaweed fritters around here, but I'd like to know which enlightened master of the ancient practice of timetabling thought it would be such an excellent idea to hold the yellow-belt exams right in the middle of Football Focus, which by amazing good fortune happens to be the exact time my wife has arranged with her diary to unavoidably pop into town to look in some shop windows and eat cakes at the Jolly Teapot.

Still, I am nothing if not Zen-like in the face of the day panning out in a less leisure-oriented way than expected, so pausing only to pack a nutritious hydrogenated-oils-and-chocolate-based lunch for the little one, off we go, me settling for the shipping forecast on the car radio while my raucous trio of red belts discuss textbook lunging techniques and the ritual preparation of Japanese poison blowfish as demonstrated on The Simpsons, activities that it seems can only be properly illustrated by ejaculating loudly (think samurai lottery winner) and waving your arms about in the rear-view mirror of a blood relative.

Needless to say, the community centre is nowhere to be found until we have driven past it the three times required by the law of not being very observant, but eventually we're in the waiting room with the rest of the under-12s in their traditional white straitjacket and pyjama bottoms taking advantage of being allowed to throw kicks at each other without being clipped round the ear by a responsible adult.

At last we file in. I find a seat at the back with the little one while the red belts sit on the floor being drilled by Sensei Tony, who, already bilingual in English and Essex, is no slouch at unexpectedly breaking into Japanese should the need arise. And it does, the first exercise being stretching and grunting, followed by everyone being required to go to the toilet at the same time with particular reference to remembering to bow as they exit backwards en masse through the one rather small doorway. Afterwards they split into groups to be graded.

The first four step forward.

'Yoi!' barks Sensei Tony.

'To-shiba,' they reply in unison, thrusting their fists ahead, piston-like. 'Su-shi!' The little one leaps to his feet. 'STOP SHOUTING,' he bellows. I wrestle him back to his chair. Yes, I could take a hundred years to explain the declamatory idiosyncrasies of Wado Ryu (Way of Peace) combat procedure but it seems quicker just to give him his Milky Way and get him to draw circles, an activity recently voted by readers of Negligent Parent magazine as the ideal mindless task for any occasion involving choreographed noise.

Meanwhile the Way of Peace is proceeding with a front punch and head block. 'Mitsu-BISHI!' They await further instructions in the attitude of persons engaged in synchronised defecation.

'Ukulele,' says Sensei Tony, which means 'stamp swiftly on one's imaginary opponent's toe'. They stamp, bow and return to their positions.

Now, my own little trio steps out, front-kicking and snap-punching and barking, coincidentally using the same tried-and-tested methods as they use to get into the car. 'YOKO-ugggh!' they shout in unison. It's nice to see them agreeing about something, not to mention using hand-eye coordination for something other than emptying the biscuit tin.

It seems only hours later that we are collecting certificates of distinction and happily forking out money for new belts in exchange for being allowed to go home. I manage to find the little one out in the waiting room, so we head off, the other three already elbow-strikeback-fisting and lower-body-sweeping their way to the carpark. Ah, how much longer before they can sit on a beach waiting for someone to come along and kick sand in their face?

We get home, where my wife is ready to complete the second part of today's programme of multicultural experiences by having us drive all the way out to Ikea to buy some some knives and forks that match and spend the rest of our lives in the queue trying to get back out again.

Ah well, 'Smorgasbjorn birchveneerfloorung tecnik,' as the old Swedish proverb has it.

webTitle: The big issue

fields.headline: The big issue
fields.trailText: I am one of those who willingly accepts the social contract - I give the Government a proportion of my income and that is held in trust to provide me with the services I cannot provide for myself. This has always seemed a fair exchange.
fields.body:
I am one of those who willingly accepts the social contract - I give the Government a proportion of my income and that is held in trust to provide me with the services I cannot provide for myself. This has always seemed a fair exchange.

Now I find that the Government is using the money I give it to produce an advertising campaign telling me how to spend the proportion of my income which I keep (News, last week). How dare they? It is absolutely up to me to decide whether to make charitable donations, and if I decide to, how I do it. If I feel like giving cash to a desperate, needy individual in London's West End that is my choice. I may even know that he or she will spend that money on drugs - and that is my choice, too. Who knows, maybe I am helping reduce crime by giving cash to an addict as he or she will have less need to steal, for that day at least. This attempt to manipulate my behaviour is patronising arrogance.

Carol Harding
Brentwood, Essex

Whereas we would all wish to see the homeless housed, I am astonished by Government fanaticism with respect to begging. Without going into the 'genuine case' argument, for me, when I hand over change to someone in need, at least I know that 100 per cent of it is to be used by that person. I know that it is not going to a bank for service charges, to an advertising campaign or to keeping a well-housed director of some project, however well intentioned, in post.

Ray Sirotkin
London, SE4

The Government wants to encourage people to give to charities - rather than to homeless people on the streets. It could lead by example - ensuring more funding goes to 'good causes' nationally (instead of diverting Lottery cash to statutory schemes), and enabling more grants for charities locally (by increasing local government funding). Urging individuals to give to charity is not enough to support homeless people if it simply fills gaps left by other funding shortfalls.

John Nicholson
Chief Executive, UK Public Health Association
Manchester

How apt that a campaign to discourage charity towards people who go out on to the streets to ask for it is being launched at the same time as Gordon Brown is considering a massive subsidy to road hauliers because they went out on to the streets and asked for it (Business, last week).

There has been substantial public opposition to increasing road freight for many years because of the environmental damage it causes both locally and globally, but this is all going to be forgotten because of a few days of unofficial industrial action. Once again the Government is attentive to industry and deaf to the public.

Martin Juckes
Oxford

webTitle: Extra tuition

fields.headline: Extra tuition
fields.trailText: You say (Leader Comment, last week) that the recently published performance indicators from the Higher Education Funding Council show that 'the introduction of tuition fees' is having a 'devastating effect' on student drop-out rates.
fields.body:
You say (Leader Comment, last week) that the recently published performance indicators from the Higher Education Funding Council show that 'the introduction of tuition fees' is having a 'devastating effect' on student drop-out rates.

Not so. Figures published last week relate to students starting courses in 1997, before tuition fees were brought in. Our policies ensure that from next year, 50 per cent of students will not pay tuition fees. And since 1998, new students have been taking out loans with repayment linked to ability to pay and collected through the Inland Revenue.

Tessa Blackstone
Department for Education and Employment
London, SW1

webTitle: Law goes online

fields.headline: Law goes online
fields.trailText: Solicitors don't deserve to be criticised over house buying (Cash, last week). The Law Society, representing over 90,000 solicitors in England and Wales, played a constructive part in a consortium bid led by Macdonald Dettwiler and Associates Ltd which resulted in the licence for the electronic delivery of land ownership   information in England and Wales being awarded.
fields.body:
Solicitors don't deserve to be criticised over house buying (Cash, last week). The Law Society, representing over 90,000 solicitors in England and Wales, played a constructive part in a consortium bid led by Macdonald Dettwiler and Associates Ltd which resulted in the licence for the electronic delivery of land ownership information in England and Wales being awarded.

This will mean that a comprehensive online National Land Information Service throughout England and Wales will soon be available. Solicitors will be able to exchange documents online, on secure pages, as well as conducting property and land searches throughout England and Wales.

Michael Napier
President of the Law Society for England and Wales
London, WC2

webTitle: Time to define teacher's role

fields.headline: Time to define teacher's role
fields.trailText: I am a highly qualified, enthusiastic and dedicated 26-year-old teacher of French and Russian. I have taught hockey, netball, dance and trampolining, choreographed a school play and lent my energy, goodwill and time to a range of projects in my career.
fields.body:
I am a highly qualified, enthusiastic and dedicated 26-year-old teacher of French and Russian. I have taught hockey, netball, dance and trampolining, choreographed a school play and lent my energy, goodwill and time to a range of projects in my career.

Performance arts have indeed been pushed to the margins of the curriculum (News, last week) by ever more rigorous and demanding systems and initiatives that leave children and teachers alike with decreasing time allowances. That is not to say, however, that performance arts are no longer in evidence in schools. It's just that they are now squeezed out of the school day and done on an unpaid, voluntary basis.

I am fully in favour of wider access to the arts for all children but wonder why this new burden, along with the welfare, morality and academic development and the exclusive responsibility for pupil achievement, should be laid at the door of the beleaguered teaching profession? Schools achieve miracles with the time and the budgets they have. But it would pay to remember that putting on the school musical is not part of the job description.

Just what exactly are schools supposed to be for these days? It is time that we were all given a public definition of what a teacher is and does. Perhaps then we could actually be given some recognition for doing it. I despair, not of my stimulating, varied and rewarding job, but of the current trend to find something new that teachers aren't doing in the 24-hour day and slag us all off for that.

H. Powell
Bristol

webTitle: Anarchist agenda

fields.headline: Anarchist agenda
fields.trailText: We all know the media connive in denigrating the only serious (and growing) political opposition to self-destructive capitalism when all else has been tried and found wanting. Michael Yates (Letters, last week) proclaims the fuel protests were 'the actions of anarchists'. This is a blatant misrepresentation of the real facts. We are not aware of even a single anarchist in any of the demonstrations, nationwide. Mr Yates would do better to look to the fascistically-inclined, so-called Countryside Alliance for his 'anti-democrats'. No genuine anarchist would stand alongside that lot.

fields.headline: Polite response
fields.trailText: So Kate Kellaway thinks that politeness is 'unmemorable', unlike rudeness (Comment, last week). Hasn't she heard of Sir Philip Sidney's action, when dying on the battlefield, of offering his cup of water to another dying man? And as for rudeness as 'integrity': isn't it often just an offloading of malice, spleen, viciousness? You might just as well praise the 'integrity' of domestic violence.

Both are revered, rightly or wrongly, by sections of their communities, yet only one served the full prison term handed down by a vindictive system. Isn't it time we put things into perspective?

webTitle: Tokyo police discover home sex videos at house of Lucie suspect

fields.headline: Tokyo police discover home sex videos at house of Lucie suspect
fields.trailText: The Japanese businessman who is being questioned about the disappearance of a British woman, Lucie Blackman, kept a large collection of videos showing him having sex with blonde Western women, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The Japanese businessman who is being questioned about the disappearance of a British woman, Lucie Blackman, kept a large collection of videos showing him having sex with blonde Western women, it emerged yesterday.

Tokyo police discovered the videos at the house of Joji Ohara, the 48-year-old estate agent who was arrested on Thursday on suspicion of drugging and sexually assaulting a Canadian bar hostess four years ago.

Detectives believe that Ohara may also be involved in the suspected abduction of Blackman, who was working as a bar hostess in the same Roppongi district of Tokyo when she went missing.

Police have searched 20 of his properties and dug up the garden of his home in Denenchofu, in south-western Tokyo. They have discovered more than 40 videos that Ohara appears to have taken of himself having intercourse with blondes. According to the Japanese media, some of the videos were of a violent nature.

Detectives have also found a bottle of sleeping medicine at the suspect's beachside apartment in Zushi, Kanagawa. According to the media in Japan, at least five foreign hostesses have reported being drugged and assaulted in the Kanagawa area, which is about an hour's drive from Tokyo.

On the day that Blackman went missing, she telephoned a friend to say she was going to the seaside with a customer. According to sources close to the investigation, that call has been traced to a mobile phone owned by Ohara.

Ohara, who has dismissed the charges as 'groundless', was reportedly a well-known face at the foreign hostess bars in Roppongi, including the Casablanca, where Blackman, a former British Airways flight attendant from Kent, worked.

Although he used a number of pseudonyms, such as Honda and Iwasaki, he was known for wearing Armani suits and spending freely.

He also spoke fluent English, having spent three years in the United States.

Several hostesses have reportedly been invited by him to 'go and see the sea'. It would have been an impressive drive: Ohara owned a Ferrari, a Porsche and a Mercedes-Benz.

Police have yet to make an official comment on the case. Yesterday they concentrated their search at a resort apartment in Miura city, Kanagawa.

He also spoke fluent English, having spent three years in the United States. Several hostesses have reportedly been invited by him to 'go and see the sea'. It would have been an impressive drive: Ohara owned a Ferrari, a Porsche and a Mercedes-Benz. Police have yet to make an official comment on the case. Yesterday they concentrated their search at a resort apartment in Miura city, Kanagawa.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: 50,000 women in protest
fields.body:
50,000 women in protest

Up to 50,000 women took to the streets of Brussels yesterday to protest against violence, poverty and inequality. The demonstrators claimed that 80 per cent of Europe's poor were women and children and handed a petition to Employment Commissioner Anna Diamantopoulou calling for action.

Similar protests around the world will culminate in a meeting outside the United Nations building in New York on Tuesday.

Fresh fears over IRA truce

Fresh doubts were raised over the IRA ceasefire amid claims that the terrorists murdered a leading republican dissident in Northern Ireland. Unionist MP Jeffrey Donaldson and the mother of the victim said there was evidence that the Provisionals shot Joseph O'Connor in Belfast.

Why did the chickens..?

A flock of chickens will be allowed to remain on their roundabout home in Ditchingham, Norfolk, after councillors decided they did not pose a traffic hazard. Chickens have lived on the site, a former meadow, for 50 years and locals were furious when the parish council called for their eviction on safety grounds. Some villagers are now demanding signs to warn motorists of the flock's presence.

Death probe at hospital

Health Secretary Alan Milburn has ordered an urgent investigation into heart and lung transplants at St George's Hospital in Tooting, south London, after the death rate among patients rose to more than 80 per cent.

The hospital has suspended all heart and lung transplants until further notice.

Sailor killed on nuclear sub

An English sailor died while working on the nuclear submarine HMS Vengeance, it emerged today. Steven Somerville died in an accident at the American submarine base at Kings Bay, Georgia, a MoD spokesman confirmed. The operator mechanic and married father-of-one is believed to have fallen down a 40ft missile shaft while carrying out routine duties on the submarine on 7 October.

Babies swapped

A hospital in Sicily confirmed that two girls now aged two had been swapped at birth and were being raised by the wrong parents. The hospital blamed understaffing on New Year's Day for the confusion.

The two families know each other and the girls play together. The families have not yet decided what to do.

Prosecutors announced an investigation into the error on Friday.

webTitle: Power list reflects business on the rise

fields.headline: Power list reflects business on the rise
fields.trailText: Power can prove short-lived. Currency dealer George Soros, model Naomi Campbell and former British Airways boss Bob Ayling are among those who have dropped out of the latest Observer/Channel 4 Power List. Four of the five highest new entries are businessmen.
fields.body:
Power can prove short-lived. Currency dealer George Soros, model Naomi Campbell and former British Airways boss Bob Ayling are among those who have dropped out of the latest Observer/Channel 4 Power List. Four of the five highest new entries are businessmen.

For the third year running, an expert panel has selected people according to their capacity to 'influence the quality of people's lives, lifestyles and values in Britain today'. Tony Blair is first and Gordon Brown is second.

Six of the other top 10 work in banking or commerce. Steve Case, chairman of AOL Time Warner, has leapt from 59th place last year to fourth, a recognition of his new company's huge power over the world internet business.

Will Hutton, chairman of the Power List panel, said: 'We simply concentrated on the actual influence that people had on our lives in the year 2000. Sometimes that can be ephemeral, sometimes it is longer lasting. Many figures are, inevitably, international.

'We did seriously discuss whether Gordon Brown deserved the No 1 slot. He is the animating intellectual, economic and political force behind New Labour.' Thirty-eight of the top 100 entries now represent national or international businesses. Just one, the Pearson chief executive Marjorie Scardino, is a woman. The Microsoft founder Bill Gates is No 8, Rupert Murdoch is ninth and Sir John Browne, the BP chairman who some accused of helping to orchestrate the fuel crisis, is at No 10.

US Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan is at No 3 and President Bill Clinton is seventh. Wim Duisenburg, president of the European Central Bank, is at No 28.

The BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland disappears from this year's list altogether. Although he was at 71 last year, his influence has waned as he becomes overshadowed by new Director-General Greg Dyke, who is now at 16. Martin McGuinness and Chris Patten, who both played parts in the Northern Ireland peace process, have left the list.

Mr and Mrs David Beckham consolidate their position (59) as the most influential entertainers listed, one place above Prince Charles. However, the disappearance this year of Elton John, Rory Bremner, Naomi Campbell, Ewan MacGregor and Sir Melvyn Bragg will remind them that their power will only last as long as their singing and footballing skills can be sustained.

Former Chancellor Kenneth Clarke, who four years ago was almost as influential as Gordon Brown is today, has dropped out of the Power List altogether as the possibility of his one day leading a moderate Tory party has dissipated. William Hague has risen to 50, from 228, a reflection of the Government's recent uncertain footing. What is remarkable also is that there is only one black or Asian British entry among the 300. This revelation comes a week after the Commission on the Future of Multi-Ethnic Britain warned that ethnic minorities still face widespread prejudice at work.

The sole black entry this year is of the DJs Dreem Team, who are at No 211 in recognition of their huge influence on the music industry and youth tastes. However, as with most entertainers, their presence is likely to be short-lived.

All the other minority ethnic figures in the 2000 Power List are from abroad. They include UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and former South African President Nelson Mandela, who figure in positions 78 and 195.

Lord Parekh, chairman of the commission, said yesterday: 'Sadly, the criteria for selection for the Power List appear to have been correctly applied. In the last half century, black and Asian people have moved from the bottom rung of the hierarchy but their absence in top positions is still very striking.

'It's only when people are at the top in various fields that that are able to shape organisational culture and help others. As a country, we need to take this issue much more seriously than we have done in the past.'

Panel member Tamara Ingram, chief executive of advertising agency Saatchi & Saatchi, said: 'That there are not many people from diverse backgrounds indicates that the new order in Great Britain is still the old order.'

The Power List was selected by a team of seven. Hutton and Ingram were joined by biologist Lewis Wolpert, former Downing Street adviser Lord Powell, style adviser Peter York, Rachel Newsome, editor of cult magazine Dazed & Confused, and Heather Rabbatts, former chief executive of Lambeth council.

Almost 1,000 individuals were rated by each panellist on the basis of their influence on government, culture, the media and business. Highest scorers were those such as the Prime Minister or Murdoch, who are influential in more than one field.

The number of women on this year's list is only 40. This is 13 per cent of the total - up from 11 per cent last year and 9 per cent in 1998. Apart from Scardino and Victoria Beckham, the only other women in the top 100 are Cherie Booth, the Queen, News of the World editor Rebekah Wade and Madonna.

webTitle: On our mettle

fields.headline: On our mettle
fields.trailText: Had Nick Mathiason walked past the Temple 'saloon' (Business, last week), he would have seen for himself the physical transformation now being created by the thousands of new jobs and nearly £200 million of investment flowing into Rotherham in recent years. Five years ago, the borough's population of 257,000 included around 13,000 out of work. Now it's 5,900 and falling. Educational attainment levels have come on in leaps and bounds. Rotherham schools are among the fastest improving in the country. A technological revolution in the South Yorkshire steel industry produces more steel than it did 20 years ago with only a quarter of the workforce.

webTitle: In love? You'll have butterflies in your brain

fields.headline: In love? You'll have butterflies in your brain
fields.trailText: Singers croon that it makes life worth living, poets declare it to be the answer to the human condition. Now scientists have come up with a definition of love: a warm patch near the centre of the brain.
fields.body:
Singers croon that it makes life worth living, poets declare it to be the answer to the human condition. Now scientists have come up with a definition of love: a warm patch near the centre of the brain.

Neurologists found that, when you see your beloved, parts of your brain 'light up'. The heart has nothing to do with it, suggesting St Valentine's Day cards should be emblazoned, not with images of the heart, but of the medial insula.

A study by Professors Semir Zeki and Andreas Bartels of University College, London, to be published in the journal NeuroReport next month, confirms that being in love is physically different from merely liking someone.

Physical effects of this brain activity may account for the traditional sensations associated with love, including euphoria, butterflies in the stomach, love sickness and love addiction.

The team at UCL's Wellcome Department of Cognitive Neurology scanned the brains of 11 women and six men while showing them pictures of their true loves as well as pictures of people who were just good friends.

Measuring the brain's blood flow with 'magnetic resonance imaging' showed regions that were particularly active when people looked at their loved one. The same areas lit up for the participants, who took a lie detector test to establish how honest they were about their affections.

In addition to the medial insular, three other centres were identified as involved in the love process: the anterior cingulate cortex, the caudate nucleus and the putamen. The arrangement of 'hotspots' associated with this emotion is unique, and helps explain the feelings associated with love.

The medial insular, which is associated with all sensory areas of the brain, has a particular link with the gut. 'This could explain why we get butterflies in our stomach,' said Bartels.

The findings could have practical implications: for example, in developing anti-depressant drugs, or by producing the first aphrodisiac to promote love rather than lust.

By isolating the seat of love, the research raises the prospect of a love-detector test. Such a test could have been critical in the case of former Playboy model Anna Nicole Smith, who married nonagenarian billionaire J Howard Marshall II shortly before his death. She insisted the union was based on true love, and was unrelated to the £650m she inherited last month.

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk
