webTitle: Fat's entertainment

fields.headline: Fat's entertainment
fields.standfirst: It's been a squelchy, fleshy week - from Judy Finnigan's bosom to a sitcom set in a slimming club
fields.trailText:
Who Wants To Be A Millionaire ITV
The Frank Skinner Show ITV
The National Television Awards ITV
Fat Friends ITV
The Sopranos C4
Hidden Love C4
Black Books C4
fields.body:
Who Wants To Be A Millionaire ITV
The Frank Skinner Show ITV
The National Television Awards ITV
Fat Friends ITV
The Sopranos C4
Hidden Love C4
Black Books C4

On last Thursday's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, there was a delightfully rounded contestant called Kevin Squelch. I hoped very much that Kevin, who might have got even squelchier under the full glare of the studio lights, would put the Moon, the Earth, Jupiter and the Sun into the ascending order, sizewise, in the fastest time and thus make it into the hot seat, but he didn't.

Shame - Chris Tarrant would surely have enjoyed a Kevin Squelch, the best character Martin Amis never created. And a glance at my local phone directory revealed that he wasn't necessarily a pesudonymous would-be stand-up comedian, either, for here were two more real Squelches a mere postcode away, sandwiched squidgily between a Squarenina and a Squibb.

It's been a very fleshly, slightly squelchy sort of week. I squirmed for Jamie Oliver, a guest on The Frank Skinner Show on Monday night, when the wardrobe door from his childhood bedroom was wheeled on so that Frank could recreate, for a wider audience, the humiliation of Oliver's recent wedding reception, when his dad had done the same thing. The door was daubed with the young Oliver's drawings of Empire State penises and female pudenda imagined from a gynaecological perspective. 'You bastard,' muttered the Naked Chef, pinkly, struggling to retain his cool as Skinner refused to let it lie. Oliver's face said it all: I wonder what Sainsbury's will think . It wasn't very funny, but then Skinner rarely is.

And then, of course, there came the squelchiest moment of the television week, year, decade, millennium, whatever. I had dutifully tuned in to The National Television Awards, because it was live and one could only hope that Michael Barrymore might get even more tired and emotional than he had last year... but Judy Finnigan accidentally flashing her foundations?

This is the kind of event that TV critics think they dream of, except that when it happens, in all its awesome cringefulness, there isn't much to say aside from 'Bra! Blimey! On live TV! Didn't she handle it like a trouper?!' - and everybody has been saying that all week so I hardly need bother.

'You've got a place in TV history now,' observed guest Phill Jupitus on Wednesday's This Morning . Sobering news for Judy that, despite a hugely successful TV career, this was probably her defining professional moment and when it comes to the obituary it will be her breasts that bear the burden of her celebrity.

On Thursday, right after Kevin Squelch, we had Kay Mellor's new comedy drama, Fat Friends. Earlier in the day, a magazine survey of 5,000 women had revealed that one in 100 women is satisfied with her body (as many as that? Who did they interview - supermodels?) and that 85 per cent admit they worry about their body every day (could be worse, I suppose. Could be 95 per cent worrying every hour, on the hour), so I think Kay Mellor will find her audience.

Set among the members of a northern slimming club run by diet guru Julia Fleshman (a slightly overwrought Josie Lawrence), the show wasted no time setting its agenda: Fat May Be A Feminist Issue, But If It's On ITV At 9pm It's Still Quite Funny. Alison Steadman, as Betty Simpson, had lost five-and-a-half stone on the Fleshman diet and was up for a regional slimmer of the year award. 'I bet you feel like a different person!' she was asked. 'Yeah, she used to be happy and always laughing and now she's a bloody misery!' interjected her size-22 daughter, Kelly (Ruth Jones). Kelly was very big, but - hurrah! - happy with her body, though still attempting to fit into a wedding dress two sizes too small (to the skinny, disapproving shop assistant: 'Don't suppose you get much call for fat girls getting wed'), while Betty thought being thinner would change her life but, confusingly, her husband treated her exactly the same as he ever had.

Mellor gives good one-liners: 'She's been up and down that many times her fat thinks it's got déjà vu ' and 'If I'm ever on a life-support machine, don't turn it off until I'm a size 10', but the plot swiftly sacrificed anything it might have craved to say about rampant body fascism, or women's warped self-esteem, for out-and-out prime-time, feel-good ratings-grabbing sentimentality. It will be an enormous hit, even without Dawn French.

The first episode of the long-awaited second series of The Sopranos opened with an elegiac series of vignettes revealing that Tony Soprano's stomach is spreading comfortably, his midlife crisis is still in full swing (conducted by Nelson Riddle) and he remains overly nostalgic for the days when a man could slip unselfconsciously into a pair of two-tone brogues, polish off a business rival, sleep with a mighty beautiful woman and down three martinis, all before lunch.

The series kicked off not with a bang, but with that dangerously sentimental Sinatra croon - 'When I was 35/ It was a very good year/ For blue-blooded girls of independent means/ We'd ride in limousines (etc)...' - so it was a good few minutes before the first shockingly cold-blooded execution and wincingly gratuitous beating, by which time I was leafing through my vinyl in search of Sinatra's Songs for Swingin' Lovers while Tony was suffering from paranoid delusions and panic attacks, or perhaps indigestion. Brilliant, brutal business as usual in New Jersey, then.

Despite the violence, The Sopranos couldn't compete with the week's scariest programme, Hidden Love. 'Living in a world totally bereft of intimacy and closeness is for most of us intolerable and a small number of people move into delusion,' we were told. A small number? I don't think I know anybody who hasn't teetered close to the edge of De Clerambault's syndrome, which is when ordinary, lovesick souls make the leap to become obsessive, fixated stalkers: erotomaniacs. As Ian McEwan, who wrote about the subject in his novel Enduring Love, observed: '[De Clerambault's] just turned the heat up under a number of things that were common to all of us.' In other words, the truly scary thing about the illness is the thinness of the line that separates the near- madness of ordinary, acceptable lovesickness from the sheer madness of obsession.

Trevor is the star of his own Play Misty For Me , fixated on a radio DJ whom he believes loves him and sends messages via her show. But while Trevor is obviously, recognisably and sadly disurbed, fellow-sufferer Karen was somehow even more unsettling because she looked and sounded perfectly normal even when she was saying, earnestly: 'There's an affinity between us', of a man she has seen only once, nine years ago. Caught in a world they see as riddled with signs and portents, the tiniest of coincidences (car number plates, overheard conversations) are all fuel for the un-extinguishable flames of obsessively unrequited love, even when court orders are in place and prison terms are being served.

But then something odd happens - a weird coincidence, A Sign - and you find yourself suddenly sucked into A Syndrome. It happened to me while watching Black Books, the funniest programme on TV. I nearly wrote about it last week and the week before but, for some reason, I waited. Now I know why. Now I know that its star, Dylan Moran, is trying to tell me that, yes, he loves me as much as I love him, maybe even more, despite the obstacles that stand in our way - which include not having met, stuff like that.

Last week's painfully hilarious episode (Plot? Oh, if you must: a £7,000 bottle of Bordeaux, destined for the Pope but drunk in error by Moran and sidekick, Bill Bailey) finished with Moran reading The Observer. I'm not stupid, Dylan. You don't imagine I'd miss A Sign as blindingly obvious as that, do you? Do you...?

Could be 95 per cent worrying every hour, on the hour), so I think Kay Mellor will find her audience. Set among the members of a northern slimming club run by diet guru Julia Fleshman (a slightly overwrought Josie Lawrence), the show wasted no time setting its agenda: Fat May Be A Feminist Issue, But If It's On ITV At 9pm It's Still Quite Funny. Alison Steadman, as Betty Simpson, had lost five-and-a-half stone on the Fleshman diet and was up for a regional slimmer of the year award. 'I bet you feel like a different person!' she was asked. 'Yeah, she used to be happy and always laughing and now she's a bloody misery!' interjected her size-22 daughter, Kelly (Ruth Jones). Kelly was very big, but - hurrah! - happy with her body, though still attempting to fit into a wedding dress two sizes too small (to the skinny, disapproving shop assistant: 'Don't suppose you get much call for fat girls getting wed'), while Betty thought being thinner would change her life but, confusingly, her husband treated her exactly the same as he ever had. Mellor gives good one-liners: 'She's been up and down that many times her fat thinks it's got déjà vu ' and 'If I'm ever on a life-support machine, don't turn it off until I'm a size 10', but the plot swiftly sacrificed anything it might have craved to say about rampant body fascism, or women's warped self-esteem, for out-and-out prime-time, feel-good ratings-grabbing sentimentality. It will be an enormous hit, even without Dawn French. The first episode of the long-awaited second series of The Sopranos opened with an elegiac series of vignettes revealing that Tony Soprano's stomach is spreading comfortably, his midlife crisis is still in full swing (conducted by Nelson Riddle) and he remains overly nostalgic for the days when a man could slip unselfconsciously into a pair of two-tone brogues, polish off a business rival, sleep with a mighty beautiful woman and down three martinis, all before lunch. The series kicked off not with a bang, but with that dangerously sentimental Sinatra croon - 'When I was 35/ It was a very good year/ For blue-blooded girls of independent means/ We'd ride in limousines (etc)...' - so it was a good few minutes before the first shockingly cold-blooded execution and wincingly gratuitous beating, by which time I was leafing through my vinyl in search of Sinatra's Songs for Swingin' Lovers while Tony was suffering from paranoid delusions and panic attacks, or perhaps indigestion. Brilliant, brutal business as usual in New Jersey, then. Despite the violence, The Sopranos couldn't compete with the week's scariest programme, Hidden Love. 'Living in a world totally bereft of intimacy and closeness is for most of us intolerable and a small number of people move into delusion,' we were told. A small number? I don't think I know anybody who hasn't teetered close to the edge of De Clerambault's syndrome, which is when ordinary, lovesick souls make the leap to become obsessive, fixated stalkers: erotomaniacs. As Ian McEwan, who wrote about the subject in his novel Enduring Love, observed: '[De Clerambault's] just turned the heat up under a number of things that were common to all of us.' In other words, the truly scary thing about the illness is the thinness of the line that separates the near- madness of ordinary, acceptable lovesickness from the sheer madness of obsession. Trevor is the star of his own Play Misty For Me , fixated on a radio DJ whom he believes loves him and sends messages via her show. But while Trevor is obviously, recognisably and sadly disurbed, fellow-sufferer Karen was somehow even more unsettling because she looked and sounded perfectly normal even when she was saying, earnestly: 'There's an affinity between us', of a man she has seen only once, nine years ago. Caught in a world they see as riddled with signs and portents, the tiniest of coincidences (car number plates, overheard conversations) are all fuel for the un-extinguishable flames of obsessively unrequited love, even when court orders are in place and prison terms are being served. But then something odd happens - a weird coincidence, A Sign - and you find yourself suddenly sucked into A Syndrome. It happened to me while watching Black Books, the funniest programme on TV. I nearly wrote about it last week and the week before but, for some reason, I waited. Now I know why. Now I know that its star, Dylan Moran, is trying to tell me that, yes, he loves me as much as I love him, maybe even more, despite the obstacles that stand in our way - which include not having met, stuff like that. Last week's painfully hilarious episode (Plot? Oh, if you must: a £7,000 bottle of Bordeaux, destined for the Pope but drunk in error by Moran and sidekick, Bill Bailey) finished with Moran reading The Observer. I'm not stupid, Dylan. You don't imagine I'd miss A Sign as blindingly obvious as that, do you? Do you...?

webTitle: Tip-off on 'Bible John' killings

fields.headline: Tip-off on 'Bible John' killings
fields.trailText: Detectives were investigating a tip-off last night which could finally bring to justice the man responsible for three of Britain's most baffling murders.
fields.body:
Detectives were investigating a tip-off last night which could finally bring to justice the man responsible for three of Britain's most baffling murders.

The killer, known as Bible John, struck three times in the late Sixties. He picked up his female victims from Glasgow's Barrowland ballroom, then strangled them with their own tights or stockings.

Police believed that all three murders were committed by the same man, who gained his nickname by quoting the Bible in conversation.

The first victim, Pat Docker, 25, in February 1968, was followed by Jemima McDonald, 32, 18 months later, and Helen Puttock, 10 weeks later. Police have never given up the hunt for their killer.

Now, Ian Stephen, a retired psychologist who worked on the original case, has been contacted by the relative of a man who is said to be a strong suspect for the murders.

Stephen said the source had given him information about a relative who is thought to be living in England. His relative was the son of a Glasgow police officer, and in 1960 was married and living in Lanarkshire.

In the late 1960s, his behaviour is said to have changed and he increasingly stayed out overnight. In 1970 he abruptly put his house on the market, moving to England.

In 1996 police exhumed for DNA tests the body of a man buried in a graveyard in Lanarkshire. Former Scots Guard John McInnes killed himself in 1980. Police said later there was insufficient evidence from the tests to link him with the scene of Helen Puttock's murder.

webTitle: Paul Harris on the new generation of mobile phones

fields.headline: Don't worry. The voices inside your head are real
fields.trailText: Hearing voices inside your head? Don't be alarmed. You'll probably be wearing the mobile phone that allows you to take calls by sticking your finger in your ear.
fields.body:
Hearing voices inside your head? Don't be alarmed. You'll probably be wearing the mobile phone that allows you to take calls by sticking your finger in your ear.

The prototypes have been developed and work well. Soon the days of the mobile phone pest on a train or bus will be gone. Instead, commuters will get annoyed as people jam their fingers firmly inside their ears and shout into their wrists.

The phone, dubbed Whisper by the Japanese firm that invented it, is worn like a watch. It consists of a receiver that converts audio signals into vibrations. The caller's voice travels through the hand, into the fingers and out into the ear canal. You talk back via a microphone in the phone's wristband.

There is no keypad. Incoming calls are signalled by a gentle vibration and you answer the phone by tapping your thumb and index finger together. To dial and use other functions you tap your fingers, in different rhythms. Or you can use voice commands similar to those in use on many mobiles.

The new device was invented in Japan, becoming the home of the weird and wonderful in technology. Masaaki Fukumoto, a senior research engineer at Tokyo-based NTT DoCoMo, got the idea for his finger phone during a conference on wearable computers in 1997.

Though demonstrations have worked well, Fukumoto believes most people are reluctant to 'wear' computers and the phone may be an idea ahead of its time.

'People are not willing to use wearable devices except the wristwatch. We have to establish a culture that registers an idea with people that wearing a device is a cool thing,' he said.

Firms want to make computers a fashion accessory, as well as a tool, so that people will choose colours and styles to go with their outfits. A whole raft of wearable devices, from games to music players, that are in development could see us don computers as easily as we now put on ties or lipstick.

A 'glove phone' aimed at roller-bladers and snowboarders is also in development and an American company, Charmed Technology, is to market a badge for people at trade shows and conferences, allowing them to swap and store contact information.

A version aimed at nightclubbers will go on sale next year allowing chat-up lines to be delivered whatever the noise of the music.

webTitle: Race fears fuel rise of Antwerp's own Haider

fields.headline: Race fears fuel rise of Antwerp's own Haider
fields.standfirst: Nationalist leader targets Moroccan immigrants
fields.trailText: When Flemish nationalist Filip DeWinter, exultant after his rapid advance in local elections, talks of 'zero tolerance', the immigrants of Antwerp know what he means. And they are apprehensive.
fields.body:
When Flemish nationalist Filip DeWinter, exultant after his rapid advance in local elections, talks of 'zero tolerance', the immigrants of Antwerp know what he means. And they are apprehensive.

I met DeWinter in the headquarters of his Vlaams Blok party here, and he told me: 'I think that sometimes the police in Antwerp are too much like social workers.' He added: 'We want them to be more like the police - not like social workers.'

His party, which won 20 of the city's 50 council seats, has made scapegoats of immigrants in a city with an ethnic element of less than 13 per cent in its population of 485,000. It has blamed them for a rise in crime. It also wants Flemish independence and is against abortion.

DeWinter arrived for our meeting nearly half an hour late. Along with the Austrian Freedom Party's hero, Jörg Haider, he is the new face of right-wing politics in Europe. The suit is fresh but the eyes are close-set, the mouth curved in an unending sneer. His figure is tall and bullish.

He describes his policies with enthusiasm. He sweeps aside the doctrine of multiculturalism: 'I don't believe in all these cultures living together. We are the bosses around here. I don't like that people adopt little pieces out of other cultures.

'What is wrong with purity? We should not try to organise some kind of multicultural society. If I want to experience other cultures, I will go to other countries.

'I sometimes go into the Moroccan communities. These Moroccan restaurants, they have Arabic writing on the walls. And the music they play. The women dress in hijabs. It's not our culture, and I feel threatened. What is wrong with these people adopting our way of life? They should assimilate into our way of life or leave.'

DeWinter hopes to run the city by forming a coalition with conservatives, but is unlikely to succeed. In the city centre, only streets away from the city's halal butchers, staff at the Federation of Moroccan Organisations still struggle to digest last Sunday's election results. The group represents 50 ethnic welfare organisations.

'How do you think we feel,' says Muhammad Shakar, the director. 'We're living in a city where almost a third of the population voted for Vlaams Blok. Imagine a Turkish child at school being taught by a teacher who has voted for DeWinter. Do you think that teacher will have a clear head when it comes to marking that boy's exams?'

Shakar's primary concern is Vlaams Blok's calls for an extra 600 police in Antwerp. The city already has a force of nearly 1,800. Zero tolerance, says Shakar, as practised in New York, has targeted immigrant communities.

'We'll all be suspects,' he says. 'One handbag will be stolen and 100 Moroccan youths will be arrested. DeWinter is always talking about New York as a blueprint, but look at the civil rights abuses committed by the police there.'

Later on Wednesday, a group of Moroccan teenagers stand sharing cigarettes outside a sweet shop in Amerikalie Street. Dressed in the international urban uniform - baggy jeans and throwover anoraks - they huddle together against a chilly wind.

The Vlaams Blok office can be seen down the street. 'You have an interview with DeWinter?', asks Fatah Hajaj. He laughs: 'Make sure you bomb that building.'

Hajaj and his three friends could barely wait to finish school. Earlier in the day, Shakar had described the city's ethnic teenagers as 'the no-future generation'.

Only 10 per cent of the Moroccan children opt for further education. 'There are no jobs for us, so why should we study?' asks Hajaj. 'There is very little for us to do. With Vlaams Blok in power, there will be even less for us to do.'

Vlaams Blok has exploited the fear of immigrant crime. A recent pamphlet depicts a city overrun by immigrants - a cartoon depicts an Arab restaurant whose speciality is a bombe surprise .

A city-centre gun battle between the Eastern European mafia and the police two weeks ago provided vital votes for Vlaams Blok at the council elections.

After the interview with DeWinter, his secretary calls The Observer a taxi. She worked as an au pair in London - 'I liked the city,' she says. 'Every part is so different'. Asked to translate some posters on the walls, she is sheepish. 'You don't understand,' she says. 'Some of these Moroccans are like terrorists. We find them very threatening.'

Does Vlaams Blok have any Asian members? 'Yes,' she says. She pauses: 'No.'

Institute of Race Relations
Guardian special report: the Austrian far right in power

webTitle: Was Noye case witness killed by Hell's Angels?

fields.headline: Was Noye case witness killed by Hell's Angels?
fields.standfirst: Alan Decabral was far from an innocent victim, reports crime correspondent  Tony Thompson. His part in a war between biker gangs may have cost him his life
fields.trailText: Detectives believe two classic underworld hits could be linked to a rapidly escalating war between biker gangs
fields.body:
They were both classic underworld hits. Last month Michel Auger, one of Canada's top investigative journalists, was climbing out of his car at the office of Le Journal de Montreal when a man in a balaclava came up behind him and shot him five times with a handgun. Two weeks ago, antiques dealer Alan Decabral, the man who helped put road-rage killer Kenneth Noye behind bars, was sitting in his son's car outside Halfords in Ashford, Kent, when a man appeared at his window and shot him once in the side of the head.

The two incidents were thousands of miles apart and had different outcomes - Auger is still alive, whereas Decabral died instantly - but detectives believe the attacks could be linked to a rapidly escalating war between biker gangs, fighting for control of a lucrative drug trade. The Canadian Hell's Angels have been linked to a string of murders and police are investigating a theory that Decabral, a member of a British biker gang, may have crossed them over a drugs deal - and paid the price.

Initially, the finger of suspicion in the Decabral murder pointed at Noye, who is one of Britain's most dangerous men and a serial bearer of grudges. Decabral had given evidence at the Old Bailey trial into the murder of Stephen Cameron that Noye had stabbed Cameron and then walked nonchalantly back to his Range Rover. Decabral dialled 999 and gave chase in his Rolls Royce before losing Noye. There were reports that he received death threats shortly before taking the stand; that three bullets were pushed through his letter box.

The stress of playing a key role in Noye's downfall was said to be so great that Decabral's wife left him. He was forced to shut his business and moved to the quiet village of Pluckley in Kent. Eight weeks before he was killed, he told a newspaper that he spent all his time looking over his shoulder.

For a man supposedly living in fear, Decabral took few precautions. He had been offered, but refused, police protection. He had continued using his own name and made little attempt to blend into the shadows. Weighing more than 20 stone with a distinctive beard and hair, Decabral was well-known in his village and beyond. His notoriety grew further after he was banned from his local pub after fighting with another customer.

Far from being an innocent victim of the underworld, Decabral was closely allied with some of Britain's most powerful villains. The 40-year-old father-of-three was a high-ranking underworld fixer: villains turned to him when they needed guns, drugs or the services of a money launderer.

Customs have confirmed that Decabral ran a team of bootleggers bringing back illicit booze and tobacco from the continent. He had 56 guns in his house, including machine guns and automatic pistols.

That Decabral had found a way of making crime pay is not in doubt. His £350,000 house in Pluckley was bought without a mortgage, he owned a number of vehicles including a Rolls-Royce and a Jaguar and, when his house was raided a few months before his death, police found a £100,000 stash of £50 notes. There had been three raids on the home in the 18 months before his death. Ironically, Noye's defence team were planning to use this information in an attempt to discredit Decabral as a witness in the upcoming appeal hearing. Far from giving Noye the satisfaction of revenge, Decabral's death could scupper his plans for shortening his sentence.

Above all, Decabral was a biker. Not an enthusiast, not a collector, but a committed, hard-core gang member. A former Hell's Angel. Although the majority of bike gang members are simply enthusiasts, a hard-core of professional criminals exists. Tracked across the world by the FBI and the National Criminal Intelligence Service, these élite members are involved in drug trafficking, protection and prostitution. Decabral was believed to be a key member of this group.

The Hell's Angels are the most notorious of all the bike gangs. They are also by far the most active in criminal circles and guard this position fiercely. In Scandinavia, a war between the Angels and their rivals, the Bandidos, has left more than 25 dead in the past five years. Inter-gang violence in the UK is rarer but still happens: three years ago, two members of the Outcasts gang were murdered by Hell's Angels in south London.

A few years earlier, Michael 'Long Mick' Rowledge, a member of the Hell's Angels' Windsor chapter, was shot dead in Liverpool while waiting to collect payment on a drug debt from a local gang.

However, the most vicious biker gangs in the world are to be found in Canada. In Quebec alone, more than 150 bikers have been killed in the past six years. Canadian Angels are also highly placed in the world of drug trafficking. A recent raid recovered more than £6 million of cocaine. The morning that Auger was shot, he had written a major exposé about criminal activity in biker gangs.

The fear now is that the war is spilling across the Atlantic. The Outcasts murdered by the Hell's Angels allegedly died because the Angels had been warned by their American counterparts to do more to maintain their reputation.

While Hell's Angels around the world consider fellow club members to be their brothers, the links between those in Britain and those in Canada are some of the strongest. When Robert 'Snake' Tremblay was forced to go on the run from Montreal after murdering five bikers, he came to Britain where members of the London chapter fixed him up with a flat in Bermondsey. In 1994, when detectives swooped on a London hotel to arrest two Canadian Angels, they found a wealth of evidence of links with their British counterparts.

A spokesman from the National Criminal Intelligence Service confirmed that police officers in the UK are in regular contact with their colleagues in Canada and that firm links between the international chapters of the Angels and other gangs continue to function.

The intimate details of Decabral's deals with the Angels are still being uncovered. One theory is that he was trying to sell drugs and guns to rival biker factions; another is that he had tried to sell sub-standard products at an over-inflated price. Yet another suggests that Decabral, something of a playboy with several women on the go, had become involved with the girlfriend of a major biker figure.

Whatever the motivation, the smart money believes that Decabral knew all along who was after him. He had turned down police protection after the Noye trial because he knew he would never be able to make any money with police officers looking over his shoulder. Once the threats from his eventual executioners started, going to the police would simply have put him in even more danger. Instead he went to the press, concocting stories about threats and bullets through his letter box - Decabral's friends and family have no knowledge of such an incident ever occurring - and betting that the publicity surrounding him would deter any potential assassin. He lost.

Inter-gang violence in the UK is rarer but still happens: three years ago, two members of the Outcasts gang were murdered by Hell's Angels in south London. A few years earlier, Michael 'Long Mick' Rowledge, a member of the Hell's Angels' Windsor chapter, was shot dead in Liverpool while waiting to collect payment on a drug debt from a local gang. However, the most vicious biker gangs in the world are to be found in Canada. In Quebec alone, more than 150 bikers have been killed in the past six years. Canadian Angels are also highly placed in the world of drug trafficking. A recent raid recovered more than £6 million of cocaine. The morning that Auger was shot, he had written a major exposé about criminal activity in biker gangs. The fear now is that the war is spilling across the Atlantic. The Outcasts murdered by the Hell's Angels allegedly died because the Angels had been warned by their American counterparts to do more to maintain their reputation. While Hell's Angels around the world consider fellow club members to be their brothers, the links between those in Britain and those in Canada are some of the strongest. When Robert 'Snake' Tremblay was forced to go on the run from Montreal after murdering five bikers, he came to Britain where members of the London chapter fixed him up with a flat in Bermondsey. In 1994, when detectives swooped on a London hotel to arrest two Canadian Angels, they found a wealth of evidence of links with their British counterparts. A spokesman from the National Criminal Intelligence Service confirmed that police officers in the UK are in regular contact with their colleagues in Canada and that firm links between the international chapters of the Angels and other gangs continue to function. The intimate details of Decabral's deals with the Angels are still being uncovered. One theory is that he was trying to sell drugs and guns to rival biker factions; another is that he had tried to sell sub-standard products at an over-inflated price. Yet another suggests that Decabral, something of a playboy with several women on the go, had become involved with the girlfriend of a major biker figure. Whatever the motivation, the smart money believes that Decabral knew all along who was after him. He had turned down police protection after the Noye trial because he knew he would never be able to make any money with police officers looking over his shoulder. Once the threats from his eventual executioners started, going to the police would simply have put him in even more danger. Instead he went to the press, concocting stories about threats and bullets through his letter box - Decabral's friends and family have no knowledge of such an incident ever occurring - and betting that the publicity surrounding him would deter any potential assassin. He lost.

webTitle: Top dogs beat stress in daycare

fields.headline: Top dogs beat stress in daycare
fields.trailText: They emerge from their luxury cars, some shy and reluctant, some bursting with excitement. Some sport new haircuts, some the latest autumn fashion. They are the American capital's most coddled canines, and they are regulars at Dog-ma Daycare.
fields.body:
They emerge from their luxury cars, some shy and reluctant, some bursting with excitement. Some sport new haircuts, some the latest autumn fashion. They are the American capital's most coddled canines, and they are regulars at Dog-ma Daycare.

They will romp, roll and play in 10,000 sq feet of open space. Some will bone up on social niceties at 'day school'; others will relax with a massage, shampoo and pedicure and some will watch the Animal Planet TV channel.

Rebecca Bisgyer, the founder of Dog-ma, says as social animals, dogs can suffer severe anxiety - with panic attacks and depression - if left at home.

Then there's the owner's guilt. She had felt so bad about the suffering of her own dog Morgan that she quit her six-figure executive post at a currency trading firm. 'He would bark and howl all day, I'd rush home after a 12-hour day, and he'd be nuts. It was unbearable. I don't have kids, so Morgan is my surrogate child, and I couldn't bear to see him suffer.'

She also knew doggie daycare was big business. A day in Dog-ma is $25, not including extras such as a $625 two-week private training course. And even with a reduced rate for regulars, the bill adds up fast: $4,500 for five days a week, 50 weeks a year, more than a lot of Americans spend on their toddler's daycare or children's education.

'I know a lot of people think it's crazy how much I spend, but before Dog-ma, I'd come home from work and my Dalmatian Allie would have so much pent-up energy that I'd spend the entire evening trying to calm her down and disciplining her,' says Dog-ma disciple Andrea Nash. 'Now, it's so much less stressful, I'm happier, she's happier, and she no longer thinks her name is Allie-No!'

In Manhattan, the cost of canine living is steep: $10 carrot bones, $20 shampoos, $60 hydrotherapy treatments or $120 grooming sessions. And then there's canine couture: Ekoo's range of leather, satin and 'faux fur' bomber jackets, dresses and 'classic coats' range from $80 to $120, never mind Gucci and Prada gear.

Pundit, our young golden retriever, has little time for fashion fripperies or trendy treatments, but he hates to be left alone. When it comes to daycare, his tastes tend to the extravagant - $35 a day with Alice Moss in the East Village.

'Many of the Manhattan dogs I treat are suffering from separation anxiety,' Dr Burns of the TriBeCa-SoHo Animal Hospital says. 'It manifests itself in unrelenting barking, aggression, destructive chewing, uncontrolled urination, sometimes trembling. Doggie daycare is a great solution, but for those more thin of wallet, sometimes drugs are the only answer.'

Americans are spending more than ever on their pets, a staggering $28.5 billion on the 63 million household dogs in the country, and that's not including veterinary care, day care or dog walking, says the American Pet Products Manufacturing Association.

webTitle: Now it's sex, drugs and opera

fields.headline: Now it's sex, drugs and opera
fields.standfirst: Puccini's students get their kicks from coke, a duchess performs simulated sex, and cloning adds a twist to the plot. Welcome to Neo-classical Britain
fields.trailText: Loud music, sex and fast living have long been seen as teenage territory. Opera-goers have a fustier, more élitist image. But all that is changing. For maximum street cred last week, the hottest ticket was not a rock concert but a daring new Glyndebourne production featuring impoverished students snorting cocaine.
fields.body:
Loud music, sex and fast living have long been seen as teenage territory. Opera-goers have a fustier, more élitist image. But all that is changing. For maximum street cred last week, the hottest ticket was not a rock concert but a daring new Glyndebourne production featuring impoverished students snorting cocaine.

Puccini's nineteenth century hit, La Bohème, has been thrilling Glyndebourne audiences in an updated version of the story of a group of artists starving together in a Parisian garret in the 1830s. Gone are the frockcoats, easels and berets. Instead the two heroes, writer Rodolfo and painter Marcello, share a squalid bedsit in modern London and are shown taking drugs together - a first for Glyndebourne and an artistic decision that has upset some of the regulars at the Sussex opera house.

'I love the music and the story - it always makes me so sad,' said regular opera-goer Isobel Carter, who is in her seventies. 'But why do they have to put in a nasty thing like that? I just can't understand it.'

So far, critics have been more welcoming of David McVicar's radical rethink of the opera and have praised his cast of attractive, twenty-something unknowns. 'This is a story about young people, and audiences are responding to seeing it played by young people,' said a spokeswoman for Glyndebourne Touring Opera.

Commentators who have worked in opera production have noted wryly that drugs are not quite such a novelty backstage. 'In my experience of the opera houses of the world, most shows would never be ready in time for curtain up if the crew did not indulge,' said a stagehand in the West End.

'The singers don't take any because it ruins the voice,' said one former director, who went on to concede that opera crews might take drugs to cope with their late-night schedules.

The change in opera's potential audience is the result of an outcrop of imaginative new productions all aimed at proving how entertaining and relevant opera can be. The tragic La Bohème, first performed in Turin in 1896, is one of the most romantic works in the classical canon but until now had few points of reference for younger people. The central love story concerns Rodolfo's chance encounter with a consumptive neighbour called Mimi. In the original libretto she comes to ask him for a light for her candle. In the new production she makes the request because the electric lights in their block of flats have fused.

In the final scene, a dying Mimi returns to Rodolfo's door. Conventionally the boys and their two friends, Schaunard, a musician, and Colline, a philosopher, have been dancing in a frantic effort to cheer up the dejected Rodolfo and to celebrate the purchase of a large fish for supper. In the new production a packet of drugs is fetched, along with the fish, and lines of cocaine are passed around. Only Rodolfo, who is pining for Mimi, does not partake.

'The director could not see how young men in this day and age could be expected to get excited about a wet fish,' explained Mandy Chang, who is making a film for Channel 4 about the new production. It will show both the documentary and the opera on Christmas Day and is happy to promote the new wave of operas. Last year it screened Powder Her Face by Thomas Ades and Phillip Hensher, an opera about the scandalous Duchess of Argyll which featured simulated scenes of fellatio.

In December the youth opera Zoe, by John Lunn, will also be broadcast. This is a story which combines teacher/pupil sex, death, cloning and GM science and was written by Stephen Plaice, a regular writer on ITV drama series The Bill , who has also worked with inmates at Lewes Prison. The opera, which premiered to rave reviews this spring, was the result of a collaboration between professional and youth singers in Sussex.

'The students came from all over Sussex and had no interest in opera,' said Teresa Griffiths, who has just finished directing the film version of Zoe. 'But they are all stars now, and several of them are going on to drama school in London.'

Plaice has gone on to work on a collaboration with the Royal Opera House on a youth opera for 13- and 14-year-olds involving schools in Croydon.

A new English National Opera production of a little-known opera by Rossini, The Turk in Italy, which opened this week at The Coliseum in London, is further evidence of opera's fashionability. The libretto has been translated and modernised by the comedian Kit Hesketh-Harvey, of Kit and the Widow, and has been set, by David Fielding, in the Cinecitta studios of Rome's 'new wave' in the 1960s. The renowned singer Thomas Allen plays Prosdocimo, a poet in the original, as a film director. The staging is full of references to cinema icons such as Sophia Loren, Marcello Mastroianni and Fellini and makes plenty of anachronistic jokes - even giving Tommy Cooper an unexpected namecheck.

 'The Turk in Italy' runs until 18 November, call 020 7632 8300. 'La Bohème' is at Glyndebourne until 26 October (01273 813813) and will then tour the country.

 vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Life support

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Clarissa Dickson Wright first met Sir John Scott when they were children, and he offered to show her his ferrets. Now, she's roaming the countryside for a new television series with the only man who's ever called her 'Petal'
fields.trailText: Clarissa Dickson Wright first met Sir John Scott when they were children, and he offered to show her his ferrets. Now, she's roaming the countryside for a new television series with the only man who's ever called her 'Petal'.
fields.body:
Clarissa Dickson Wright: When I was 10 I started spending holidays with my friend Christine who lived in a village in Sussex. My first memory of Johnny is going to a barbecue in a nearby village and this immensely scruffy little redheaded boy saying to me, 'Do you want to see my ferrets?' We banded together, roaming about the countryside and going to parties. I didn't have a crush on him, neither of us were each other's type, but I had a touch of hero worship - he could ride anything.

He went off to some strange places, jackerooing in Australia, while I went to university to study law. When he came back I had graduated and he started farming in Sussex and Kent, then moved north. About this time my drinking was kicking in.

I isolated myself. Johnny saw me at the height of my drinking and was really sad about the state I'd got myself into. When I got sober, I didn't make much effort to get back in touch. I moved to Scotland about seven years ago, and one day Henry, my partner in the bookshop, told me we had a mutual friend. He dialled a number and handed me the telephone. I said, 'Hello, this is Clarissa, who is that?' and the other person, in a distinctive butterscotch voice said, 'Hello Petal.' Nobody else has ever called me Petal.

Johnny was living about 20 minutes away from me on an 8,000-acre hill farm with 1,500 sheep, a wife Mary and two children. Johnny and I just picked up from where we left off as the closest of friends. When the BBC approached me about doing a countryside programme, I told them that I couldn't do it without Johnny. If he didn't translate well to camera, I wanted him as a consultant because he is the best countryman I know. Just as well, because I needed his support during filming.

About a month before filming started last December, I was in Spain on holiday and my hernia tore. When we filmed the first day, I'd literally had stitches out the day before and I was feeling like shit.

One of the first things that I was required to do for the show was walk six miles across a salt marsh in wellington boots, and Johnny was a brick. He just kept me laughing with his wonderfully witty sense of humour.

Jennifer Paterson and I were brought together like the Spice Girls. I was fond of her but there were great difficulties working with her, especially in the afternoon. She liked to drink and it was hard representing a friendship that wasn't there. With Clarissa and the Countryman [BBC2, 8pm, starting Friday] it's the real thing.

Johnny Scott: The countryside was a Pandora's box of treasures for Clarissa. My upbringing was completely rural and I had all the things in life that she didn't. She was the most exuberant person I knew, so it was particularly sad to see her become so ill. Alcoholism is such a powerful illness and what causes it is terribly complex. In Clarissa's case, she was dreadfully upset at the death of her mother. Clarissa never married although she lived with someone for a number of years. He died tragically.

Things were going desperately wrong for her - she'd given up a brilliant career as a barrister, she had terrible money problems and the last time I saw her before she got sober she was unrecognisable. I did fear she wasn't going to make it. Her courage saved her. When she called me a few years later, it was the same exuberant voice on the telephone telling me she was in Edinburgh. It was wonderful to have such a dear old friend living so close by. She had dried out and started to rebuild her life.

She'd always had an interest in food and that led her to The Cooks Bookshop in Edinburgh. She soon became an authority on cooking. Anything she does with seafood is wonderful, and we share a love of British beef and game. Some time later came Two Fat Ladies.

Clarissa has always been an enormously supportive friend and has the ability to think laterally. We often eat together, and go to the theatre. We might go fishing for trout on the river where I live or to the races. As with any close friendship, there are numerous times when she's been there for me, and I for her. We share the problems of life together.

webTitle: Who wants to be a rupee millionaire?

fields.headline: Who wants to be a rupee millionaire?
fields.trailText: These days the hush of the night descends on India three hours early. Buses roll away from their stands half empty; cinema tickets go unpurchased; and the only things to be found wandering the pot-holed roads are sacred cows.
fields.body:
These days the hush of the night descends on India three hours early. Buses roll away from their stands half empty; cinema tickets go unpurchased; and the only things to be found wandering the pot-holed roads are sacred cows.

In government offices, tenement blocks, and upmarket slums, the words 'Confident?' and 'Final answer?' can be heard issuing from TV sets.

This is, of course, Kaun Banega Crorepati?, India's version of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? Since its launch in July the Hindi show has become a national phenomenon. Much of its success is down to its host Amitabh Bachchan, India's biggest movie star. In three months the show has turned around the fortunes of Rupert Murdoch's previously ailing Star Plus channel. Now its rival, Zee TV, is about to launch its own version of the quiz, in what threatens to become a Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? war.

Yesterday, Zee unveiled the vital ingredient of Sawaal Dus Crore Ka (The Hundred Million Rupee Question) - the host. Zee's show is to be presented by another Bollywood star, Anupam Kher, a popular character actor.

In the original show, contestants are given the chance to become a crorepati, by winning a crore which is 10 million rupees (£155,000). On Thursday the Star channel wil consolidate its grip on the Indian psyche when millions see a 27-year-old policeman's son from Bombay saunter through 15 questions to become the show's first jackpot winner. Harshvardhan Nawathe, who is training for the Indian civil service's tough entrance exams, has already been presented to the media, to steal Zee's thunder.

'It's like a dream. I am thrilled,' he said. 'But I went to the show not to win the big prize, but to see in the flesh my dream hero Amitabh Bachchan.' Some of the gloss came off his win, however, when it emerged the inland revenue was to take nearly half his winnings in tax.

Cultural observers are transfixed by the success of Kaun Banega Crorepati? In a population overwhelmingly poor, part of its appeal is clear. But, according to Sevanthi Ninan, India's leading TV critic, Bachchan holds the key. 'In the movies in his early career, he was an angry young man, on the side of the oppressed. Now he has gone through a process of re-iconisation to represent something aspirational and middle-class,' she said. 'Though they have said rickshaw wallahs could go on the quiz I've never seen anyone who is not a middle-class face.'

'Though they have said rickshaw wallahs could go on the quiz I've never seen anyone who is not a middle-class face.'

webTitle: In bed with the sexperts

fields.headline: In bed with the sexperts
fields.standfirst: The rise and rise of men's magazines has created a new market: the woman who reveals the most intimate details of her sex life. A novel way of talking dirty, or proof that equality has finally arrived?
fields.trailText: The rise and rise of men's magazines has created a new market: the woman who reveals the most intimate details of her sex life. A novel way of talking dirty, or proof that equality has finally arrived?
fields.body:
A year ago, I read an article in the men's magazine GQ by the magazine's sex columnist, Kate Taylor. 'The editor called me into his office,' wrote Taylor, 'and said, "Katy, this month your column goes dirty."'

This was interesting, partly because I was fascinated to know how Kate Taylor felt about doing something that was sexually dirty, or, at any rate, dirtier than she would normally do, and partly because reading the article made me want to meet her and find out what kind of person she was. And, perhaps more importantly, something new seemed to be happening in the world of sex. Women were addressing men directly about their desires and experiences, in mainstream magazines. For years, if you wanted to read about women's intimate sexual feelings, you had to read books aimed at women, by authors such as Nancy Friday. Or you had to go to the top shelf, where you could find saucy articles purportedly written by women, but which had actually been written by men - pure fiction, in other words.

But perhaps things were more complicated than they seemed. Were women really writing about their desires and experiences? Or were they writing about desires and experiences that men might enjoy reading about? Was this a good thing or a bad thing? Were they telling the truth? Here was Dylan Jones, a male editor, asking a female writer to have a certain type of sex. He wanted hard facts. 'It's totally legitimate, because that's something that personally I want to read about,' he tells me. 'And I hope our readers do, too.'

The sex columns, which have been around for a handful of years, reflect a change in both men and women. There are four or five regularly covered topics: the fact that women like plenty of foreplay and have many erogenous zones; the fact that cunnilingus virtually guarantees an orgasm; the fact that having sex in unusual places, or in unusual positions, can be a turn on; the fact that illicit affairs are exciting; and the fact that anal sex, in the right circumstances, can be more than a remote fantasy. 'Six years ago,' says Anthony Noguera, editor of FHM, 'you wouldn't have seen a men's magazine covering anything to do with sex, because the whole point of men's magazines was to say, "You're a º ª great guy." The magazines didn't challenge their readers.'

If something was happening to men, something was happening to women, too. They were becoming less reserved. In Sky magazine, you could read 'High priestess of perv' Karen Krizanovich. In Later, you could read Tracey Cox, the bestselling author of Hot Sex: How To Do It, and Rachel Lewis, who writes this month about 'The U Spot', which 'was discovered in 1988 by a research team at Northwestern University in Chicago'.

Oliver James, the clinical psychologist and author of Britain on the Couch, says, 'The evidence is all there that woman are far more liberated than they ever were.' He believes that 'throughout the developed world, the number of partners of young women has been steadily increasing and the age at which they first have sex has decreased'. He also adds, 'It's quite obvious to me, from talking to younger women, that they are more libidinous, less hung up, and they don't see sex as this critical issue, like their grandmothers or their aunts did.' On the other hand, the negative conditioning, built up over centuries, has not disappeared overnight; according to research, women still 'fantasise less about sex' than men, they 'are less sexually explicit in their fantasies', and they 'focus more on the build-up than the climax'.

Rowan Pelling, editor of The Erotic Review, writes her own column in GQ, under the heading Erotica. 'The thing about the lads' mags,' says Pelling, 'is they gave men a freedom to say, "I no longer have to have an appropriate response." And that was a great freedom.' When magazines such as FHM and Loaded were launched, in other words, men were no longer expected to hide their lust. What had once been private had become public. Men could look at pictures of unclothed women on trains and buses.

Pelling is not anti-pornography. 'Most standard pornography,' she says, 'is people having sex, and I just don't think sex is corrupting.' She sees herself as a member of an in-between generation of women - not an old-style feminist, and not part of 'the Ibiza generation'. She is 32, and comes across as a bit posh and old fashioned. She is not what you'd expect. She talks about sex with unjaded enthusiasm, as if she's a student writing a thesis on it. She's a libertarian, as long as people do whatever they do behind closed doors. At one point, she says, 'I pretty much subscribe to the argument that it's better to have sex with a sheep, probably, than to kill it and have it end up as mutton on your plate. I mean, from the sheep's point of view.' She thinks we should be more forgiving about affairs, like the French, and enjoyed the movies Showgirls and Romance. She says she found Romance, in which a girl has rape fantasies, 'all very psychologically accurate'.

We meet in the West End offices of The Erotic Review, where a female editorial assistant is photocopying black-and-white illustrations of a woman baring her naked hindquarters to be spanked. Pelling says, 'Pornography, which is still made largely by men for men, still contains stuff that women don't find particularly interesting - massive orgies, baby oil. It's all about the thrust. There's very little foreplay. Most pornography is not tactile.'

The Erotic Review is a journal of highbrow smut with quaintly lewd illustrations. There is a story in the summer issue by Gavanndra Hodge which goes, 'For me the library has always been one of the most erotically charged public spaces.' There is a cartoon strip featuring Egyptologists and frolicking lesbians. Politically, it is absolutely incorrect.

Pelling's column, she tells me, is quite different from Taylor's. She says, 'I think Kate's column is practical and hands on. It's much more about sex that she has. There's an obvious difference with me, because I'm married. I think my column is written as a persona. I wouldn't be able to talk about my private life in the way that Kate does. Some people can and some people can't.'

The Erotica column, she says, she would call 'advisory', while Taylor's is 'adventuresome'. Pelling says, 'You can only go two ways if you talk about your own experience. Either you write about disastrous stuff, which is necessarily embarrassing and humiliating for someone, or you write about something that's totally wonderful, and then you not only make people want to puke, but you also jeopardise something. It's the Hello! factor. If you say anything is good, I think you jeopardise it immediately.'

In other words, it's hard to write the truth. The gay novelist Edmund White once told me that, whereas gay writers find it relatively easy to write about their sexual exploits, heterosexuals are always worried about embarrassing and shaming their sexual partners. Pelling tells me that she would never reveal anything about her own sex life with her husband Angus McKinnon, ex-editor of GQ. Her mother, she says, is broadly supportive of her career, but 'in the best possible scenario, she'd probably prefer it if I were doing something that wasn't so preoccupied with sex. She likes the fact that I write for The Spectator as well. That sort of cheers her up.'

Pelling has no moral view on monogamy. She has just written a column on love triangles, which she thinks are prevalent, at least in people's minds. She says, 'If somebody asks, "Is that true?" the correct response is, "Well, yes, of course it's true. It just may not have happened where I said it did, at that time, in that place, or in that order." I think the interesting thing about sex is that even if you said, "I'm so frank, I write absolutely the truth," who's going to know unless they were in the bedroom? I wouldn't be surprised if what I wrote in a more veiled way weren't more truthful than the people writing total self-exposition.'

She is from Kent, where her parents ran a pub. She has raunchily sensible attitudes to everything. She thinks people would benefit if their first sexual experience was with someone older and more experienced. She once wrote robustly about roaming around London looking for a brothel with Malcolm MacLaren. There are many problems facing the female sex columnist. First, you are dealing with a delicate subject, with gynaecology on one side and innuendo on the other. What will your partner think? Your ex-partners? Your parents? Also: will you be in some way tainted by the experience?

Bibi Lynch, who writes for various publications, including Fiesta, says she'd like to referred to as a 'journalist and broadcaster'. Her days in the salt mines of writing sex columns are over, or at least numbered. These days, she is working on several TV pilots as a presenter. Her break came when she was reporting a comic item on a Radio 5 programme about orgasms on pop songs. Lynch persuaded Claire Rayner to rate the orgasms. An editor at Risque magazine heard the item, and Lynch's career as a sex writer was launched. She was, she was told, someone 'who could call a vagina a vagina'.

But she didn't always write about her own experiences. 'If I fell out with people I'd certainly make sure they were in the features,' she says. Then she says, 'I'm joking.' At parties, she gets a bit sick of people who say, 'Here's Bibi - she's a porn queen.' She once covered a story for more! magazine on orgasm classes. 'It was horrific - a house in Norwood in south London, with social misfits talking about how to have orgasms for England.' For Lynch, writing about sex was a rung on the ladder. Now, like Krizanovich, she does not want to be too strongly identified as a sex writer. Lynch says, 'You do get sick of that sticky sex brush.'

Anne Hooper, who has written 23 books about sex, including The Ultimate Sex Guide, tells me that, while 'women are discovering the ability to be free about sex for the first time, it's partly inhibition that's driving them to be so feisty'. Perhaps, having been repressed for centuries, women are going too far the other way. Hooper, who has also worked as a sex therapist, says, 'I probably know more about sex than any other writer in the country.' She's an expert on female anatomy. When she first began to write about the subject, there was 'shock and horror within my family. My father was a very straight British individual, a major in British intelligence during the war. But when The Ultimate Sex Guide became a bestseller, he was as pleased as anybody.'

It is possible, Hooper believes, for women to write about sex in a way that is too feisty, too coarse. 'The minute things are only suggested or hinted at,' she says, 'that's more erotic. It's a mystery, a kind of labyrinth of sexuality you have to negotiate to find out what lies at the end.'

What has happened, it seems, is something very simple. Women now feel free to tell men, in mainstream British publications, that they enjoy sex, that they fantasise about it, albeit in slightly different ways. They want to tell men about these different ways. And men like reading about it. Rachel Lewis, whose advice to men in this month's Later is, 'She'll be expecting you to start driving full pelt towards the main event by now, but instead of stamping on the accelerator, take a bit of time', says men respond to visual stimulation, whereas women are turned on by a more complex array of things. As Oliver James puts it in Britain on the Couch: 'Men are more explicit about sexual acts during fantasies.' And as Lewis adds, 'You wouldn't illustrate a women's sex article with pictures of naked men.'

Tracey Cox, who was born in England but grew up in Australia, says, 'Men and women are similar in sex drive. But a woman's body is more complicated. It's harder to play. You've got to turn us on in so many different ways before it'll happen for us.' Cox is 38 and divorced. 'If I'd met and married Mr Wonderful at 21, what would I know about relationships?' she asks. 'My family,' she says, 'is fine about me writing about sex because I don't just write about sex.'

Cox says, 'I thought Australia was uptight - until I came here.' In Australia, she tells me, the expression 'nice girls don't' refers to kinky things - it's assumed that everybody enjoys sex. 'We should all just relax about sex,' she says. She believes that women, as well as men, can have 'the best sex of your life' with 'somebody you couldn't care less about, because it doesn't matter if they judge you'.

Her first sexual experience was disappointing. She was 16. 'I had it all organised,' she says. 'I had condoms. I knew about clitorises and orgasms, which most people don't at that age.' But sex education let her down. 'What I didn't realise is that people actually moved when they had intercourse. A year later I discovered sex properly.'

Cox is forthright and sensible. She thinks we should be more like the Swedes, who are franker about sex, and have lower rates of sexually transmitted disease and unwanted pregnancy. She reckons that the ladette culture is silly: 'What's she proving? We know she can go down the pub and drink and bonk as many men as she wants. What's the point?'

Talking about her column, Kate Taylor says, 'I was given a brief when I started. You've got to make them laugh. You've got to make them think. And you've got to give them a bit of a tingle.'

We are in a wine bar. Taylor comes across as being a journalist who drifted into writing about sex, rather than a sex professional. 'It was never anything I planned to do,' she says. 'But I've got a smutty sense of humour. I haven't gone into it very professionally.' She started writing the column a couple of years ago, when James Brown was editing GQ.

'I wrote a style piece on what men should wear in bed,' she says. In the piece, she wrote:

'They should keep their pants on, because an unharnessed willy really makes its presence felt.'

She could hear Brown laughing from his office, and the column was born.

Taylor, who is not currently in a relationship, is 29. She says she sometimes writes about things that have happened to her, and sometimes about things that have happened to friends. 'I suppose it's like being this fantasy girlfriend, where I'm up for everything, and nothing's taboo,' she says. When she first tried to have sex as a teenager, 'I remember lying back and thinking, "They write poems about this!" But it got better.' Her mother, she says, likes her column 'when it's funny and about relationships. Dad doesn't read it'.

Like all the other columnists, Taylor believes that women are fundamentally different from men. They may be just as horny, but 'I see it again and again, girlfriends saying, "It was only a one-night stand, but he hasn't called." I think women pursuing men doesn't work. I think sex is one thing. Being feisty and up for it, that's fine. But I think relationships work out better still when the man pursues the woman.'

When Dylan Jones asked her to have anal sex and write about it, he was asking her to do something much less dangerous and frightening than an editor who asks a reporter to cover a war or a riot. But this was not an example of a woman responding to her desires. It was an example of a woman being pursued. As it turned out, it was a legitimate exercise - the reader was made to think, to laugh and to tingle, and the reporter, as it turned out, enjoyed the assignment.

What the female sex columnists are telling us is pretty clear. Nice girls do. And they like to do it in all sorts of ways. On top of this, though, men must listen to what women want and be gentle with them. Meeting Taylor, I find that she is not what I expected - she's nicer. She appears vulnerable. She does not, in some indefinable way, seem like someone who would write, 'I can orgasm on a pogo stick.' Which demonstrates the level of my prejudice. Like several of the others, Taylor doesn't expect to be a sex columnist for-ever. 'I've got an idea for a novel,' she says.
