webTitle: Web watch

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: Surfing the slopes
fields.trailText: Surfing the slopes.
fields.body:
Greyer skies and shorter days prompt many skiers and snowboarders to start planning the one thing that will get them through the cold season.

There is a wide variety of websites offering skiing holidays, but don't be tempted to click 'buy' for the insurance deals that go with them without checking whether the policy provides adequate cover and offers good value.

Adequate insurance is vital on the slopes, as accidents are common and emergency assistance is very costly in most resorts.

An E111 form is not enough and the cost of an uninsured holiday could be an extra £6,000 if a helicopter and private clinic are involved - more if there are complications.

Try www.inghams.co.uk which offers a wide range of resorts worldwide. You can view flight details, accommodation, resort information and weather conditions. But the cost of its insurance is not particularly competitive: 10 days' cover in Europe for a single adult costs£44.

And www.firstchoice.co.uk offers a selection covering trips to snowy resorts. The standard travel insurance offered on the website is reasonably priced but beware - it doesn't cover winter sports at all.

LunnPoly books winter holidays through its subsidiary, Crystal Holidays, with winter sports insurance available only if you have booked the entire holiday through them. A telephone call is necessary to obtain full details of the cover but it is comprehensive and costs £35 for 10 days.

The Virgin site, www.virginholidays.co.uk, offers skiing trips to the United States with a travel insurance deal covering all aspects of winter sports which, for outside Europe, costs £50 for up to 10 days.

However, you may save substantially on insurance if you buy independently. www.worldwideinsure.com has two types of winter sports cover: normal skiing and snowboarding, which costs £23 for 10 days in Europe, or cross country skiing, which only costs £17.25.

It's worth remembering that while skiing itself is classed as a dangerous sport and not covered on a standard holiday insurance policy, there are many other alternative winter activities which also need further special cover.

MRL Insurance at www.insure4cover.com has online quote and payment facilities and includes cover for off-piste skiing and various other 'hazardous' sports on offer in a ski resort such as heli-skiing, luging (similar to bob-sleighing), snow mobiling, tobogganing and even paragliding. Up to 10 days in Europe costs £22.50. www.optionsinsurance.co.uk offers winter sports cover at £20 for a single European trip of 10 days.

But if you take several holidays a year, including a ski trips, you may do better at www.moneyextra.com where £41.98 insures a 30-year-old male for an annual multi-trip policy to Europe with winter sports cover for skiing and several other hazardous snow sports.

The Ski Club of Great Britain offers the most comprehensive winter sport policies at www.skiclub.co.uk. Designed with advice from skiers, the cover goes beyond loss and injury. If a piste is closed for 12 hours, customers can claim up to £500. Closure by avalanche is also taken into account, allowing compensation for extra hotel costs and the reimbursement of ski hire and ski pass expenditure.

There is cover for ski equipment, which is not the case on most policies. New skis often cost around £400, which would exceed the value of most single items covered on a normal policy.

The Ski Club of Great Britain's insurance is lower for members of the club, at £49.50 for an annual travel policy which allows up to 17 days of winter sports in Europe; but non-members can get the same cover for £64.35. You are therefore covered for all other trips to Europe for a year.

A Superclub version of this policy is slightly more for an unlimited number of winter holidays - so long as they don't exceed 31 days per trip. The family rates are also worth looking at.

webTitle: Insurance: That mobile phone's a steal

fields.headline: That mobile phone's a steal
fields.standfirst: Your handset is prone to a variety of disasters so, asks  Tracey Boles, should you take out cover?
fields.trailText: Your handset is prone to a variety of disasters so, asks Tracey Boles, should you take out cover?
fields.body:
If they're not dropped down toilets, eaten by animals or had drinks spilt over them in pubs, one is stolen every three minutes. What are they? Mobile phones.

Since you may have to pay up to £200 to replace a lost or damaged handset, taking out insurance to cover such an eventuality would seem sensible. But choosing mobile phone insurance can be almost as bewildering as choosing a network or handset. Where can you find the best deals?

A survey by retailer Mobile Phone Centre (MPC) has found that accidents involving loos, beer and our four-legged friends are among the most common reasons for claims, accounting for 21 per cent of them.

Incidents that MPC has come across include a phone devoured by a pig, another buried in the back garden by a pet dog and one falling from a bar into the slops tray.

But it's not just accidents that leave mobile phone users - now more than 70 per cent of the population - with the inconvenience of managing without a phone and the cost of a replacement, which can be as much as five to 10 times the original price of the handset.

Around 15,000 mobile phones are stolen every month in Britain and the number is growing. Theft accounted for 51 per cent of claims on the MPC scheme in 1999.

But don't take the first insurance deal that is offered. Price and terms vary. Handset manufacturer Nokia recommends that you check what the networks or home insurers are offering. Network One 2 One spokeswoman Liza Hoeksma says: 'Look around. Sometimes the insurance is packaged into the deal or there may be a special offer of free insurance for a year. But we do recommend you take some insurance out. Phones are so easy to lose - people carry them around in their top pockets for instance - and replacing them can cost as much as £200.'

Insurance can be bought from the networks directly or through the shops that sell the phones. Handset manufacturers do not offer insurance. Network Vodafone offers 'comprehensive' cover at £5.95 a month for contract phones. You have to stump up a £25 policy excess yourself when you make a claim. One 2 One's insurance is £3.99 a month with a policy excess of £20. Orange offers insurance at £5 a month, again with a policy excess of £20. The other big network, BT Cellnet, says it does not offer a scheme.

Given that Orange will replace your handset for £50, you may not think it is worthwhile taking out the insurance. But the company argues: 'If you take out the emergency care insurance once you have lost your phone you pay out £20 for a new phone and £30 pays for six months' insurance, all for the equivalent of your £50.'

Paying for accidental damage out of your own pocket can also be costly. If you drop your phone and crack the screen you will have to pay £80 without insurance according to retailer Carphone Warehouse.

Network insurance deals can tie you in for a year but Carphone Warehouse sells the insurance in three-month blocks after finding that most people lose their phones in the first six months because they are not used to having them.

The price of Carphone Warehouse insurance depends on what type of phone you have and the level of cover. Its insurance for contract phones will set you back between £89 and £107 annually while cover for pre-paid phones costs £30 a year. Rival retailer MPC offers a deal through Cornhill which works out at £60 a year.

With all policies check what is not covered as well as what is. Loss is often excluded from policies meaning you will not get a payout if your phone is stolen because you leave it unattended on a bar. General wear and tear will probably not be covered.

For theft to form the basis of a claim it may have to involve force. Remember all instances of theft or loss should be reported to the police and to the airtime provider. You won't get anywhere with your claim without a crime number.

It is worth investigating whether mobile phones are covered by any household or motor insurance you already have. Norwich Union says mobiles may be covered under both the contents or personal belongings section of its household insurance as long as they are for personal use only. There is also a policy excess of £50.

Fewer than 30 per cent of mobile phones are insured, according to Carphone Warehouse. However, since the cost of replacing or repairing them is so high and problems so frequent, it is worth considering - provided you ask the right questions.

webTitle: On the market

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Newcastle Building Society RESI Bond Issues 4 and 5
fields.trailText: Newcastle Building Society RESI Bond Issues 4 and 5
fields.body:
Contact: 0191 244 2244 or visit www.newcastle.co.uk

Aim: To provide returns linked to increases in house prices.

Closing date: 27 October 2000.

Bells & whistles: The society says many economists predict that violent house price fluctuations have ended, while the Council for Mortgage Lenders predicts house price inflation of 6 per cent in 2001 and 5 per cent in 2002. The Newcastle claims the RESI bonds offer 'an innovative method of investing in residential property with no risk of capital loss'.

How it works: RESI Bond issue 4 pays a guaranteed return of 7.5 per cent gross a year until 31 October 2002, plus 50 per cent of the growth of the Halifax House Price Index over the three-year term (until 31 October 2003), based on the original amount invested. Interest is paid on 1 November. Issue 5 pays a return equal to 200 per cent of the growth in the Halifax House Price Index over the three-year term from 1 November 2000 to 31 October 2003. If house prices fall over the term, you still get all your capital back.

Minimum: £5,000.

Charges: Built into the product.

Tax: Interest is paid net of tax.

Risk: Issue 4 - low, Issue 5 - medium.

Should you buy it? Amanda Davidson of London independent financial adviser Holden Meehan likes issue 4: 'The 7.5 per cent gross guaranteed for two years is a good rate, only leaving your return in year three at any risk. Issue 5 offers no guarantees, and as house prices have been high, you could be investing at a time when they could reduce or at least slow down.' Chris Wicks of Glossop firm Bridgewater Financial Planning says: 'You wouldn't want to invest in equities over three years, so this is not a bad place to put your money. However, I would go for Issue 4 rather than Issue 5.'

Points out of 10: Issue 4: Davidson - 6, Wicks - 7. Issue 5: Davidson - 4, Wicks - 5.

webTitle: Property: The Ulster feel-good factor

fields.headline: The Ulster feel-good factor
fields.standfirst: The peace dividend means house prices and sales are still rising in Northern Ireland, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: The peace dividend means house prices and sales are still rising in Northern Ireland, writes Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
One part of the United Kingdom property market has avoided dipping house prices and slowing sales - not a fashionable London hotspot, nor a rural idyll, but Northern Ireland. Even an uneasy peace in the province has produced huge levels of investment from developers in commercial and residential property, and the housing market has been climbing in the province while it has peaked across Britain.

Cranes tower over central Belfast's skyline, and European Community flags flutter from new hotel and industrial sites denoting new tranches of funding.

'The feel-good factor is by far the biggest influence in all of this,' says Gault Ervine of Ulster Property Sales, which has branches across Northern Ireland. 'People want things to get better. We've experienced average house price increases of between 10 and 12 per cent over each of the past two years; in some areas have risen by up to 20 per cent each year.'

Ervine claims the market is far from exhausted: 'It's showing signs of a little slowdown this autumn, but one theory has it that as more new investment creates more jobs and more money, there will be a continuation - there could be up to 40 per cent more to come in some areas over the next few years.'

In some prestigious, sought-after areas of Belfast, such as Malone, relatively ordinary detached bungalows with large gardens are on the market for £250,000. Double-fronted Victorian family houses in the same area reach £500,000 - a price that would not be considered cheap in South-East England. A village 10 minutes from Belfast may have comparable properties at half the price.

'We used to be at the bottom of the league table of house prices in UK regions,' says Ervine, 'and now we're roughly halfway up. But leaving bigger political issues aside, it's obvious that the North and South housing markets are going to be much more closely aligned in the future, and it's more realistic to compare Belfast with Dublin than with, say, London or any English city.'

But there are still cheap houses around, although many are in poor condition. The University of Ulster estimates that 8 per cent of private houses need substantial repairs. A mid-terrace two-bedroom house near the centre of Belfast is on the market through estate agent Brian Morton for £11,500 - 'in need of extensive modernisation'. Others are on sale for even less, and some agents require payment in cash on properties costing less than £10,000.

Some of the recent rises in these low-cost areas are being driven by purchasers from the Republic. 'My company has bought five houses in the north,' said one Dublin investor who did not want to be named and who used a third party to buy the properties in mixed Catholic and Protestant areas.

'They were pretty run-down but demand for rental is high from students and people coming to Belfast because of the new investment, so they'll give a good yield once renovated. House prices are roughly 50 per cent more here in the South than in many parts of the North, but that gap is likely to close in years to come.'

Public housing has an importance in Northern Ireland which has long gone from much of the rest of the UK, at least partly because of the historic reluctance of private developers to build in some of the more sensitive areas, and partly because some estates have become identified with the Troubles.

Last month, housing authorities agreed to invest £110 million to add another 1,200 council homes, a new road and a community hall to north Belfast's stock. Some will be new-build, but others will be restored houses in the Shankill area, scene of recent Loyalist paramilitary feuding, and where six different 'peace lines' divide the community.

But the UK Government and Stormont Assembly are emphasising the importance of private ownership by promoting a scheme operated by the Northern Ireland Co-Ownership Housing Association.

It allows those on low incomes to buy part of a private house, with the rest of it paid for and owned by the housing association. No deposit is needed and each month the 'co-owner' pays a sum to a mortgage lender and another sum - rent, in effect - to the housing association. If your income goes up, you can increase the proportion of the house that you own, or vice-versa.

If you want to sell your house, all parties must agree and you split the proceeds proportionately. So far, 15,000 people have become part-property owners via the scheme - putting more pressure on prices in the Northern Ireland housing market.

More information

Ulster Property: 02890 650844
Brian Morton and Co: 02890 721678
Northern Ireland Co-Ownership Housing Association: 0800 333644

'They were pretty run-down but demand for rental is high from students and people coming to Belfast because of the new investment, so they'll give a good yield once renovated. House prices are roughly 50 per cent more here in the South than in many parts of the North, but that gap is likely to close in years to come.' Public housing has an importance in Northern Ireland which has long gone from much of the rest of the UK, at least partly because of the historic reluctance of private developers to build in some of the more sensitive areas, and partly because some estates have become identified with the Troubles. Last month, housing authorities agreed to invest £110 million to add another 1,200 council homes, a new road and a community hall to north Belfast's stock. Some will be new-build, but others will be restored houses in the Shankill area, scene of recent Loyalist paramilitary feuding, and where six different 'peace lines' divide the community. But the UK Government and Stormont Assembly are emphasising the importance of private ownership by promoting a scheme operated by the Northern Ireland Co-Ownership Housing Association. It allows those on low incomes to buy part of a private house, with the rest of it paid for and owned by the housing association. No deposit is needed and each month the 'co-owner' pays a sum to a mortgage lender and another sum - rent, in effect - to the housing association. If your income goes up, you can increase the proportion of the house that you own, or vice-versa. If you want to sell your house, all parties must agree and you split the proceeds proportionately. So far, 15,000 people have become part-property owners via the scheme - putting more pressure on prices in the Northern Ireland housing market. webTitle: Till death - not debt - do us part

fields.headline: Till death - not debt - do us part
fields.standfirst: The average wedding costs £12,000. But you can get hitched for less, says  Adrian Holliday
fields.trailText: The average wedding costs £12,000. But you can get hitched for less, says Adrian Holliday.
fields.body:
The average British wedding costs a staggering £12,000. But for the couple who would rather not blow a big pile of cash on the Big Day there is another way.

The essential wedding costs - after stripping away the vol-au-vents, marquees, laid-on entertainment and clothes hire - are astoundingly low. For couples in England and Wales, £62.50 can cover all register office expenses. In Scotland, a basic church wedding costs less than half that - only £32.

Rob and Kirsty Shaw, both 24, wanted to spend the minimum when they married at Doncaster register office in June. Rob's only expense was a new shirt, while Kirsty wore a new work suit. Their total wedding bill: £200.

They say the key is to remember you don't need to entertain anyone, or do anything you don't want to do.

'People always say it is "your day", but it took me a while to fully appreciate what that meant,' says Rob. 'Some of my family wanted us to have a huge church wedding and big hotel reception. But that was the last thing either of us wanted.

'In the end, we spent the money we'd saved for the wedding on a sporty new VW Lupo which took us on our honeymoon. The car will last us years and give us a lot more enjoyment than one very expensive piss-up.'

However most people are prepared to spend at least £1,000 on their wedding. University researchers Jim and Debbie Dimmock, who married two years ago, kept the costs down to £1,300.

Debbie said: 'We had a talented friend take photos, and asked friends and relatives to bring food for the reception. People were happy to contribute - and folk surprised us with their culinary skills and generosity.

'Loads of my unmarried friends said how relaxed the day was and how much fun they'd had. Friends who married before us are still paying off the bills.'

But for real economy, head north of the border. Apart from the £32 licence fee, most Scots clergy won't charge for conducting the service, although 'a small brown envelope' for the church and the organist is usually expected. And Scots ceremonies can be performed anywhere - on top of a mountain, in your front room, or in your back garden (à la Gordon Brown).

'It always amazed me how much families would spend on weddings,' says Ralph Gordon, a former Church of Scotland minister. 'After paying the licence fee, all you need do is approach a minister, saying there will just be the bride, groom and the necessary two witnesses.

'The minister could even perform the ceremony in the family home.'

It pays to be civil

Your first call when preparing for an ordinary civil wedding in England and Wales should be to the local register office to pay a £25 notice fee. If the couple live in different districts, they must each pay this to declare their legal intention to marry 21 working days after the money is paid.

After that there is a £34 register office fee to cover the attendance of the registrar. This brings the total cost, including a £3.50 marriage certificate, to £62.50.

If you're in a hurry, you can marry by licence within days, though this raises the total cost to £105.50. A £46.50 licence fee is added to your £25 notice and £34 register office fees.

Fees for church weddings in England and Wales, in any denomination, vary locally and are likely - even at their lowest - to be higher than in Scotland.

Head north to cut costs

Some Scottish church weddings are cheaper than civil ceremonies. A church wedding requires a couple each to pay a standard £12 registrar's fee and £8 for a marriage certificate. Total cost: £32. The clergy may not charge if you are church members, though it's usual to give something for the organist and church funds.

Apart from the registrar's fee and the marriage certificate, a Scottish civil ceremony means paying a £45 'solemnisation' fee, pushing the total cost to £77. The local council may charge extra if additional rooms are needed for your guests, or if the big day is a Saturday.

You must provide ID (passport and bank statements, for example) when paying your notice fees.

Be a Friday bride

You can't avoid the bureaucratic costs, but the other bills can be kept down:

 Hold the wedding on a Friday. It keeps numbers down, and family and friends are grateful for an excuse to take a day off. Avoiding a Saturday can bring you discounts on photography and catering.

 Ask everyone to bring a bunch of flowers with them to the register office or church: it looks pretty and colourful.

 For entertainment, approach a local band and ask to pay a fixed fee. Special wedding music firms are often expensive.

 Don't tell the owner of the hall you hire for the reception that it's for a wedding. Rates can be doubled instantly.

 Write the invitations, orders of service and table place names yourself.

 Try wholesalers from Yellow Pages for food and even a wedding dress. If you're spending hundreds of pounds, the savings can be spectacular, as the mark-up on some items can be 100 per cent.

webTitle: Student debt: How to cope with payback time

fields.headline: How to cope with payback time
fields.standfirst: So you have graduated with large debts. How do you cope financially? How do you ensure that you can still enjoy yourself while you pay it off?
fields.trailText: So you have graduated with large debts. How do you cope financially? How do you ensure that you can still enjoy yourself while you pay it off?
fields.body:
For starters

If you are a recent graduate, you are probably ahead of the game. Financial advisers are finding that the current generation can cope with debt far more happily than their older siblings. 'Five years ago, students were angry about getting into debt,' says Martin Preator of the Barclays bank branch at the University of Bath. 'But nowadays they generally accept it.'

Ian Carter, welfare manager at the Student Advice Centre at Sussex University, has a similar view: 'Students never cease to amaze me. The revolutionary student seems to have died. Today's students seem far more attuned to the idea of taking credit than previous generations.'

Someone in Carter's position might well have lambasted the Government five, 10 or 20 years ago for imposing such large debts on graduates. But even as he prepares to offer advice to graduates with £15,000 of debt next summer, he does not expect to see more hardship. 'They might have a big debt to repay - but the repayment plan is a very good one.'

A side benefit could be that they actually become far better money managers than their parents. 'Neither a lender nor a borrower be' may once have been good advice but it is clearly inap propriate now for people who can take on the discipline of debt repayment.

Student loan company debts

The Glasgow-based SLC lends at very advantageous rates so it is well worth borrowing from them (if you need more than the £1,000 to £2,000 that you can get as a student in the form of a free bank overdraft). The rates are pegged to inflation - and are currently 2.6 per cent. There are about 2.5 million 'live' accounts handled by the SLC - including both new borrowers and people who are repaying.

Many new students form a poor impression of the SLC when they first try to draw down their loans. But this is not always the SLC's fault. The present loan application system is notoriously cumbersome and involves assessment of students' eligibility by the local education authorities. Students have often experienced delays - especially at this time of year - in getting through on the SLC hotline (0800 405010).

Problems often come when the loan is due to be repaid. Repayments are programmed to start the April after graduation. At present money is removed from the new graduate's account by direct debit - under an authorisation they gave when they took out the loan - unless the graduate asks for deferment. About 550,000 graduates were allowed to defer payments this year.

But some students and graduates create problems for themselves by moving house and not giving their new address to the SLC. They therefore do not get the reminder notices and are shocked when the first payment is taken out of their bank account. If they then fit the criteria for deferment, they can stop future deductions but they will not get that first repayment back.

A new system of repayment comes into place next April through which graduates repay 9 per cent of any income they earn above £10,000. On a £15,000 salary, they would repay £37 a month. On £20,000, they would repay £75 a month. Until then, graduates repay a fixed amount a month (to repay the debt in five to seven years) once their salary reaches 85 per cent of national average earnings. (The current threshold is an annual salary of £19,104, or £1,592 a month.)

If you have problems with repayment, it is best to keep the SLC informed and to negotiate with them.

Bank debts

You can get an interest-free overdraft of up to £2,000 for up to two years if you take up the best deals. Lloyds TSB offers this - the others rather less. The banks should be eager for your custom even if you have large debts. They are increasingly trying to recruit customers with future high earnings potential so they are very keen to attract graduates. They will also offer credit cards and graduate loans at lower rates than for other adults.

Expect to repay your bank loan in four to 10 years, depending on the loan size and lender. At Barclays, for instance, debts under £5,000 are expected to be repaid in five years. Loans between £5,000 and £10,000 (the maximum graduate loan) have to be repaid in seven years. Set up two accounts, advises Ian Carter of Sussex University. Use one as a budget account into which your salary is paid each month. Set up monthly direct debits to pay your electricity, telephone, rent, mortgage, student loan and other crucial payments. Arrange for a transfer each month into your second account. This is your spending money. You are far less likely to overspend and get into financial difficulties if you impose this kind of discipline on yourself.

Other debts

'A lot of people get into worse trouble in their first year after graduating than when they were students,' says Carter. 'Once you are earning, it is far easier for credit card companies to give you a card and a spending limit.' A minority of graduates find it difficult to cope with money. They fall into the obvious traps - running up debts on credit cards; storing up future trouble by not registering for council tax or with their utility suppliers; moving house without letting banks and creditors know; and not answering difficult letters.

'You can get county court judgments for relatively small amounts of money - perhaps £600 or £700,' says Marsha Healy of the Manchester Central Citizens Advice Bureau. Once you have this kind of legal black mark against your name, you will find it extremely difficult to get a mortgage, open a building society account or get other forms of credit for several years. So avoiding these judgments is very important. Negotiation often saves the day. 'If we can get involved, we can often argue that it is a temporary situation and that the person's prospects are good,' says Healy.

You will always want to be paying interest on debts at the lowest level possible. The disadvantage of credit cards is that they often charge interest rates of more than 20 per cent a year. You can usually find far better rates: from a bank, the Student Loan Company or a credit union perhaps.

Many universities will not allow students to graduate if they still owe money for fees or accommodation. But times are changing. De Montfort University in Leicester, which used to take this approach, has just introduced an 'agreement' scheme under which students can still graduate if they explain the situation and agree to a repayment schedule. Other universities will probably go this way too.

Mortgages

Over the last few years there has been an increase in twenty-somethings renting rather than buying. This may be partly caused by the need for job mobility but the existence of graduate debt is a factor. The average first-time buyer is now 32, according to the Council for Mortgage Lenders. 'Postponing buying isn't necessarily a bad thing,' says Patrick Bunton of London & Country Mortgages. 'If they are more mature, they might be able to handle the commitment better. We have seen young people who didn't really think the implications through and hadn't thought through what would happen, in a shared property, if someone wanted to leave.'

On the other hand, being cautious can mean losing out on the potential gains of a rising property market. Someone who struggled to buy a £70,000 flat in North London five years ago could now be putting it on the market for more than £170,000. Mortgage lenders are a traditionally cautious breed themselves and have always shied away from lending to people with debts.

But they will almost undoubtedly become more imaginative over the next few years in the way they approach debt-laden graduates. Northern Rock stands out at the moment for offering loans worth 120 per cent of the property value in some circumstances. In five years, lenders could be falling over themselves to offer such deals.

Pensions

The question is whether you should concentrate on paying off past debts or if you should also start preparing for the future. Independent financial adviser Peter Smith of Hill Martin says the answer should depend on individual circumstances. 'There are people who can run long-term debt without a problem. But others should get rid of it as soon as possible because it weighs on them very heavily.'

Whatever approach you take, he thinks you should have begun making pension contributions by the age of 30 at the latest: 'From 25 onwards the thought should be in the mind. If nothing has happened at 30, flashing lights should start.' Since many people want to retire by 50, they will need a good 25 years to pave the way and should really be making the payments by their mid-20s.

Graduates who are offered membership of an employer's pension scheme should think particularly seriously about this option. In most schemes - apart from some group personal pensions and the new stakeholder pension - the employer will be offering to make pension contributions on your behalf.

They could easily be putting in £50 for every £100 that you contribute. And you also get tax relief on your contributions - so, if you pay tax at the basic rate of 22 per cent, a contribution from you of £78 will be topped up by the Government with £22 to make a total contribution of £100. It is an effective use of money which, in most circumstances, it would be a shame to miss out on.

Employers have to make contributions to most of the pension schemes they run. But with group personal pensions they can opt out - although many of them still make some payment on behalf of employees. Under the new stakeholder scheme, which starts in April next year, all employers will be required to offer a scheme - a new requirement since offering a pension plan is voluntary at the moment.

Although employers will not be forced to contribute to the stakeholder pension, many will. You or your employer will need to pay charges on the stakeholder pension - but the Govern ment has capped these at 1 per cent a year.

'Golden hellos'

People graduating over the next 20 years will have some very strong cards to play with employers: in our aging population, there is a demographic shortage of young workers. Many companies are prepared to offer generous perks to attract young, talented staff. Andersen Consulting, for instance, is now offering a £6,000 'golden hello' to new analysts in their first year of employment. A second tranche of money - £4,000 - is to be paid to those new analysts a year later. Other businesses are following suit. Some also offer interest-free loans.

Advice

Many students keep their true debt levels secret from their parents. This may not be so unwise since many older people get very anxious about debt. However, obtaining some good advice can be useful. Basic guidelines on money management are now offered by many universities. De Montfort is seeing 100 students a day at its new Student Financial Advice Centre. Such places can also help you prepare for the financial demands of repaying your debts after university, when you might feel more isolated.

If you get into financial difficulties, your bank might be able to help but a very useful source of help is Citizens Advice Bureaux. They have specialist debt advisers who will help you for free, work out budgets and repayment schedules with you and write letters to your creditors. You should nearly always avoid debt advisers who charge for their help.

Take care also in your dealings with solicitors, accountants, insurance company and bank sales people and independent financial advisers. If you had a traditional education, you were probably taught to respect authority and to assume that you could rely on professionals. But many solicitors and accountants will charge you at least £50 an hour for theoretical advice. Sales people are trained to sell financial products and will want you to buy something. Most financial advisers make their money through commission on the products they sell you.

One of the great truths of life in the big bad world is that you need to be sceptical when dealing with professionals who say they have your interests at heart.

Take care also in your dealings with solicitors, accountants, insurance company and bank sales people and independent financial advisers. If you had a traditional education, you were probably taught to respect authority and to assume that you could rely on professionals. But many solicitors and accountants will charge you at least £50 an hour for theoretical advice. Sales people are trained to sell financial products and will want you to buy something. Most financial advisers make their money through commission on the products they sell you. One of the great truths of life in the big bad world is that you need to be sceptical when dealing with professionals who say they have your interests at heart.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Can I afford to put six through college?

fields.headline: Can I afford to put six through college?
fields.standfirst: IT manager Don Grunbaum is thinking long-term. He'll be over 65 by the time his youngest is ready for university, writes  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: IT manager Don Grunbaum is thinking long-term. He'll be over 65 by the time his youngest is ready for university, writes Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Don Grunbaum

Age 52

Lives in East Harling, Norfolk

Occupation IT manager

Earns joint income £40,000

Mortgage £45,000

Debts £5,000 five-year loan

Investments £3,000 in deposit accounts, Tessa, Isa

Pensions company pension

Aims to check if he is financially secure and to plan ahead for children's further education

Don Grunbaum is worried about funding his children through university. At the moment he is getting off quite lightly because his eldest child, Eleanor, 20, has just started a midwifery course. She gets her fees paid and receives a bursary of £100 a month. But her accommodation costs £50 a week and she has to commute between the university in Nottingham and a hospital in Milton Keynes.

This, though, is just the beginning. Don and his wife Wendy, 48, have another five children: Adele 15, Charlotte 13, Lydia 12, Laurence eight and Alastair four. 'As yet we're not sure what our commitment will be for Eleanor and, as we would also like to make allowances for the others to go to university, this is a long-term commitment.'

Don wants to know if they are financially secure: 'We would like to be able to replace our main family car next year. This is a 12-year-old Citroën eight-seater that we have owned for eight years.' They have another two cars which are both classics but not expensive to run. One car is a 1960 Ford Prefect which Don uses to get to work and the other a 1968 Morris Minor that has just got through its MOT. Eleanor wants this to commute between university and hospital but Don is worried about insurance costs: 'She is already a named driver on our insurance but then she will become the main driver.' Despite the two classics, cars are not Don's hobby: 'I only tinker with the cars when I have to. Most of the time it is point and pay - you point out what is wrong with it and pay someone else to do it.'

A major expense this year was a holiday in Australia for the whole family: 'We wanted to go to Sydney, despite the fact that it was a long way.'

Their four-bedroom house is worth about £150,000 although, as an 80-year-old 'one-off', it is difficult to value without putting it on the market. They have an interest-only mortgage of £45,000 with Direct Line, covered by four life insurance policies, three with Sun Alliance and one with Barclays Life. These mature over the next three years, with a projected surplus of £16,800.

Don's job includes life insurance and long-term sickness insurance. They also have a joint whole-life insurance policy for £40,000 which pays out when the first one dies.

He contributes 10 per cent of his salary to a Norwich Union pension and his employer puts in 7 per cent. Although his youngest son will still be facing GCSEs when Don is 65, he is toying with the idea of early retirement: 'I'd retire tomorrow if I could and it has been suggested that I might be able to retire two or three years early because there will be sufficient funds for me to take retirement. But I would like to know if I am contributing enough.'

Adviser 1: Joanne Cox

The spread of the children's ages means that Don and Wendy have plenty of time to save and, when the mortgage is repaid, will have extra disposable income as well as a lump sum.

As they want to change their car, and Adele is 15, their short-term needs are the more pressing. They should choose between National Savings and bank and building society accounts. For tax relief, they should maximise contributions to a mini cash Isa and take out another next year.

For the longer term, the best returns come from equity Isas, provided Don and Wendy are comfortable investing in a share-based fund. They should write down their income and expenditure to see how much it costs to keep the family afloat each month and plan forward for up to 15 years, then check if Don's sickness insurance continues if he is ill for a long time, and whether they could manage if Wendy was ill. If not, they should think about health insurance.

Don should budget for after retirement, remembering that some costs will disappear but others increase, particularly for leisure activities. If his projected pension does not cover the planned expenditure, he should save more. Wendy should check whether she can join an employer's pension scheme or look for a low-cost stakeholder pension next April.

The lump sum from the endowments could be used to repay any loans and the excess invested for future university costs.

 Joanne Cox works for Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers.

Adviser 2: Lynne Maltby

Don should bear in mind that the easiest way to increase income is to reduce outgoings. His monthly expenses will be fairly static until 2002 when the mortgage is scheduled for repayment. In the meantime, he could move his £5,000 loan on to his mortgage which will immediately release spare cash. This, in turn, could be diverted towards Eleanor's university costs.

The good news, of course, is that come September 2002 his monthly outgoings will reduce substantially, by about £450. At that time he should start a short-term cash-based saving scheme for Adele and Charlotte's university costs and look at a longer-term savings structure for the three younger children.

Regular saving maxi Isas are appropriate for his five- year objective as they provide tax-free flexibility and a range of low to medium-risk funds.

The mortgage is pivotal to Don's financial planning as it looks likely that an extra £15,000 lump sum will be available when his endowments mature. So, as well as having more money to save each month, he should use at least a proportion of the lump sum either to kickstart the savings regime or to provide an additional retirement fund for himself and Wendy.

They could think about remortgaging their home, using a repayment mortgage vehicle to tie in with Don's retirement age. This releases equity for their substantial university funding needs.

 Lynne Maltby is a manager with Willis National.

Advice is for guidance only.

You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Help: Should I get a fixed-rate or a discount mortgage?

fields.headline: Help!
fields.standfirst: Should I get a fixed-rate or a discount mortgage?
fields.trailText: Should I get a fixed-rate or a discount mortgage?
fields.body:
Most people shopping around for a mortgage need to choose between a fixed-rate or a discounted loan.

Sometimes, the decision is relatively easy - if it is clear that rates are set to rise substantially, a fixed rate is more attractive - but with rates static, as they have been for the past eight months, it is harder to predict which offers best value.

The Bank of England kept the base rate at 6 per cent again this month, and mortgage broker Charcol believes the longer interest rates stay at 6 per cent, the greater the chance they have peaked. Charcol marketing manager Siobhan Hotten predicts they will fall towards the end of the year. The broker has just brought out a new two-year fixed-rate mortgage at 5.49 per cent on 75 per cent loan to value in keeping with this prediction. However, rival broker London & Country thinks the base rate will go up by 0.25 per cent before falling away in the first quarter of next year.

If you think rates will soon fall, a discounted mortgage, where the lender charges a set amount below its standard rate, may be tempting. But David Hollingsworth, a mortgage adviser with broker London & Country, says borrowers should think about what they want. If they want the stability of knowing how much they will be paying out each month, they should go for a fixed rate.

If rates drop during the fixed period, you always have the option of switching to a mortgage with a lower rate. But then you may be hit with a redemption penalty.

There are some highly competitive fixed-rate deals on the market. The base rate would have to plummet for them to become bad value. Northern Rock offers a three-year fix at 5.39 per cent, but there is a redemption penalty equivalent to 3 per cent of the loan in the first two years and 2 per cent in the third year.

Discount rate mortgages undercut the lender's standard variable rate, which they track. Hollingsworth says they suit borrowers who can take a rate increase, or who are optimistic. Most discount mortgages have no redemption penalty in the discount period, according to Charcol, so you are free to remortgage. But remortgaging involves costs, typically £800 on a £100,000 mortgage.

Capped-rate mortgages would seem to offer the best of both worlds: security and the potential to pass on a drop in rates. There is no limit to how much the rate can fall but there is a 'cap' on rate rises. However, this type of mortgage tends to be more expensive than the fixed-rate variety. Check out fixed-rate options first.

Some lenders offer a rare hybrid - a mortgage that offers both a capped and a discount rate. But again watch out for penalties. Bristol & West is offering a mortgage capped at 4.99 per cent until 1 November 2001, after which there is a 2 per cent discount for a year.

webTitle: Endowments scandal: No surrender over shortfalls

fields.headline: No surrender over shortfalls
fields.standfirst: Homeowners who fell victim to endowments mis-selling face a daunting complaints process, writes  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Homeowners who fell victim to endowments mis-selling face a daunting complaints process, writes Maria Scott.
fields.body:
Efforts by the financial regulators to clean up the endowment scandal are failing to reassure all of the homeowners affected by shortfalls and mis-selling.

The Financial Services Authority, the chief financial regulator, announced a fortnight ago that homeowners would be required to take action themselves if they felt their endowment had been mis-sold.

It is already clear that homeowners are daunted by the task of deciding whether they have a case for redress over their endowments and what is the best way to make up for shortfalls.

Some, who have been offered settlements by insurers, are unsure whether they are being offered a fair deal.

Several Cash readers told their stories last week. One couple were sold endowment policies in 1995 by Abbey National to cover a £60,000 mortgage, and were told at the end of August that the policies may not repay the loan. The couple felt that the options sug gested by Abbey National for covering the shortfall were unattractive, and claim that the Abbey told them they had to make up their minds by the end of October because they would then have only 10 years before the loan was due to be repaid.

The couple surrendered the policies - a step experts usually warn against - but are furious about what has happened. They reckon they paid Abbey £40,000 and received a surrender value of just £13,000. They have taken out a new mortgage and life insurance and monthly payments are substantially higher than before.

Abbey said it could not comment on what had happened in this case, but suggested that the borrowers lodge an official complaint.

Another couple has been offered a refund of premiums paid on their endowment, plus interest, after complaining about the sale of an endowment that was not due to mature until after the husband retired.They are uncertain about whether they are being offered enough compensation.

In cases such as this, the next step is to take the case to the Financial Ombudsman.

In a similar case, the Ombudsman's office has found in a middle-aged couple's favour and they have been offered a refund plus interest. But both now suffer medical problems and fear that they may not be able to replace the life insurance built into the endowment.

A spokesman for the Ombudsman said that this couple's case was unlikely to have been settled and should still be open to negotiation.

The Ombudsman has made it clear that his aim is to put policyholders back into the same position they would have been in had they not taken out the endowment. This will often mean ordering a company to refund premiums, plus interest, but the Ombudsman has made it clear that he will take ill-health, and its effect on the homeowner's ability to get life cover into account when assessing compensation.

Key points for unhappy endowment owners:

 Complain to your lender or insurer first. Read the advice in the FSA leaflet on complaints, obtainable by calling: 0845 606 1234

 If you are unhappy about the insurer's response, go to the Financial Services Ombudsman. The ombudsman's website at www.financial-ombudsman.org.uk has details of how the office awards compensation.

webTitle: Alternative investments: Custard cups that cheer

fields.headline: Custard cups that cheer
fields.standfirst: Suddenly 18th century pots are worth hundreds, says  John Windsor
fields.trailText: Suddenly 18th century pots are worth hundreds, says John Windsor.
fields.body:
New collectables are cropping up all the time. Ten years ago, collectors of antique fishing tackle, fountain pens, vinyl records and even modern first-edition books were thought to be chucking their money away. More recently, vintage television sets, HMS Titanic memorabilia, TV show tie-in toys and Beanie babies all found a market, and handbags and tattooists' accessories now vie for places in Miller's Collectables Price Guide.

But some collectables are 'sleepers' in that it takes more than a year or two, or perhaps a decade, for collectors to notice them. Centuries may pass before they are recognised and their prices begin to rise.

Two such sleepers will be for sale at two forthcoming fairs in London. Pieces made by cabinet makers' apprentices will be at this week's Lapada (the former London and Provincial Art and Antique Dealers' Association) Fine Art and Antiques Fair at the Commonwealth Institute, in west London. And custard cups, used originally for serving consommé, will be at Olympia next month. Both date back to the eighteenth century and both, in their time, have been mistaken for other things.

The miniature chests of drawers, chairs and tables have sometimes been mistaken for dolls' house furniture. But while they are small enough to hold in the hand, they are too big for dolls' houses.

A second glance reveals exquisite dovetailing and mitring, drawers that fit so perfectly that they emit a puff of air when closed. Too fine for the playroom, the purpose of this miniaturisation was not to amuse children but to test the precision of the teenage apprentices' craftsmanship.

Helen Linfield, of the Sussex dealer Wakelin and Linfield, will be offering a selection of apprentice pieces at the fair. These were 'portable examples of the cabinet maker's abilities', she says.

'Miniature furniture was sometimes displayed in shops as examples of pieces that could be made full-size. Not many pieces survive from before the beginning of the eighteenth century.

'I love the craftsmanship; the detail. In the finest pieces, the proportions are correct - even the locks are to scale - and the veneers are matched. They are identical replicas.' Today, miniature bureau bookcases with many little drawers are sometimes used to store jewellery and cufflinks.

Custard cups are just as versatile. They are sometimes called cream cups, mustard pots, and even mistaken for bourdaloues, those ceramic chamber pots used discreetly by ladies in carriages and at the theatre. 'Custard cup' is actually a change of use by the British that has obliterated knowledge of the dazzling regal origins of these 7-8cm tall porcelain pots with lids and single handles.

Custard, indeed! They were designed to drink from, and contained rich consommé made from the roast at royal banquets in France of almost unimaginable splendour.

Among eighteenth century European royalty, following the re-invention of porcelain at Meissen, there was a mania for dinner services. Sometimes comprising more than 2,000 pieces, they took years to make and cost more than their weight in gold. They became symbols of power, gifts to foster international alliances, influence betrothals and reward loyalty. Napoleon gave them to friends and enemies alike. Catherine the Great of Russia owned 20 or 30.

With the prized porcelain as a centrepiece, dinners were pure theatre. Seven or eight courses, 20 or more dishes at each course, and a footman standing behind each diner to reach for dishes laid out like a formal garden amid fountains, statuary and chandeliers. The eating and drinking could last six hours.

Into this fabulous display were brought the jewels of the dinner service: lidded, single-handled pots à jus containing hot, rich consommé.

Meanwhile, in England, the farmer king George III would have none of such junketing. He did not collect dinner services and was unusual among European royalty in not owning a porcelain factory. So when the English aristocracy began importing continental porcelain, the little pots à jus were a mystery. But English ingenuity was not to be defeated. They became custard cups.

A solecism, perhaps, but their incorrect use has inspired some tasty recipes for custard-and-liqueur desserts and syllabubs. A couple are given below.

More than 80 European factories made 'custard cups' in that century. Besides the top-ranking Sèvres, they included Chantilly, Sceaux, Mennecy and Bough le Reine. Potteries in this country also made them.

A collection of more than 350 custard cups - the biggest ever assembled - will be displayed at Olympia by Ulla Stafford, who will have about 30 to sell.

Her newly published book, Custard Cups: Pots à Jus , illustrates them and explores the various, confusing names they have been called. In nineteenth century France, bourgeoisie outside the palace banquet circuit who bought them separately began calling them pots à crème, the Swedes called them jelly cups, the Germans crème topfchen or cocots, and the Danes iis cups - ice cups. The book is a must-have for collectors hoping to spot wrongly identified and cheap custard cups on sale.

Stafford says: 'If you've got the knowledge, you can do extremely well. But it's going to take me another few years before I have completely cracked their history.'

Not only antique collectors but chefs and gastronomes should take a hint from her discoveries, for today the convenience and practicality of drinking a small quantity of hot, highly concentrated concoction from a pot à jus has been all but forgotten. Only the French preserve a vestige of it, using them to serve turtle soup.

Among those in the know, prices of custard cups are rising. A French dealer was recently asking £3,000 for a pair of apple green Sèvres cups. Made in 1771, they had fetched £150 at a London auction, then been sold for £300 in London's Camden Passage antiques market to a trader who sold them on to him for £900. Stafford persuaded the French dealer to part with them for £2,200. They are now part of her collection, and not for sale.

If you come across a set of six custard cups that have not been parted from their matching porcelain tray, it will be worth five figures.

At the fair, she will be offering printed English custard cups of 1790-1820 from £250 each. A Vienna cup of 1792 is priced at £450. A Fürstenberg cup of 1765 and a 1760 Mennecy cup are £600 each.

Custard cups seldom appear at auction, are occasionally mis-catalogued, usually lotted together with other pieces, and sometimes go unnoticed. Prices are therefore patchy. At Christie's in South Kensington last month, two Sèvres cups of 1775, correctly described as both custard cups and pots à jus, together with a flat 'sauce tureen' of 1763 that some would swear was a matching tray, had estimated prices of between £1,000 and £1,500 the pair. They were snapped up for £1,292.

At Bonhams and Brooks a year ago, eight Wedgwood custard cups from the nineteenth century, lotted among 22 other pieces, went for £253 (estimate £150-£250) and the previous year another eight English ones, in a lot of 17 pieces, fetched £275 (estimate £100-£150).

Only last month, at Phillips, bidders pushed the price of two English Caughley custard cups of 1785-95, both with minor chips, to a whopping £575 the pair (estimate:£160-£200).

As for apprentice pieces, which are now in demand by American collectors, auction prices are now comfortably exceeding estimates. At Bonhams and Brooks in April a George II miniature walnut and feather banded bureau with unusual glazed fall, 24cm tall, exceeded its estimate of between £2,000 and £3,000, selling for £4,370.

The Sussex dealer Helen Linfield says: 'Miniature pieces can command prices as high as their full-size counterparts, from as little as £500 for a country-made chest of drawers to £25,000 for an exquisite, accurately proportioned bureau bookcase.'

At the fair, Ingrid Nelson of Cranbrook, Kent, will be offering a 44cm high English miniature bureau in oak with brass fittings, the fall revealing six small drawers and six arched compartments, priced at £5,750.

More information

fields.bodyText: New collectables are cropping up all the time. Ten years ago, collectors of antique fishing tackle, fountain pens, vinyl records and even modern first-edition books were thought to be chucking their money away. More recently, vintage television sets, HMS Titanic memorabilia, TV show tie-in toys and Beanie babies all found a market, and handbags and tattooists' accessories now vie for places in Miller's Collectables Price Guide. But some collectables are 'sleepers' in that it takes more than a year or two, or perhaps a decade, for collectors to notice them. Centuries may pass before they are recognised and their prices begin to rise. Two such sleepers will be for sale at two forthcoming fairs in London. Pieces made by cabinet makers' apprentices will be at this week's Lapada (the former London and Provincial Art and Antique Dealers' Association) Fine Art and Antiques Fair at the Commonwealth Institute, in west London. And custard cups, used originally for serving consommé, will be at Olympia next month. Both date back to the eighteenth century and both, in their time, have been mistaken for other things. The miniature chests of drawers, chairs and tables have sometimes been mistaken for dolls' house furniture. But while they are small enough to hold in the hand, they are too big for dolls' houses. A second glance reveals exquisite dovetailing and mitring, drawers that fit so perfectly that they emit a puff of air when closed. Too fine for the playroom, the purpose of this miniaturisation was not to amuse children but to test the precision of the teenage apprentices' craftsmanship. Helen Linfield, of the Sussex dealer Wakelin and Linfield, will be offering a selection of apprentice pieces at the fair. These were 'portable examples of the cabinet maker's abilities', she says. 'Miniature furniture was sometimes displayed in shops as examples of pieces that could be made full-size. Not many pieces survive from before the beginning of the eighteenth century. 'I love the craftsmanship; the detail. In the finest pieces, the proportions are correct - even the locks are to scale - and the veneers are matched. They are identical replicas.' Today, miniature bureau bookcases with many little drawers are sometimes used to store jewellery and cufflinks. Custard cups are just as versatile. They are sometimes called cream cups, mustard pots, and even mistaken for bourdaloues, those ceramic chamber pots used discreetly by ladies in carriages and at the theatre. 'Custard cup' is actually a change of use by the British that has obliterated knowledge of the dazzling regal origins of these 7-8cm tall porcelain pots with lids and single handles. Custard, indeed! They were designed to drink from, and contained rich consommé made from the roast at royal banquets in France of almost unimaginable splendour. Among eighteenth century European royalty, following the re-invention of porcelain at Meissen, there was a mania for dinner services. Sometimes comprising more than 2,000 pieces, they took years to make and cost more than their weight in gold. They became symbols of power, gifts to foster international alliances, influence betrothals and reward loyalty. Napoleon gave them to friends and enemies alike. Catherine the Great of Russia owned 20 or 30. With the prized porcelain as a centrepiece, dinners were pure theatre. Seven or eight courses, 20 or more dishes at each course, and a footman standing behind each diner to reach for dishes laid out like a formal garden amid fountains, statuary and chandeliers. The eating and drinking could last six hours. Into this fabulous display were brought the jewels of the dinner service: lidded, single-handled pots à jus containing hot, rich consommé. Meanwhile, in England, the farmer king George III would have none of such junketing. He did not collect dinner services and was unusual among European royalty in not owning a porcelain factory. So when the English aristocracy began importing continental porcelain, the little pots à jus were a mystery. But English ingenuity was not to be defeated. They became custard cups. A solecism, perhaps, but their incorrect use has inspired some tasty recipes for custard-and-liqueur desserts and syllabubs. A couple are given below. More than 80 European factories made 'custard cups' in that century. Besides the top-ranking Sèvres, they included Chantilly, Sceaux, Mennecy and Bough le Reine. Potteries in this country also made them. A collection of more than 350 custard cups - the biggest ever assembled - will be displayed at Olympia by Ulla Stafford, who will have about 30 to sell. Her newly published book, Custard Cups: Pots à Jus , illustrates them and explores the various, confusing names they have been called. In nineteenth century France, bourgeoisie outside the palace banquet circuit who bought them separately began calling them pots à crème, the Swedes called them jelly cups, the Germans crème topfchen or cocots, and the Danes iis cups - ice cups. The book is a must-have for collectors hoping to spot wrongly identified and cheap custard cups on sale. Stafford says: 'If you've got the knowledge, you can do extremely well. But it's going to take me another few years before I have completely cracked their history.' Not only antique collectors but chefs and gastronomes should take a hint from her discoveries, for today the convenience and practicality of drinking a small quantity of hot, highly concentrated concoction from a pot à jus has been all but forgotten. Only the French preserve a vestige of it, using them to serve turtle soup. Among those in the know, prices of custard cups are rising. A French dealer was recently asking £3,000 for a pair of apple green Sèvres cups. Made in 1771, they had fetched £150 at a London auction, then been sold for £300 in London's Camden Passage antiques market to a trader who sold them on to him for £900. Stafford persuaded the French dealer to part with them for £2,200. They are now part of her collection, and not for sale. If you come across a set of six custard cups that have not been parted from their matching porcelain tray, it will be worth five figures. At the fair, she will be offering printed English custard cups of 1790-1820 from £250 each. A Vienna cup of 1792 is priced at £450. A Fürstenberg cup of 1765 and a 1760 Mennecy cup are £600 each. Custard cups seldom appear at auction, are occasionally mis-catalogued, usually lotted together with other pieces, and sometimes go unnoticed. Prices are therefore patchy. At Christie's in South Kensington last month, two Sèvres cups of 1775, correctly described as both custard cups and pots à jus, together with a flat 'sauce tureen' of 1763 that some would swear was a matching tray, had estimated prices of between £1,000 and £1,500 the pair. They were snapped up for £1,292. At Bonhams and Brooks a year ago, eight Wedgwood custard cups from the nineteenth century, lotted among 22 other pieces, went for £253 (estimate £150-£250) and the previous year another eight English ones, in a lot of 17 pieces, fetched £275 (estimate £100-£150). Only last month, at Phillips, bidders pushed the price of two English Caughley custard cups of 1785-95, both with minor chips, to a whopping £575 the pair (estimate:£160-£200). As for apprentice pieces, which are now in demand by American collectors, auction prices are now comfortably exceeding estimates. At Bonhams and Brooks in April a George II miniature walnut and feather banded bureau with unusual glazed fall, 24cm tall, exceeded its estimate of between £2,000 and £3,000, selling for £4,370. The Sussex dealer Helen Linfield says: 'Miniature pieces can command prices as high as their full-size counterparts, from as little as £500 for a country-made chest of drawers to £25,000 for an exquisite, accurately proportioned bureau bookcase.' webTitle: Student debt: A debtor and a scholar

fields.headline: A debtor and a scholar
fields.standfirst: Students face life after university £35,000 in the red. But it needn't be hell, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Students face life after university £35,000 in the red. But it needn't be hell, says Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
Following the example of the US is usually seen as a bad way of doing things in this country - whether it means becoming more litigious, saying 'Have a nice day' or eating in McDonald's.

But one of the biggest areas of Americanisation in the last decade has been our system of financing higher education. Current undergraduates now have to pay for their own maintenance and tuition fees - a source of anxiety to many parents, who got their own degrees for free.

And the load is getting heavier on new graduates. The complete withdrawal of grants means that students graduating next summer are likely to have debts of between £12,000 and £15,000, according to the National Union of Students - a massive hike on the £5,300 average debt for students graduating in 1999, according to research by Barclays bank.

For the class of 2000, debt was reduced because many received grants each year. But most of the class of 2001 will have studied under a new system with no grant so they took out government loans through the Student Loans Company. The maximum loan this year is £3,445 outside London (£4,590 in the capital). Unlike their parents, they are also paying tuition fees of £1,050 a year, with calls from the universities to raise them to as much as £4,000 a year.

But if we follow the US example, our graduates could be leaving university with debts closer to £35,000 - or more if studying medicine, law or business. US universities are free to set their own fees - and many of them charge more than £10,000 a year. Putting a child through college has spawned a huge financial industry in the US. You can even get tips on the web about keeping costs down when the family goes on a two-week trip with young Freddie in the camper van to visit the different universities on offer.

In the UK we are seeing the start of similar moves. Calls from the top universities for more freedom in setting fees is just one part of a new desire for greater liberalisation. Conservative Party proposals to give huge endowments to universities and let them manage their own money is another move in the same direction. If Oxford University - current endowment funds estimated at £1.5 billion - ends up with funds in the order of £10bn (the amount that Harvard sits on), then it is likely to take a more commercial approach both to the setting of fees and to the awarding of scholarships.

A big difference between the countries is that Americans are far more likely to get bursaries and scholarships than Britons. Laura Spence, the would-be medical student rejected by Oxford in controversial circumstances this year, is just starting her Harvard course after winning grants worth £65,000.

Whenever you hear experts expressing their worry about the brain drain, you can expect the argument to go towards giving universities a freer hand in setting fees. US academics earn considerably more than their UK counterparts. The simplest way to pay lecturers higher salaries would be to put up course fees but that would almost certainly lead to even greater graduate debt.

In the US, students and their families are far more likely to see higher education as a commodity. They are unlikely to run up debts of £35,000 by the age of 21 unless they think it worthwhile financially in the long run. This kind of consideration is already becoming more important here. The economics department at Warwick University recently produced a report which shows that a first-class degree is worth, on average, 12 per cent more in likely future earnings than a third and that male law and politics graduates (the best paid) are likely to earn twice as much as female agriculture graduates (the worst paid). Research from the High Fliers recruitment agency suggests a link between university and future pay - with Imperial College (London), Oxford and Cambridge graduates likely to earn a third more than Glasgow and Cardiff alumni.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders sees graduate debt as 'an issue we can't afford to ignore', according to deputy director general Peter Williams. Might graduates postpone buying property so they can pay off their debts? What effect does this have on house prices if the bottom rung of first-time buyers suddenly falls away? Research conducted for the council by analysts London Economics concludes that the effect is likely to be minimal - not least because graduates tend to earn well and become quite accustomed to dealing with debt. But the council will continue to monitor the situation - especially if interest rates rise and the economic climate becomes less buoyant.

Whatever the effect on property prices and ownership all graduates will have to learn to deal with debt.

£13,000 of debt - but Kate's had a ball

Kate Emmanuel graduated in 1998 and still has about £13,000 of debt - but she is happy about it.

During her four-year international manage-ment and French course at the University of Bath, she spent a year in Montreal and then, a few months after graduation, went to New York for several months.

'I have had a brilliant time,' says the 23-year old. 'Some of my friends scrimped and saved throughout university and never took out a loan. But I took out all the loans I could - and I did what I wanted.

'If I wanted to go out for a meal, I did. I didn't live off baked beans. So now I have a big dump of debt to pay off - but most people have a mortgage to pay off. It's just like paying that.'

She was the first person from her family to go to university, encouraged by a careers adviser who was impressed by her results at school.

Although she was one of the last undergraduates to get a grant, she still needed other funds. So she got a free overdraft with the campus branch of Barclays ('they have been brilliant') and, in each of the four years, she drew down her full loan from the Student Loan Company.

Her plan was to maximise her income, rather than cutting the outgoings. In her second year, she worked in a café. In her final year, she worked in a French restaurant in the city. 'It meant that I met all the French people in Bath. I was constantly having conversations in French.'

When she graduated in July 1998, she knew that payback time had arrived. She took two jobs - as an office manager in the day, and a waitress some evenings - to pay off the £3,000 overdraft she had accumulated.

She paid off this by May 1999 when she went to New York, having negotiated another £3,000 loan from Barclays.

Now she is working for an internet service provider in Cardiff. Having started as a PA there, she has expanded her role to include liaison.

She is also preparing to start repaying her student loan from April. Her fairly low level of earnings means that she has not had to repay any so far.

She does not worry about her debts now. When she was at university, however, she did have the occasional sleepless night. But when she went to see her bank and discussed her affairs with them, she learnt how to control the situation.

This seems to be the key to her peace of mind: 'As long as my finances were in control they were fine. I realised that as long as I tightened up in one area, I could survive if I really wanted to pay for something else.'

So now she is on the verge of buying a car - on hire purchase. She does not need to worry about buying a house - because she now lives with her partner in Cardiff and he had already bought a property.

The pension is the next issue. 'It's something I want to get sorted out - even if it's only a small amount.'

She knows that it will take 'quite a few years' to clear these debts, but says: 'It's not daunting.'

Is she typical of her friends? 'Money wasn't something that people talked about much - a lot of people wanted to keep it to themselves. But for some of my friends, it was their parents who took on the extra jobs to see them through education.

'Some just had wealthy parents. Some took on all the debts they could, like me. And some applied for hardship funds.'
